questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient with paronychia, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paronychia is an infection of the nail fold, presenting with redness, swelling, tenderness, and pus formation.
  • Acute paronychia is most often bacterial, caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) provides coverage against Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes, making it the drug of choice for acute bacterial paronychia.
  • Along with antibiotics, if pus is present, incision and drainage may be required.

Paronychia:

  • Acute paronychia:
    • Cause: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus.
    • Onset: Rapid, painful swelling with pus.
    • Treatment: Drainage (if abscess) + Amoxiclav.
  • Chronic paronychia:
    • Cause: Candida albicans most common.
    • Onset: Gradual swelling, less painful, usually without pus.
    • Treatment: Antifungals (eg, topical clotrimazole, oral fluconazole in resistant cases).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Metronidazole (Option B): Effective against anaerobes and protozoa but not first-line for Staphylococcus or Streptococcus, which are the main causative organisms.

Amikacin (Option C): An aminoglycoside targeting Gram-negative bacilli. It is not effective against the Gram-positive organisms commonly responsible for paronychia.

Norfloxacin (Option D): A fluoroquinolone with poor coverage against Staphylococcus aureus. It is not recommended for soft tissue infections like paronychia.

Key Takeaway:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the treatment of choice for acute paronychia because it provides broad coverage against the most common causative bacteria. Chronic paronychia, however, requires antifungal therapy since Candida is the usual culprit.

choices.text: Neurovascular Assessment and Closed reduction and slab application
Neurovascular Assessment and Closed reduction and cast application
Neurovascular Assessments and Immediate open reduction

questions.text: An RTA patient was presented to the emergency department with severe pain in the Ankle, an X ray was performed as given below. What is the best next step of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In all cases of trauma, the first step is neurovascular assessment to check for distal pulses, capillary refill, and nerve function, since dislocations and fractures can compromise vascular supply.
  • The immediate management of a fracture-dislocation of the ankle is closed reduction to restore alignment and relieve pressure on soft tissues and neurovascular structures.
  • After successful reduction, a slab (posterior splint) is applied instead of a complete cast. This is because swelling is common after acute trauma, and a cast may increase the risk of compartment syndrome as it does not allow room for expansion.
  • A slab provides stability while accommodating swelling, serving as the appropriate temporary immobilization until definitive treatment.

Fracture-dislocation of the ankle:

  • First step: Neurovascular assessment.
  • Next step: Immediate closed reduction.
  • Immobilization: Posterior slab preferred in acute phase.
  • Definitive management: If closed reduction is unstable or unsuccessful, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) is performed once swelling subsides.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Neurovascular Assessment and Closed reduction and cast application (Option B): Incorrect because a cast is contraindicated acutely-it does not allow for swelling and increases the risk of compartment syndrome.

Neurovascular Assessment and Immediate surgery (Option C): Surgery may ultimately be needed, but the initial step is always closed reduction. Immediate surgery is not performed without first attempting closed reduction and temporary immobilization.

Neurovascular Assessment and Immediate open reduction (Option D): Incorrect because open reduction is only considered if closed reduction fails or if there are open fractures or vascular compromise. Initial management is closed reduction with slab.

Key Takeaway:

In an ankle fracture-dislocation following trauma, the priority is neurovascular assessment, immediate closed reduction, and immobilization with a slab to allow swelling. A cast is avoided initially, and surgery is reserved for cases where closed reduction is unstable or unsuccessful.

questions.text: What is the enzyme defect if a child with anemia, thrombocytopenia, bony pain, and hepatosplenomegaly shows a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on light microscopy of bone marrow aspirate?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

  • The underlying defect is in the enzyme beta-glucosidase (also called glucocerebrosidase).
  • This defect causes the accumulation of glucosylceramide (glucocerebroside) within macrophages.
  • These engorged macrophages are termed Gaucher cells, which display the classic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on bone marrow aspirate due to fibrillary inclusions in the cytoplasm.
  • The infiltration of Gaucher cells in bone marrow, liver, and spleen explains the clinical findings of anemia, thrombocytopenia, bony pain, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Sphingomyelinase (Option B):

  • Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease.
  • In this condition, bone marrow aspirates reveal foamy histiocytes packed with lipid-filled cytoplasm, not the crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Hexosaminidase (Option C):

  • Defective in Tay-Sachs disease.
  • It does not typically cause anemia, thrombocytopenia, or bony pain.
  • Histopathology may demonstrate an "onion-skin" appearance of lysosomes, which is distinct from Gaucher disease.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option D):

  • Deficiency results in Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I).
  • Patients present with hepatosplenomegaly and sometimes bone pain, but anemia and thrombocytopenia are not characteristic.

The hallmark is hypoglycemia with glycogen accumulation, not Gaucher cells.

Reference: Gaucher disease

questions.text: Which organization is responsible for vaccines, child health and nutrition, safe water and sanitation, quality education, and skill-building?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

UNICEF (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) is the primary organization dedicated to promoting and protecting the rights and well-being of children worldwide. Its mandate includes:

  • Vaccines and Immunization: Ensures children have access to life-saving vaccines.
  • Child Health and Nutrition: Implements programs for growth monitoring, micronutrient supplementation, and high-protein, low-cost food mixes.
  • Safe Water and Sanitation: Promotes clean water supply and sanitation to reduce child morbidity and mortality.
  • Quality Education and Skill-Building: Supports early childhood education, female literacy, and vocational skills programs.
  • Family and Child Welfare: Works on family planning, breastfeeding promotion, and overall child development.

UNICEF operates globally, especially in developing countries, providing both emergency relief and long-term developmental programs. Its approach is holistic, addressing health, nutrition, education, and overall welfare of children.

Established in 1946 with its headquarters in New York, UNICEF works in over 190 countries and territories. A famous and historically significant initiative summarizing its focus on child survival is the GOBI-FFF campaign:

  • G - Growth monitoring
  • O - Oral rehydration therapy
  • B - Breastfeeding promotion
  • I - Immunization
  • F - Female education
  • F - Family spacing
  • F - Food supplementation

Explanation of Other Options:

CARE (Option A): A humanitarian organization primarily targeting global poverty and emergency relief; it works on health and nutrition but does not focus specifically on child immunization, education, or skill-building.

UNDP (Option B): Focuses on sustainable development, poverty reduction, and governance; it is not primarily responsible for child-specific health, nutrition, or educational programs.

WHO (Option D): Responsible for global health policy, disease prevention, and health standards; it supports vaccination programs but does not implement holistic child development, nutrition, or education initiatives like UNICEF.

Reference:

https://www.unicef.org/media/84666/file/SOWC-1984.pdf

questions.text: In an urban area of Madhya Pradesh, a primigravida undergoes institutional delivery after being motivated by an ASHA worker. What are the monetary benefits (in rupees) provided under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a centrally sponsored scheme launched in 2005 under the National Health Mission (NHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries through conditional cash transfers.

The amount of benefit under JSY varies depending on:

  1. Geographic region - High Performing States (HPS) vs. Low Performing States (LPS).
  2. Place of residence - Urban vs. Rural.
  3. Eligibility criteria - All pregnant women in LPS vs. only BPL/SC/ST in HPS.

Since Madhya Pradesh is an LPS, all pregnant women delivering in government or accredited private institutions are entitled to benefits.

Monetary Benefits in Urban Areas of LPS (e.g., Madhya Pradesh):

  • Mother: Rs 1000 for institutional delivery.
  • ASHA worker: Rs 400 for motivating and accompanying the mother.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of paresis (motor weakness) without numbness suggests that motor fibers were preferentially affected while sensory fibers remained intact.
  • Motor supply is mediated predominantly by large, myelinated A fibers (Aα), which are highly sensitive to mechanical pressure.
  • Sensory pain fibers (C fibers), being small and unmyelinated, are more resistant to pressure but more vulnerable to metabolic stress such as hypoxia.
  • Hence, A fibers succumb to compression during sleep, producing temporary weakness without sensory loss.

Nerve Fiber Classification (A, B, and C Fibers):

  • A Fibers: Large, myelinated, fastest conduction; transmit sharp pain, touch, proprioception, and pressure.
  • B Fibers: Smaller, myelinated, moderate conduction; regulate autonomic functions.
  • C Fibers: Smallest, unmyelinated, slow conduction; carry dull pain, temperature, and polymodal sensory input.

Subtypes of A Fibers:

  • Aα → Motor and proprioception.
  • Aβ → Touch and pressure.
  • Aδ → Sharp pain and temperature.

Sensitivity to Stimuli:

  • A Fibers: Highly pressure-sensitive, rapidly conducting.
  • B Fibers: Autonomic, less sensitive to pressure.
  • C Fibers: More resistant to pressure, but sensitive to hypoxia and chemical changes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers (Option A): C fibers are unmyelinated and less pressure-sensitive compared to A fibers; they mainly transmit dull pain and temperature.
  • A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers (Option B): B fibers are actually more sensitive to hypoxia than A fibers because of their smaller diameter and autonomic role.
  • A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers (Option D): C fibers are more vulnerable to hypoxia than A fibers due to their unmyelinated structure and slower metabolism.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6121522/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551652/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539845/

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot of a farmer that appeared after a minor injury, with microscope revealing copper penny bodies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hallmark feature here is the presence of copper penny bodies (Medlar bodies) on microscopy, which are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis.
  • Clinically, the disease presents as a slow-growing, cauliflower-like verrucous lesion, typically on exposed areas like the feet after trauma with contaminated soil or vegetation.
  • It commonly affects farmers and individuals exposed to rural environments.

Chromoblastomycosis:

  • Causative organisms: Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora, Phialophora.
  • Risk factor: Minor trauma in agricultural workers.
  • Clinical appearance: Verrucous, cauliflower-like lesions that spread slowly but can become disfiguring if untreated.
  • Microscopy: Thick-walled, pigmented fungal cells called Medlar bodies or copper penny bodies.
  • Spread: Chronic, localized; lymphatic spread is uncommon.
  • Treatment: Prolonged antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine; surgical excision for localized severe disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Blastomycosis (Option B): Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. Typically presents with pulmonary infection or ulcerative skin lesions. It does not produce verrucous cauliflower-like growths or Medlar bodies.

Sporotrichosis (Option C): Known as "rose gardener's disease," caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Characterized by nodular lesions spreading along lymphatic channels. It does not produce localized cauliflower-like masses or copper penny bodies.

Phaeohyphomycosis (Option D): Caused by dematiaceous fungi (darkly pigmented), but histology shows pigmented septate hyphae, not Medlar bodies. Clinical presentation is variable but not typically cauliflower-shaped verrucous growths.

Key Takeaway:

A cauliflower-shaped verrucous lesion on the foot of a farmer with copper penny bodies on microscopy is diagnostic of chromoblastomycosis. It is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis caused by pigmented fungi, managed with prolonged antifungal therapy and, in some cases, surgery.

questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for the occurrence of hyperthermia and muscle rigidity in a patient undergoing surgery while being administered anesthesia with halothane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of halothane anesthesia with suxamethonium (succinylcholine) can precipitate malignant hyperthermia (MH) in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • MH is a life-threatening pharmacogenetic disorder characterized by:
    • Hyperthermia
    • Generalized muscle rigidity
    • Hypercapnia (increased CO₂)
    • Tachycardia and metabolic acidosis
  • The underlying mechanism is uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle due to abnormal ryanodine receptors, leading to sustained muscle contraction and heat production.
  • Immediate treatment is with IV dantrolene, which inhibits calcium release, along with supportive measures like cooling and correcting metabolic derangements.

Malignant Hyperthermia:

  • Triggers: Volatile anesthetics (halothane, sevoflurane, isoflurane, desflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine).
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant inheritance, commonly involving mutations in the RYR1 gene.
  • Complications: Rhabdomyolysis, arrhythmias, renal failure, and death if untreated.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

D-curare (Option A): A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It does not trigger malignant hyperthermia.

Cis-atracurium (Option C): A non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, known for organ-independent metabolism (Hofmann elimination). It is safe and not associated with MH.

Rocuronium (Option D): Another non-depolarizing agent, commonly used for rapid sequence intubation. It does not cause malignant hyperthermia.

Key Takeaway:

Suxamethonium in combination with halothane can precipitate malignant hyperthermia in susceptible patients. Prompt recognition and immediate administration of dantrolene are critical to reduce mortality.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done using the image shown below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The investigation shown is Hysterosalpingography (HSG), where a radiopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes, followed by X-ray imaging. In this case, the image demonstrates a unicornuate uterus, a congenital uterine anomaly that can contribute to recurrent miscarriages.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG)


  • Purpose: Assess uterine cavity and tubal patency.
  • Technique: Retrograde injection of iodinated contrast with serial X-rays.
  • Preparation:
    • NSAID 30 mins before (to prevent tubal spasm)
    • Paracervical block if cervical stenosis
  • Phases of imaging:
    • Preliminary (before contrast)
    • Contrast filling of the uterine cavity
    • Spillage of contrast into the peritoneum
    • Withdrawal/deflation phase
  • Contraindications:
    • Acute pelvic infection
    • Active uterine bleeding
    • Iodine allergy
    • Pregnancy
  • Prophylaxis: Doxycycline may be given if dilated tubes (hydrosalpinx) are seen.
  • Complications: Pelvic pain, vasovagal reaction, dye allergy, uterine perforation.

Explanation of other options:

Hysteroscopy (Option A): Involves direct visualisation of the uterine cavity with a hysteroscope, mainly for diagnosis and treatment of intrauterine pathology.

Saline infusion sonography (Option B): Uses sterile saline with transvaginal ultrasound to detect intrauterine abnormalities such as septa, polyps, or fibroids.

Transvaginal ultrasonography (Option D): High-frequency ultrasound probe introduced vaginally; commonly used for follicle monitoring, endometrial assessment, and adnexal pathology, but does not assess tubal patency.

Key Takeaway:

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is the investigation of choice for assessing uterine cavity shape and fallopian tube patency in women with infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss.

Reference: [DT1]https://share.google/images/UqjBcDd9CXyAVG0BA

questions.text: A patient presents with acute exacerbation of asthma. He gives a history of sinusitis and headaches for which he had self-medicated. On examination, nasal polyps are found. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for triggering this episode of asthma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of asthma, nasal polyps, and intolerance to aspirin/NSAIDs defines Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), previously known as Samter's triad.
  • In these patients, aspirin or other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 can provoke bronchospasm, rhinitis, and sometimes anaphylaxis.
  • The underlying mechanism involves a shift of arachidonic acid metabolism towards leukotriene production, leading to bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation.
  • Hence, aspirin is contraindicated, and NSAIDs such as ibuprofen should also be avoided.

AERD:

  • Clinical triad: bronchial asthma, recurrent nasal polyposis, and NSAID hypersensitivity.
  • Pathophysiology: COX-1 inhibition decreases prostaglandin synthesis and increases cysteinyl leukotriene production, worsening airway obstruction.
  • Management:
    • Avoid aspirin and non-selective NSAIDs.
    • Leukotriene receptor antagonists (eg, montelukast) can be beneficial.
    • Corticosteroids and endoscopic sinus surgery may be required for severe nasal polyposis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): A combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim used as an antibiotic. It has no known association with Samter's triad or asthma exacerbation.

Co-amoxiclav (Option B): Combination of amoxicillin with clavulanic acid, commonly used for bacterial infections such as sinusitis. It does not trigger aspirin-sensitive asthma.

Chloramphenicol (Option D): A broad-spectrum antibiotic with limited modern use. It is not implicated in respiratory disease or aspirin-induced bronchospasm.

Key Takeaway:

In patients with asthma and nasal polyposis, the use of aspirin or other NSAIDs can precipitate life-threatening bronchospasm due to aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (Samter's triad). The correct management involves strict avoidance of COX-1 inhibitors and consideration of leukotriene-targeted therapy.

questions.text: A female patient collapses soon after delivery. There is profuse bleeding and features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sudden collapse after delivery, with profuse bleeding and features of DIC, is most consistent with Amniotic Fluid Embolism (AFE).

Amniotic Fluid Embolism (AFE)

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Amniotic fluid or fetal debris enters maternal circulation.
    • Triggers a systemic inflammatory and anaphylactoid reaction.
    • Leads to hemodynamic collapse, respiratory compromise, and coagulopathy (DIC).
  • Presentation:
    • Sudden hypotension or cardiac arrest.
    • Respiratory distress (dyspnea, cyanosis, gasping).
    • Profuse bleeding from DIC.
    • Neurological symptoms: agitation, seizures, altered consciousness.
  • Timing:
    • Usually during labor, immediately postpartum, or within 30 minutes after delivery.
  • Clinical Triad:
    • Hemodynamic collapse
    • Respiratory compromise
    • DIC

Explanation of other options:

Postpartum hemorrhage (Option B): Causes hypovolemic shock but not abrupt DIC in most cases.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (Option C): Presents with heart failure and collapse, but not associated with bleeding/DIC.

Rupture of uterus (Option D): Can cause massive hemorrhage and rarely DIC, but sudden cardiorespiratory collapse + DIC triad is more typical of AFE.

Key Takeaway:

  • Amniotic fluid embolism is the most likely cause of sudden maternal collapse with profuse bleeding and DIC immediately after delivery.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a patient who presented with tendon xanthomas, a lipid profile showing serum cholesterol = 283 mg/dL and serum LDL = 202 mg/dL, and was subsequently started on lovastatin therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of tendon xanthomas and markedly elevated serum cholesterol and LDL levels are classic features of Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa Hyperlipoproteinemia).


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Tangier's disease (Option B):
    • Caused by mutations in ABCA1 gene → defective cholesterol efflux → very low HDL.
    • Classic signs include orange-colored tonsils and peripheral neuropathy, not raised LDL or tendon xanthomas.
  • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency (Option C):
    • Defect in lipoprotein lipase (LPL) or its cofactor ApoC-II.
    • Leads to Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Type I).
    • Presents with severe hypertriglyceridemia, eruptive xanthomas, hepatosplenomegaly, and milky plasma, not high LDL.
  • Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Option D):
    • Overlaps with LPL deficiency, leading to chylomicron accumulation.
    • Clinical features include eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis, abdominal pain, and pancreatitis.
    • Not associated with high LDL or tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1 (SGLT 1) is present in the small intestine and renal tubules. In the intestine, it plays a critical role in glucose absorption coupled with sodium transport.

  • ORS works because sodium and glucose are absorbed together via SGLT 1, and water follows osmotically.
  • This mechanism remains intact in diarrheal states, making ORS highly effective in preventing dehydration.

Glucose Transporters:


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

SGLT 2 (Option B): Found in the kidney (proximal tubule), responsible for renal glucose reabsorption, not intestinal absorption.

GLUT 4 (Option C): Present in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue; its activity is insulin-dependent. Not involved in intestinal glucose absorption or ORS action.

Na-Ca transporter (Option D): Involved in calcium efflux and homeostasis, has no role in glucose transport or ORS mechanism.

Reference:

  1. Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporters

questions.text: A 15-year-old with a known history of spinal tuberculosis presents with low-grade fever, dull aching back pain, and persistent hip flexion. Movements at the hip are painful and restricted. On CT imaging, the muscle marked as 2 is involved. Which muscle is it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure labeled 2 corresponds to the psoas muscle. In the clinical context of spinal TB with hip flexion deformity, this points toward a psoas abscess, a common complication of Pott's disease.

  • Iliopsoas muscle function:
    • Formed by psoas major and iliacus
    • Chief flexor of the hip joint
    • When inflamed, spasm pulls the femur anteriorly, leading to persistent hip flexion
  • Psoas abscess in spinal TB:
    • Caused by spread of infection from vertebral bodies into the psoas compartment
    • Presents with fever, back pain, limp, and hip flexion deformity

Spinal Tuberculosis (Pott's Disease)

  • Common sites:
    • Adults → lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae
    • Children → upper thoracic vertebrae
  • Pathology:
    • Granulomatous infection spreads to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral discs
    • Vertebral collapse → kyphotic deformity (gibbus)
    • Cold abscess formation:
      • Upper spine → may extend to chest wall
      • Lower spine → may track along psoas, presenting as psoas abscess
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Demonstrates vertebral destruction, abscesses
    • Definitive confirmation: Biopsy/aspiration with culture or histology
  • Complications:
    • Paraplegia due to cord compression or large abscess → may need urgent drainage

Explanation of other options:

1. (Option A): Abdominal wall muscles (rectus abdominis, external/internal oblique, transversus abdominis), provide trunk stability and movement, not associated with hip flexion deformity in spinal TB.

3. (Option C): Adductor muscles (longus, brevis, magnus), located in medial thigh, function is hip adduction, not implicated in this presentation.

4 (Option D): Gluteal muscles (maximus, medius, minimus), function in hip extension, abduction, and rotation; not related to psoas abscess formation.

Key Takeaway

In spinal tuberculosis, a cold abscess may track into the psoas muscle, producing hip flexion deformity due to iliopsoas spasm.

Reference:Tuberculosis of the spine - PMC.

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-COVID male patient came with complaints of one-sided facial swelling, headache, and nasal sinus congestion. He is diabetic and it is uncontrolled. On examination black lesions on the nasal bridge and upper inside of the mouth were observed. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation-unilateral facial swelling, sinus congestion, black eschar in the nasal and oral cavity, and uncontrolled diabetes post-COVID-is highly suggestive of mucormycosis.
  • The gold standard for confirming mucormycosis is biopsy with histopathologic examination, which demonstrates broad, aseptate fungal hyphae with tissue invasion.
  • Potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount and fungal culture may also support the diagnosis, but tissue biopsy is definitive.

Mucormycosis:

  • Aggressive fungal infection affecting the nose and paranasal sinuses, which rapidly spreads to orbit, brain, and meninges.
  • The fungus invades arteries, leading to thrombosis, necrosis, and tissue destruction.
  • Clinical features: Black necrotic debris in nasal cavity, involvement of septum, turbinates, or palate; "black turbinate sign" on contrast-enhanced MRI.
  • Risk factors:
    • Uncontrolled diabetes (especially ketoacidosis)
    • Prolonged corticosteroid therapy (common in post-COVID patients)
    • Immunosuppression (chemotherapy, neutropenia, HIV, organ transplantation, chronic kidney disease)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Endoscopy: Initially pale mucosa, later black crusting and necrosis.
    • Biopsy: Gold standard; shows angioinvasive broad aseptate hyphae.
    • Imaging:
      • CT: Detects sinus involvement and bony destruction.
      • CECT: Better defines sinus opacification, mucosal thickening, and extent of bone erosion.
      • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue spread, orbital and intracranial extension.
  • Treatment:
    • Antifungals: Amphotericin B (0.6-1 mg/kg/day IV) or Liposomal Amphotericin B (5 mg/kg/day); Posaconazole as step-down oral therapy.
    • Surgery: Endoscopic debridement; in severe cases, maxillectomy or orbital exenteration.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

X-ray (Option A): Conventional X-rays are inadequate for diagnosing mucormycosis. They fail to detect early fungal invasion or soft tissue extension. CT and MRI are superior imaging tools.

Serum ferritin (Option C): Elevated ferritin and iron overload predispose patients to mucormycosis, but ferritin testing is not diagnostic. It cannot confirm or exclude the infection.

HbA1c (Option D): Reflects long-term blood sugar control. Poor control is a risk factor for mucormycosis, but HbA1c has no role in confirming fungal infection.

Key Takeaway:

In a post-COVID diabetic patient with black necrotic nasal or palatal lesions, biopsy with histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosing mucormycosis. Imaging supports staging, but tissue confirmation is mandatory to establish the diagnosis and guide urgent antifungal and surgical management.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab culture grew a strict aerobe, and the oxidase test shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely etiology in this scenario because:

  • It is a strict aerobe (cannot survive in anaerobic conditions).
  • It is oxidase-positive (a key differentiating test from Enterobacteriaceae, which are oxidase-negative).
  • It is a well-documented pathogen in burn wound infections, where it causes severe, necrotizing, and often life-threatening infections.
  • It produces characteristic pigments:
    • Pyocyanin (blue-green)
    • Pyoverdin (yellow-green, fluorescent)
  • Colonies often give a fruity/grape-like odor.
  • It forms biofilms on necrotic tissue, making infections persistent and resistant to antibiotics.

Burn Wounds & Pseudomonas:

  • In burn patients, the damaged skin barrier and moist environment favor colonization.
  • It can invade bloodstream → septicemia, which is associated with very high mortality.
  • Pseudomonas septicemia in burns may show ecthyma gangrenosum (necrotic skin lesions).

Explanation of Other Options:

Klebsiella (Option A): Klebsiella is an oxidase-negative Gram-negative bacillus that more commonly causes pneumonia and urinary tract infections rather than burn wound infections.

Escherichia coli (Option B): E. coli is oxidase-negative and typically associated with urinary tract infections, gastroenteritis, and intra-abdominal infections, not burn site infections.

Salmonella (Option D): Salmonella is oxidase-negative and primarily causes gastroenteritis, enteric fever, and septicemia, not wound infections following burns.

questions.text: Calculate the sodium deficit in a 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg with a sodium level of 120 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sodium Deficit Calculation:

  • Formula: Sodium Deficit (mEq) = (Desired Sodium - Current Sodium) x Total Body Water (TBW)

  • Total Body Water (TBW):
    • 60% of body weight (for males)
    • 50% of body weight (for females)
  • Therefore,
    • For a 70 kg male: TBW = 0.6 x 70 = 42 L
    • Desired sodium: 140 mEq/L (average range: 135-145 mEq/L)
    • Current sodium: 120 mEq/L
    • Sodium Deficit = (140 - 120) x 42 = 840 mEq

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer presents with swelling on foot and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Granules from the discharge were examined under the microscope, shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation described-chronic swelling of the foot, multiple discharging sinuses, and granules in pus-is typical of mycetoma.
  • Farmers and agricultural workers are commonly affected due to repeated trauma with soil contamination.
  • Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria (Actinomycetoma) and fungi (Eumycetoma), making option A correct.
  • The granules seen under microscopy are diagnostic clues, with color varying by causative organism.

Mycetoma:

  • Actinomycetoma (bacterial):
    • Causative agents: Actinomyces, Nocardia.
    • Granule colors: white, yellow, or red.
    • Treatment: Long-term antibiotics.
  • Eumycetoma (fungal):
    • Causative agents: Madurella, Exophiala.
    • Granule colors: black or brown.
    • Treatment: Antifungal agents and sometimes surgical excision.
  • Pathology: Progressive granulomatous infection with discharging sinuses, leading to deep tissue and even bone involvement.
  • Spread: Direct extension and hematogenous spread, but not lymphatic.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Undergoes lymphatic spread (Option B): Incorrect because mycetoma does not spread via lymphatics. It spreads by direct extension and hematogenous routes.

There is lymphocyte accumulation (Option C): Incorrect because mycetoma is a granulomatous disease characterized by neutrophils, macrophages, and giant cells rather than predominantly lymphocyte infiltration.

Involves only superficial tissues (Option D): Incorrect because mycetoma progressively extends into subcutaneous tissue, fascia, muscle, and bone, causing chronic deformity and disability if untreated.

Key Takeaway:

Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by swelling, discharging sinuses, and granules. It can be caused by both bacteria (actinomycetoma) and fungi (eumycetoma), which spreads by direct extension, and involves deep tissues including bone.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/kg, and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg. Which electrolyte abnormality is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has low serum osmolality (270 mOsm/kg, below normal 285-295 mOsm/kg), indicating serum dilution.
  • High urine osmolality (1000 mOsm/kg) demonstrates that the kidneys are inappropriately concentrating urine.
  • This pattern is typical of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia, most commonly due to SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion).
  • Severe hyponatremia can cause neurological manifestations such as seizures.

Causes of Euvolemic Hyponatremia:

  • Drugs: desmopressin, oxytocin, antidepressants, opioids, thiazide diuretics, carbamazepine, vincristine, nicotine, antipsychotics, cyclophosphamide, NSAIDs, MDMA.
  • SIADH: increased ADH → water retention → dilution of sodium.
    • ANP release → natriuresis → no edema.
  • Conditions associated with SIADH:
    • Tumors
    • CNS disorders: stroke, trauma, infections, psychosis, porphyria.
    • Pulmonary disorders: pneumonia, TB, COPD.
    • Drugs: anticonvulsants, cytotoxic agents, psychotropics.
    • Idiopathic.
  • Other causes: Addison's disease, hypothyroidism, primary polydipsia, potomania, excessive iatrogenic fluid administration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypernatremia (Option A): Characterized by high serum osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) due to water deficit relative to sodium, not seen in this patient.

Hyperkalemia (Option C): Represents increased potassium levels in blood, usually associated with metabolic acidosis or impaired renal excretion, unrelated to this case.

Hypokalemia (Option D): Defined by low serum potassium, typically caused by diuretics, GI fluid losses, or hyperaldosteronism; does not explain this patient's presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Low serum osmolality with high urine osmolality = dilutional hyponatremia.
  • SIADH is the most common cause in such cases.
  • Severe hyponatremia can present with neurological symptoms like seizures.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470386/#:~:text=Hypotonic%20hyponatremia%20represents%20an%20excess,capacity%20to%20excrete%20free%20water

questions.text: A patient receiving Digoxin, Potassium chloride, Clarithromycin, Atenolol, and Triamterene developed atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. Tests revealed increased Digoxin levels. Which of these drugs is responsible for the elevated serum Digoxin?
questions.solution:
The presence of atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate and raised digoxin levels indicates digoxin toxicity, most likely triggered by the concurrent use of clarithromycin, which inhibits P-glycoprotein and elevates digoxin concentration.

  • P-glycoprotein (P-gp), also called ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1) or multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1), is an efflux transporter protein that plays a key role in digoxin clearance.
  • Its main function is to move drugs from inside the cell to the outside.

Tissue distribution and effects:

  • GIT: Lowers drug absorption.
  • Kidneys: Promotes drug elimination through urine.
  • Liver: Enhances drug excretion into bile.
  • Blood-brain barrier / Placenta: Restricts drug penetration into the brain and placental cells.

Explanations of other options:

Potassium Chloride (Option A): Potassium chloride is given to treat potassium deficiency and does not have a direct effect on digoxin metabolism.

Atenolol (Option C): Atenolol, a beta-blocker used in managing hypertension and other heart conditions, may interact with digoxin but generally decreases its action rather than enhancing it.

Rifampicin (Option D): Rifampicin, an antitubercular medication, acts as a P-glycoprotein inducer, thereby enhancing P-gp activity and promoting greater excretion of digoxin.

Key takeaway:

  • P-gp inhibitors (e.g., verapamil, ketoconazole) raise the bioavailability of P-gp substrates like digoxin by reducing their cellular efflux.
  • In contrast, P-gp inducers (e.g., rifampicin, St. John's wort) lower the bioavailability of these substrates by enhancing their efflux.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and progressive distension. An abdominal X-ray reveals multiple dilated bowel loops. Based on the radiographic findings, identify the bowel segment involved
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray demonstrates dilated small bowel loops with mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes) crossing the entire lumen, which are most characteristic of the jejunum.

  • Valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares):
    • Prominent mucosal folds running across the full width of the lumen.
    • Best appreciated in the jejunum and proximal ileum.
    • Radiographically create a "feathery" appearance on plain X-ray.

Thus, the presence of these folds confirms that the dilated loops belong to the jejunum.


Radiographic Features of Small Bowel Obstruction

  • Initial Test: Plain abdominal X-ray
    • Erect view: Shows air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern.
    • Supine view: Helps localize the obstruction site.
  • Gold Standard (IOC): Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT)
    • Useful for identifying high-grade obstruction, strangulation, or extraluminal causes.

Key Radiographic Differentiation

  • Jejunum:
    • Central loops, markedly dilated
    • Prominent valvulae conniventes spanning the full width
    • "Feathery" mucosal pattern
  • Ileum (Option B):
    • Central loops, dilated
    • Featureless/characterless appearance due to less distinct mucosal folds
  • Duodenum (Option C):
    • Retroperitoneal, not typically well-visualized unless massively distended
  • Transverse Colon (Option D):
    • Haustrations that appear as incomplete lines, not extending across the lumen

Key Takeaway:

On abdominal X-ray, dilated central loops with mucosal folds crossing the entire lumen (valvulae conniventes) point toward jejunal obstruction, while ileal loops look "characterless" and colonic haustrations do not span the full width.

questions.text: Tocilizumab works by blocking which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tocilizumab acts by blocking interleukin-6 (IL-6).

Explanations of other options:

IL-2 receptor (Option A): Daclizumab and Basiliximab block the IL-2 receptor and are used as immunosuppressants following kidney and heart transplants.

IL-5 (Option B): Mepolizumab, Reslizumab, and Benralizumab target and inhibit IL-5, and are utilized to help decrease asthma flare-ups.

IL-4 (Option C): Dupilumab blocks IL-4 and is used to help lower the frequency of asthma exacerbations.

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Following VVF repair, adequate healing time is crucial to avoid recurrence or breakdown of the repair:

  • Sexual abstinence for 3 months: Prevents disruption of the surgical site and allows complete tissue healing.
  • Avoid pregnancy for 1 year: Pregnancy increases intra-abdominal and pelvic pressure, potentially compromising the integrity of the repair. Waiting one year minimizes recurrence risk and ensures optimal healing before the uterus undergoes pregnancy-related changes.

Key Takeaway:

  • After vesicovaginal fistula repair: advise sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoidance of pregnancy for at least 1 year.

Reference:

  1. NCBI - PMC5704560

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper-quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of fever, severe calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, and icterus is classic for leptospirosis (Weil's disease, icteric form).


Explanation of Other Options:

Chikungunya (Option B): Chikungunya virus (Togavirus, Alphavirus) typically presents with high fever, severe polyarthralgia/arthritis, rash, and joint swelling. Unlike leptospirosis, there is no conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness, and jaundice is not a typical feature.

Dengue hemorrhagic fever (Option C): Caused by Dengue virus (Flavivirus), it presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, rash, bleeding tendency, thrombocytopenia, and plasma leakage leading to shock.

Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A (Option D): Hepatitis A virus (Picornavirus, RNA virus) causes acute viral hepatitis with fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice. In rare cases, hepatic encephalopathy may occur. However, conjunctival suffusion and calf muscle pain are absent.

choices.text: Prolapse of membranes into the vagina

questions.text: A 40-year-old G2P1 woman at 18 weeks of gestation presents with a dilated cervix. Cervical length is 15 mm. Despite understanding the risks, she insists on cerclage. Which of the following is a contraindication for cervical cerclage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cervical cerclage is contraindicated in ruptured membranes.

Cervical Cerclage:

  • A surgical procedure to reinforce a weak or incompetent cervix, aimed at preventing preterm birth or mid-trimester loss.

Timing of Cerclage:

  • Prophylactic: ~14 weeks gestation
  • Emergency: When cervical dilation or membrane prolapse occurs
  • Removal: Typically at 37 weeks, or earlier if labor begins

Types of Cerclage:

  • McDonald (simpler, most common)
  • Shirodkar (requires dissection of cervical tissue for suture placement)

Indications:

  • Short cervix (<25 mm) on ultrasound
  • Cervical dilatation with or without bulging membranes
  • History of prior mid-trimester losses

Contraindications:

  • Ruptured membranes (risk of infection and preterm labor)
  • Active uterine infection
  • Significant vaginal bleeding
  • Severe uterine irritability
  • Cervical dilation >4 cm
  • Intrauterine fetal demise

Explanation of other options:

Prolapse of membranes into the vagina (B): This is often an indication for emergency cerclage to prevent further damage.

Fetal fibronectin positive (C): Indicates risk of preterm labor but is not a contraindication. Cerclage may still be considered if cervical insufficiency is present.

Advanced maternal age (D): Increases pregnancy risk but does not contraindicate cerclage.

or other pregnancy complications, it is not a contraindication for cervical cerclage.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cervical cerclage is contraindicated in the presence of ruptured membranes.

Reference:

  1. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/229469261_The_effect_of_advanced_maternal_age_on_pregnancy_outcome.
  2. https://fogsi.org/wp-content/uploads/fogsi-focus/fogsi-focus-maternal-fetal-and-neonatal-medicine-2020.pdf.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the opposing lawyer asked the witness, "Did A kill B in your presenc The witness said, "Yes". Which procedural route would this type of question be permitted in the court of law?
questions.solution:
Cross-examination is the correct procedural route in the court of law for this type of question.

  • Cross-examination is conducted by the opposing party's counsel after examination-in-chief.
  • Its purpose is to test the veracity, consistency, and credibility of the witness.
  • Leading questions (questions suggesting the answer, e.g., "Did A kill B?") are permitted in cross-examination under Section 146, Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA).
  • This ensures that the witness's testimony can be challenged and clarified effectively.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Examination-in-chief (Option A):

  • Conducted by the party who calls the witness (e.g., prosecutor calling a prosecution witness).
  • Its aim is to present facts supporting their case.
  • Leading questions are not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile.
  • Hence, a direct "Did A kill B?" type question would be inadmissible here.

Direct examination (Option B):

  • Another term used for examination-in-chief, especially in Anglo-American law.
  • Same rules apply-open-ended, non-leading questions must be asked.
  • Therefore, not the correct procedural stage for such a question.

Re-direct examination (Option D):

  • Conducted by the party who originally called the witness, after cross-examination.
  • Its purpose is to clarify ambiguities or repair credibility damaged during cross.
  • Leading questions are not permitted here either.
  • So, the given scenario cannot occur in re-direct.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The crown-rump length (CRL) by ultrasound is the most accurate method for dating pregnancy in the first trimester, especially when the LMP is uncertain (as in women on oral contraceptives).

  • CRL accuracy: ±5-7 days before 14 weeks.
  • After 14 weeks, other parameters (BPD, HC, AC, FL) are used.
  • If there is a discrepancy between LMP and USG, USG dating takes precedence in early pregnancy.

Gestational Age Determination:

  • Traditionally calculated from LMP (adding 280 days).
  • But in cases with irregular cycles, hormonal contraceptive use, or uncertain LMP, ultrasound is the gold standard.

Explanation of other options:

Adding 280 days to the LMP (Option B): Assumes a regular 28-day cycle and ovulation on day 14. In women on oral contraceptives, the cycle pattern is disrupted, making this method unreliable.

Fundus examination (Option C): Clinical palpation of uterine height is less accurate in early pregnancy and influenced by maternal build, bladder fullness, and fetal lie.

Adding 256 days to the LMP (Option D): This method is not standard or recommended in obstetric practice for determining gestational age.

Key Takeaway:

In early pregnancy with uncertain LMP (e.g., OCP use), the crown-rump length on ultrasound is the most reliable method for gestational age assessment.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for varicose veins. Following the procedure, he developed sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve, provides cutaneous sensation to the medial side of the leg and foot.

  • It is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.
  • The nerve courses along the great saphenous vein in the medial leg.
  • During varicose vein surgery, particularly when the great saphenous vein is handled, the saphenous nerve is vulnerable to injury due to its close anatomical relationship.



Explanation of incorrect options:

Sural nerve (Option A): Provides cutaneous sensation over the lateral foot and dorsum near the little toe, not the medial leg and foot.

Superficial peroneal nerve (Option B): Supplies the anterolateral leg and most of the dorsum of the foot, sparing the medial leg and first web space.

Deep peroneal nerve (Option C): Responsible for sensory innervation of only the first dorsal web space between the hallux and the second toe, not the medial leg.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used in the treatment of opioid overdose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Naloxone, a pure opioid receptor antagonist, is the preferred medication for reversing opioid toxicity.

Explanations of other options:

N-acetyl cysteine (Option C): N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose and is not used in cases of opioid poisoning.

Alvimopan (Option D): Alvimopan is a peripheral μ-opioid receptor blocker used to treat opioid-induced constipation in surgical patients, but it does not counteract opioid overdose.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown in the figure below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image corresponds to a PET-CT scan, a hybrid imaging technique that merges positron emission tomography (PET) with computed tomography (CT).

  • PET component: Detects metabolic activity using a positron-emitting tracer such as F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). Areas with increased glucose uptake (e.g., tumors, active inflammation) appear as "hot spots."
  • CT component: Provides high-resolution anatomical detail.
  • Combined advantage: Functional (metabolic) information from PET is fused with anatomical localization from CT, greatly improving diagnostic accuracy.

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral blood flow scan (Option A): A type of SPECT imaging used for brain perfusion studies, not PET-CT.

Sestamibi scan (Option C): Uses Tc-99m sestamibi with a gamma camera, commonly performed for cardiac perfusion, parathyroid adenomas, and breast lesions.

Full body MDCT (Option D): Purely anatomical imaging using multi-detector CT, excellent for structural abnormalities but lacks metabolic information.

Key Takeaway:

PET-CT uniquely combines functional imaging (metabolism) with structural detail (anatomy), making it the gold standard in oncology for tumor detection, staging, and monitoring response to therapy.

Reference: https://www.nibib.nih.gov/science-education/science-topics/nuclear-medicine#

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presented to the OPD with laboratory findings showing LDH 700 IU/L, platelets 75,000/mm³, serum bilirubin 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT 200 U/L, SGPT 150 U/L, and blood pressure 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has:
    • High LDH → Hemolysis
    • Thrombocytopenia (platelets 75,000/mm³)
    • Elevated AST/ALT → Liver injury
    • Hypertension (140/96 mmHg)
  • Together, these are characteristic of HELLP syndrome, a severe complication of preeclampsia.

HELLP Syndrome

  • Definition: Rare complication of preeclampsia, usually in the 3rd trimester
  • Features:
    • H: Hemolysis
    • EL: Elevated liver enzymes
    • LP: Low platelets
  • Risk factors: Age >35, multiparity, diabetes, kidney disease, prior HELLP
  • Symptoms: RUQ/epigastric pain, headache, blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, edema
  • Maternal complications: DIC, liver failure, renal failure, pulmonary edema, eclampsia
  • Fetal complications: Growth restriction, preterm birth, respiratory distress
  • Treatment:
    • MgSO4 → Prevent seizures
    • Antihypertensives → BP control
    • <34 weeks: Corticosteroids for lung maturity
    • Definitive treatment: Termination of pregnancy

Explanation of other options:

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (Option B): Typically shows very high AST/ALT and normal LDH; hypertension is not common. Platelet count usually not as low as in HELLP.

Viral hepatitis (Option C): Transaminases are extremely high (2000+ U/L); platelet count usually preserved. No hypertension in typical viral hepatitis.

Intrahepatic cholestasis (Option D): Presents with pruritus and markedly elevated bile acids/bilirubin; LDH is normal, and no hypertension or hemolysis.

Key Takeaway:

  • HELLP syndrome = Hemolysis + Elevated Liver enzymes + Low Platelets, usually in the setting of preeclampsia.

Reference:

  1. https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/21637-hellp-syndrome

questions.text: Which of the options aids in the transportation of fatty acids through the inner mitochondria membrane?
questions.solution:
The carnitine shuttle system is the key mechanism that allows long-chain fatty acids to enter the mitochondrial matrix for β-oxidation.

Steps involved:

  1. Carnitine Palmitoyltransferase I (CPT-I):
    Converts fatty acyl-CoA to fatty acyl-carnitine in the outer mitochondrial membrane.
  2. Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase:
    Transports fatty acyl-carnitine across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  3. Carnitine Palmitoyltransferase II (CPT-II):
    Reconverts fatty acyl-carnitine back to fatty acyl-CoA inside the mitochondrial matrix.

Thus, carnitine is indispensable for transporting long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria, where they undergo oxidation to generate energy.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Acyl carrier protein (Option A):

  • Functions in fatty acid synthesis within the cytosol.
  • It transports the growing fatty acid chain between enzyme active sites during synthesis.
  • It is not involved in fatty acid transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase (LCAT) (Option C):

  • Plasma enzyme that esterifies cholesterol using phosphatidylcholine (lecithin).
  • Plays a role in lipoprotein metabolism (HDL maturation).
  • Has no role in fatty acid mitochondrial transport.

Albumin (Option D):

  • A plasma protein that binds and carries free fatty acids in the blood.
  • Delivers fatty acids to tissues, but cannot transport them into mitochondria.

Key Takeaway:

  • Transport into mitochondria = Carnitine shuttle
  • Transport in blood = Albumin
  • Fatty acid synthesis = Acyl carrier protein
  • Cholesterol metabolism = LCAT

Reference: Carnitine

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count is >5000/µL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary mottling pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of nocturnal cough, fever, dyspnea, wheezing, very high eosinophil count (>5000/µL), and miliary opacities on X-ray is characteristic of Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE).

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE) - Key Points:

  • Etiology & Pathogenesis:
    • Caused by trapped microfilariae in pulmonary circulation.
    • Eosinophil degranulation releases toxic proteins → airway damage.
    • Overactive TH2 response with ↑ IL-4, IL-5, IgE, IgG, IgM → marked eosinophilia.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Dry, paroxysmal nocturnal cough.
    • Breathlessness and wheezing.
    • Systemic: fever, malaise, weight loss.
    • Extrapulmonary: hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy.
    • Examination: wheeze, crepitations, enlarged nodes.
  • Investigations:
    • CBC: leukocytosis with eosinophilia (>3000/mm³).
    • ↑ IgE, positive filarial antibody tests.
    • Chest X-ray: reticulonodular/miliary mottling; normal in 20-30%.
    • Chest CT: bronchiectasis, lymphadenopathy, effusion.
    • PFTs: mixed restrictive + mild obstructive defect.
  • Management:
    • First-line: Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 21 days → rapid symptom relief.
    • Adjunct: Corticosteroids in chronic/refractory cases.
    • Alternatives: Ivermectin, albendazole (limited data).

Explanation of Other Options:

Bronchial asthma (Option A): Chronic airway inflammation with wheeze, nocturnal cough, and dyspnea. However, miliary X-ray findings are not seen in asthma, differentiating it from TPE.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option B): Disseminated TB with tiny millet seed-like nodules across lungs and other organs. While X-ray can mimic TPE, marked eosinophilia is not a feature.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): Immune-mediated lung inflammation from inhaled antigens (dust, molds, animal proteins). Although eosinophilia may occur, miliary pattern on X-ray is not typical.

Key Takeaways:

  • TPE presents with fever, nocturnal cough, wheeze, eosinophilia >5000/µL, and miliary changes on X-ray.
  • It is strongly associated with filarial infection in endemic regions.
  • DEC for 21 days is the treatment of choice.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557524/

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of death in a body with a horizontal ligature mark completely encircling the neck and located below the thyroid, with no dribbling of saliva?
questions.solution:
A horizontal ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, found below the thyroid cartilage, and the absence of dribbling of saliva is diagnostic of ligature strangulation.

In ligature strangulation, the neck is compressed by a cord/rope/cloth, producing:

  • Asphyxia (airway obstruction)
  • Cerebral anoxia (cut-off oxygen supply to the brain)
  • Vagal inhibition (stimulation of vagus nerve)
  • Occasionally cervical vertebra fracture (rare, in violent cases)

Postmortem Findings

  1. External Examination:
  • Face: Congested, swollen, cyanosed; petechial hemorrhages (Tardieu's spots) over eyelids, conjunctiva, and skin.
  • Eyes: Prominent, conjunctiva congested, pupils dilated, subconjunctival hemorrhage possible.
  • Tongue: Swollen, dark, protruding, sometimes bitten.
  • Neck:
    • Well-defined horizontal ligature mark (furrow), encircling the neck.
    • Usually soft, reddish base with ecchymosis and imprint of ligature material.
    • Groove deeper in front/side of the neck, continuous around circumference.
  • Other signs:
    • Abrasions and nail marks from struggle.
    • Involuntary urination/defecation.
    • Genital congestion ± seminal emission.
  1. Internal Examination:
  • Hemorrhage in neck muscles and subcutaneous tissues.
  • Injury to glands, tonsils, soft tissues beneath ligature.
  • Thyroid cartilage fracture is common.
  • Hyoid fracture less frequent (ligature usually lies below thyroid).

Explanation of incorrect options:

Throttling (Option A):

  • Refers to manual strangulation using hands.
  • Findings include finger marks, nail abrasions, and diffuse bruising of the neck-none of which match the horizontal ligature furrow

Gagging (Option C):

  • Involves airway obstruction by a gag in the mouth.
  • Characteristically lacks external neck marks; cause of death is suffocation, not strangulation.

Hanging (Option D):

  • Ligature mark is oblique, incomplete (non-continuous), and above the thyroid cartilage.
  • Dribbling of saliva is a hallmark sign of hanging, but absent in this case.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Start oxytocin infusion and wait for spontaneous delivery of the placenta
Arrange for blood and use Crede's method for placental delivery

questions.text: While conducting a delivery, you perform the maneuver shown below. Following this, there is incomplete separation of the placenta and massive hemorrhage. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The maneuver shown is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver (controlled cord traction).
  • In this case, incomplete separation of the placenta has led to massive postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to retained placental tissue.
  • The immediate next step is manual removal of the placenta under anesthesia, followed by inspection for retained fragments.

Retained Placenta

  • Definition: Failure to deliver placenta within 30 minutes after birth.
  • Causes:
    • Simple adherent placenta → failure of separation despite normal implantation.
    • Lower uterine segment constriction → placenta trapped.
    • Morbidly adherent placenta (placenta accreta, increta, percreta).

Immediate Action in Hemorrhage

  • Manual removal of placenta is life-saving.
  • Supportive care: blood transfusion, fluid resuscitation, uterotonics after removal.

Types of Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)

  • Primary PPH: Within 24 hours of delivery (most common cause: uterine atony).
  • Secondary PPH: 24 hours to 12 weeks (most common cause: retained placental tissue).

Explanation of other options:

Start oxytocin infusion (Option A): Helpful in atonic PPH, but not effective if mechanical cause (retained placenta).

Uterine massage (Option B): Useful for atonic uterus, not in retained placenta.

Crede's method (Option C): Obsolete and associated with complications; not recommended in modern obstetrics.

Key Takeaway

  • In cases of incomplete placental separation with massive hemorrhage after Brandt-Andrews maneuver, immediate manual removal of the placenta is the correct management.

questions.text: Which of the following glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are responsible for corneal transparency?
questions.solution:
• Keratan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan present in the cornea and cartilage.
  • In the cornea, keratan sulfate interacts with collagen fibrils and extracellular matrix proteins to regulate hydration and spacing of collagen fibers.
  • This regular spacing of collagen fibrils is essential for corneal transparency and proper vision.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Chondroitin sulfate (Option B):
    • Found in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, and skin.
    • Provides structural support and elasticity in connective tissues, but is not the main factor for corneal transparency.
  • Heparin sulfate (Option C):
    • Present in liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes.
    • Functions as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inhibits thrombin and clotting factors.
    • Not related to corneal transparency.
  • Hyaluronic acid (Option D):
    • Found in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, and vitreous humor.
    • Provides lubrication in joints and structural integrity in connective tissues.
    • Does not contribute to corneal transparency.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who experiences strong food cravings and engages in excessive eating followed by self-induced vomiting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hallmark of bulimia nervosa is recurrent binge eating episodes followed by compensatory behaviors such as vomiting, excessive exercise, or laxative abuse to avoid weight gain.
  • Unlike anorexia, patients with bulimia often maintain a normal or slightly above-normal BMI, but the repeated purging behaviors result in distinct clinical signs and metabolic complications.
  • This patient's pattern of excessive eating and self-induced vomiting fits the diagnostic criteria for bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa:

  • Binge eating episodes: Occur at least once a week for ≥3 months.
  • Compensatory behaviors: Purging (vomiting, laxatives, diuretics) or non-purging (fasting, excessive exercise).
  • Physical signs:
    • Parotid gland hypertrophy (elevated serum amylase possible)
    • Enamel erosion (repeated vomiting)
    • Russell's sign (calluses on dorsum of hand)
  • Mallory-Weiss tears (esophageal mucosal tears)
  • Metabolic issues: Hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Epidemiology: More common in adolescent and young adult females.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Anorexia nervosa (Option A): Characterized by food restriction, distorted body image, and markedly low body weight. Unlike bulimia, anorexia does not typically involve recurrent bingeing followed by purging behaviors.

Atypical depression (Option C): Features include increased appetite, hypersomnia, mood reactivity, and leaden paralysis. While increased eating may occur, it does not involve bingeing with compensatory vomiting.

Binge eating disorder (Option D): Involves recurrent binge eating episodes but without compensatory behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise. Patients often become obese due to unopposed overeating.

Key Takeaway:

Bulimia nervosa is defined by binge eating followed by purging or other compensatory mechanisms, often with normal body weight. It is treated with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) as first-line, alongside nutritional rehabilitation and medications like fluoxetine.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is excluded from the STEP approach of the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The STEP approach by WHO is a standardized framework designed to assess and monitor risk factors for chronic diseases and mental health issues in populations. Its main focus is on evaluation and identification rather than intervention.

The approach systematically includes:

  1. Physical Assessment:
    • Measures physiological and anthropometric parameters such as weight, height, body mass index (BMI), waist circumference, and blood pressure.
    • Helps identify risk factors for conditions like hypertension, diabetes, and obesity.
  2. Psychological Assessment:
    • Evaluates mental health and emotional well-being, including stress, depression, and anxiety, which significantly influence chronic disease outcomes.
  3. Behavioral Assessment:
    • Focuses on lifestyle and habits that affect health, including tobacco and alcohol use, dietary practices, and physical activity levels.
    • Helps identify modifiable behaviors to prevent chronic diseases.

Therapeutic assessment is not part of the STEP approach, as this framework is designed for risk identification and surveillance, not for direct therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a woman who is 4 days postpartum and experiencing tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Symptoms beginning 3-5 days after delivery with tearfulness, mood swings, irritability, and mild insomnia are typical of postpartum blues (baby blues).
  • These are mild, transient emotional disturbances caused by hormonal fluctuations, stress of childbirth, and sleep deprivation.
  • They usually resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks and require only reassurance and support.
  • Postpartum mood disorders:
  • Postpartum blues:
    • Onset: 3-5 days postpartum, resolves within 2 weeks.
    • Symptoms: Tearfulness, mood swings, insomnia, emotional lability, fatigue.
    • Prevalence: Up to 80% of new mothers.
    • Treatment: Supportive care and reassurance.
  • Postpartum depression (Option A):
    • Onset: Within 6 weeks postpartum, may last for months.
    • Symptoms: Depressed mood, anhedonia, appetite changes, insomnia, irritability, hopelessness, suicidal ideation.
    • Prevalence: 10-15%.
    • Treatment: Psychotherapy, antidepressants (SSRIs).
  • Postpartum psychosis (Option C):
    • Onset: Within 2-3 weeks postpartum.
    • Symptoms: Severe mood lability, disorganized behavior, hallucinations, delusions, insomnia, risk of infanticide or suicide.
    • Incidence: 1-2 per 1000 deliveries.
    • Treatment: Hospitalization, antipsychotics, mood stabilizers, and sometimes temporary separation from the infant.
  • Postpartum anxiety (Option D):
    • Symptoms: Excessive worry, panic attacks, restlessness, nervousness.
    • Impacts maternal bonding, breastfeeding, and infant development.
    • Differs from postpartum blues since anxiety is the dominant feature rather than mood lability.

Key Takeaway:

Postpartum blues is the most common postpartum mood disturbance, presenting with tearfulness, mood swings, and mild insomnia in the first week after childbirth. It is self-limiting and requires reassurance, not pharmacologic treatment.

questions.text: A patient with giant cell arteritis presents with headache, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, and mononeuritis multiplex. What is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features are typical of giant cell arteritis (GCA), an inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large arteries.

  • The first-line treatment is high-dose corticosteroids, which must be started promptly to prevent ischemic complications such as irreversible blindness.

Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) - Key Points:

  • Epidemiology:
    • Seen almost exclusively in patients >50 years.
    • Female predominance.
    • Genetic links: HLA-DR4, HLA-DRB1*04.
  • Association with Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR):
    • 40-50% of GCA patients have PMR.
    • 10-20% of PMR patients later develop GCA.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Headache, scalp tenderness.
    • Jaw claudication.
    • Fever, malaise, weight loss, sweats.
    • Polymyalgia rheumatica symptoms.
    • Neurological: mononeuritis multiplex.
  • Complications:
    • Ischemic optic neuropathy → blindness.
    • Scalp or tongue infarction.
    • Large vessel involvement: subclavian stenosis, thoracic aortic aneurysm, risk of rupture/dissection.
  • Treatment Protocol:
    • Prednisone: 40-60 mg/day for ~1 month.
    • IV methylprednisolone: 1000 mg/day × 3 days for ocular involvement.
    • Aspirin (low-dose): reduces cranial ischemic complications, but not first-line.
    • Tocilizumab: anti-IL-6 therapy, FDA-approved for GCA, given SC weekly/biweekly with steroids.
    • Methotrexate: steroid-sparing option.
    • Monitoring: ESR/CRP, recurrence during tapering (seen in 60-85%), glucocorticoid toxicity (35-65%).

Explanation of Other Options:

Abatacept (Option A): A T-cell costimulation blocker that may reduce relapse when used with steroids, but it is not the first-line treatment.

Tocilizumab (Option B): An IL-6 inhibitor, FDA-approved for GCA and used with steroids or in refractory cases, but not initial therapy.

Aspirin (Option D): Sometimes added to reduce ischemic complications, but it is not the primary treatment for GCA.

Key Takeaways:

  • Steroids are the mainstay and first-line therapy in GCA.
  • Treatment should be started immediately to prevent blindness and ischemic events.
  • Tocilizumab and methotrexate are used as adjuncts or in relapsing/refractory cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of delayed adaptation to darkness, gritty eye sensation, dry eyes, and corneal softening. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Patient presenting with delayed adaptation to darkness, gritty eye sensation, dry eyes, and corneal softening points to a diagnosis of Vitamin A deficiency or Retinoic acid deficiency

Vitamin A Deficiency - Key Manifestations:

  1. Ocular Signs:
  • Leading cause of preventable childhood blindness in developing nations.
  • Early features:
    • Impaired sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light → night blindness.
  • Advanced deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia: conjunctival and corneal dryness, thickened keratinized epithelium.
    • If untreated → corneal ulceration → opaque scar → blindness.

WHO Grading of Xerophthalmia:

  • XN → Night blindness
  • X1A → Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B → Bitot spots
  • X2 → Corneal xerosis
  • X3A → Corneal ulcer <1/3 cornea
  • X3B → Corneal ulcer >1/3 cornea
  • XS → Corneal scar
  • XF → Xerophthalmic fundus
  • Bitot’s spots: Grayish-white, triangular patches firmly attached to conjunctiva.
  • Keratomalacia: Severe form with corneal softening after prolonged deficiency.
  1. Immune Dysfunction:
  • Deficiency reduces resistance to infections.
  • Infections themselves lower vitamin A (by reducing retinol-binding protein synthesis), worsening immune compromise.
  1. Skin and Epithelial Changes:
  • Follicular hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): rough, keratinized skin.
  • Keratinizing metaplasia: atrophy and abnormal keratinization in respiratory, GI, and genitourinary epithelium.
  1. Other General Manifestations:
  • Growth retardation (impaired chondroitin sulfate synthesis).
  • Reduced protein synthesis.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Riboflavin (Option B):

  • Deficiency manifests as oral and ocular lesions, such as cheilitis (cracked lips), glossitis (inflamed tongue), and photophobia, not corneal softening or xerophthalmia.

Niacin (Option C):

  • Lack of niacin causes pellagra, characterized by the 3 D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Ocular symptoms are not typical.

Pantothenic acid (Option D):

  • Deficiency of vitamin B5 is rare.
  • It plays a role in CoA-dependent energy metabolism, but is not associated with ocular changes like night blindness or keratomalacia.

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: Although various animals can transmit rabies, dogs are the most common source, and children are particularly affected in developing countries. Considering this, what is the most cost-effective and logical strategy to reduce the incidence of rabies?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The most effective and logical strategy for reducing rabies incidence focuses on controlling the primary source of transmission (dogs), through mass vaccination and population control.

  • Mass dog vaccination: Vaccinating dogs is highly effective in breaking the transmission cycle to humans. It provides long-term protection and is a sustainable intervention in endemic regions.
  • Stray dog population control: Reducing the number of unowned or stray dogs decreases the risk of rabies exposure, especially for children, who are most vulnerable to dog bites.

This combined approach directly addresses the root cause of human rabies, making it both cost-effective and practical in resource-limited settings.

Explanation of Other Options:

Testing all the dogs for rabies (option A): While theoretically useful, testing every dog is impractical and prohibitively expensive, especially in countries with large stray populations. It does not prevent transmission; vaccination and control measures are far more effective.

Increase the laboratory facilities (option C): Enhancing diagnostic capacity helps confirm rabies cases and supports surveillance but does not prevent the disease, so it has limited impact on reducing incidence.

Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance (option D): Training healthcare workers improves monitoring and reporting, but surveillance alone cannot prevent rabies cases. It complements prevention strategies but is not a standalone solution.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed and show no nuclei at the tail tip.

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Around day 13 of the menstrual cycle (mid-cycle), the patient is at or near ovulation.
  • At this time, physiological vaginal discharge increases, becoming copious, clear, and stretchy (like raw egg white) due to an estrogen surge.
  • Features of physiological leucorrhea:
    • Clear/white, odourless, non-irritating
    • No itching, burning, or pain
    • Vaginal pH: 8-4.2 (normal acidic environment)
    • Not associated with infection
  • This presentation matches physiological discharge and not an infectious cause.

Explanation of other options:

Candidiasis (Option A): This fungal infection caused by Candida albicans typically presents with intense itching, thick curdy white discharge resembling cottage cheese, vulvar erythema, and burning sensation, which are not seen here.

Bacterial vaginosis (Option B): Caused by overgrowth of anaerobes such as Gardnerella vaginalis, it presents with thin, homogenous, grey-white discharge with a fishy odour. Diagnosis is based on Amsel's criteria (pH >4.5, clue cells, positive whiff test, thin discharge). These findings are absent in this case.

Trichomoniasis (Option C): Caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, it is associated with frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge along with itching, burning, and sometimes a strawberry cervix on examination. None of these features is present in this patient.

Key Takeaway

  • Physiological leucorrhea increases around ovulation due to an estrogen surge and is characterised by copious, clear, odourless, non-itchy discharge.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with forearm claudication, abdominal pain, and transient episodes of vision loss. On examination, femoral pulses are weak, and fundus evaluation shows retinal hemorrhages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of limb claudication, absent/weak pulses, unequal blood pressures, and ocular ischemic symptoms strongly suggests Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease."

  • Epidemiology:
    • Commonly affects young females (<20 years old).
    • One of the leading causes of renal artery stenosis in India.
    • Frequently involves the left subclavian artery.
  • Phases of Clinical Features:
    • Early (systemic phase): Fever, malaise, night sweats, arthralgia, anorexia, weight loss.
    • Vascular (occlusive phase):
      • Arm claudication and unequal pulses.
      • Reduced/absent radial pulse → "Pulseless disease."
      • Hypertension (32-93%) due to renal artery involvement.
      • Neurological and ocular ischemic features (e.g., transient vision loss, retinal hemorrhage).
  • Investigations:
    • Raised ESR/CRP, mild anemia, increased immunoglobulins.
    • MR angiography (investigation of choice) to evaluate aorta and branches.
  • Management:
    • First-line: Corticosteroids (Prednisone 40-60 mg/day).
    • Second-line: Methotrexate (≤25 mg/week) for refractory disease.
  • Complications: Stroke, myocardial infarction, heart failure, renal failure, and aneurysm rupture.

Explanation of Other Options:
