Polyarteritis nodosa (Option A): Typically presents with systemic complaints like fever, malaise, abdominal pain, headache, and myalgia. It lacks the hallmark features of pulseless disease such as unequal blood pressures and ocular ischemia.

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Option B): Also called Buerger's disease, it affects small- and medium-sized vessels of extremities, especially in smokers. Claudication usually involves the calf or foot arch and is associated with ischemic ulcers and Raynaud's phenomenon, not large-vessel involvement.

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D): A small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis with systemic manifestations including rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, pulmonary hemorrhage, palpable purpura, and neuropathy. Large-vessel features such as weak femoral pulses are not seen.

Key Takeaways:

  • Takayasu arteritis should be suspected in young females with large-vessel occlusion, weak/absent pulses, and systemic symptoms.
  • MR angiography is the investigation of choice, and steroids remain the mainstay of treatment.

References: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430858/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531484/

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The slit-lamp image shows greyish-white, flaky material deposited on the anterior lens capsule in a characteristic concentric, bull's-eye pattern, which is diagnostic of pseudoexfoliation syndrome.
  • This is an age-related systemic condition characterized by the production and accumulation of fibrillar extracellular material within ocular tissues.
  • These deposits are commonly seen at the pupillary margin, zonules, anterior lens surface, and ciliary body.
  • The syndrome is strongly associated with secondary open-angle glaucoma, as the exfoliative material blocks aqueous outflow at the trabecular meshwork.
  • Over time, patients are at risk of optic nerve damage, visual field loss, and blindness if untreated.

Other important clinical points:

  • Lens findings: Classically, three zones are visible on the anterior lens capsule:
    • Central disc-shaped zone
    • Clear intermediate zone (due to pupillary movement)
    • Peripheral granular zone → forming the classic "target" or "bull's-eye" appearance
  • Zonular weakness: Common in this condition, predisposing to phacodonesis (lens wobbling) and intraoperative complications such as lens subluxation during cataract surgery.
  • Prevalence: More common in the elderly and in specific geographic areas (Scandinavia, Mediterranean basin).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Intraocular foreign body (Option A): Typically follows penetrating ocular trauma. Diagnosis relies on imaging (X-ray, CT, ultrasound). The picture here shows concentric deposits on the lens surface, not a retained fragment.

Ocular trauma (Option C): Trauma can cause signs such as corneal scarring, hyphema, lens dislocation, or pigmentary imprints like a Vossius ring. The layered fibrillar deposits here are not features of blunt trauma.

Vossius ring (Option D): Appears as a pigmented circular imprint of the pupillary margin on the anterior lens capsule following blunt trauma. It is a single dark ring, unlike the flaky, grey-white concentric deposits of pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome presents with flaky fibrillar deposits on the anterior lens capsule in a bull's-eye pattern and is a significant risk factor for secondary open-angle glaucoma. Recognizing this condition is essential due to its ocular surgical implications (zonular fragility) and its strong association with glaucoma-related optic nerve damage.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with seizures and has a past history of fever with rash at the age of 1 year, which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following investigations would be most useful in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's clinical history is suggestive of a prior measles infection. Years later, this can lead to Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), a chronic progressive CNS disorder caused by persistent measles virus infection.

  • The most reliable diagnostic marker is measles-specific IgG antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which remain elevated for years after primary infection.
  • IgG detection in CSF helps differentiate SSPE from acute measles and other neurological conditions.

Complications of Measles

  • More frequent in young, malnourished, or immunocompromised
  • Otitis media - most common complication.
  • Pneumonia - leading cause of mortality.
  • Other respiratory infections: bronchitis, laryngitis.
  • Acute encephalitis.
  • SSPE - most severe long-term complication; rare but invariably fatal.

Prevention

  • Measles is preventable and potentially eradicable.
  • Maternal antibodies protect infants until 6-9 months; vaccination at 9 months ensures early protection.
  • Vaccine: live attenuated measles strain (Edmonston-Zagreb), available as MR/MMR/MMR-V.
  • Schedule:
    • 1st dose: 9 months
    • 2nd dose: 16-24 months

Explanation of Other Options:

MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (Option B): Indicates temporal lobe epilepsy, unrelated to SSPE.

IgM measles in CSF (Option C): Suggests recent or acute measles infection, not SSPE which appears years after infection.

C1Q4 antibodies in CSF (Option D): Not linked to measles; usually associated with autoimmune conditions like SLE.

Key Takeaways:

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE):

  • Definition: Rare, progressive, fatal CNS disorder occurring 7-13 years post-measles infection. Also called slow virus disease or Dawson's disease.
  • Clinical features: Behavioral changes, cognitive decline, motor dysfunction, seizures, progressive neurological deterioration.
  • EEG: Periodic complexes with burst suppression pattern.
  • MRI: Cerebral atrophy, white matter lesions, abnormal signal intensities.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical history, EEG findings, and measles-specific IgG antibodies in CSF.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for a patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after undergoing a total thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Failure to extubate with breathing difficulty immediately after thyroid surgery strongly points to bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury.
  • The RLN innervates all intrinsic laryngeal muscles except the cricothyroid. Injury to both nerves leads to bilateral vocal cord paralysis in the paramedian position.
  • With both cords fixed, the glottic airway is markedly narrowed, resulting in stridor, respiratory distress, and inability to extubate safely.
  • This complication is rare but one of the most feared after thyroid surgery. Emergency airway management, often including tracheostomy, is required.

After total thyroidectomy, nerve injuries are among the most important causes of morbidity:

  • Unilateral RLN injury: hoarseness, ineffective cough, aspiration.
  • Bilateral RLN injury: airway obstruction and stridor, often requiring urgent tracheostomy.
  • Superior laryngeal nerve injury: impaired pitch modulation and voice fatigue.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Superior laryngeal nerve injury (Option A): Affects the cricothyroid muscle, leading to loss of high-pitch phonation and weak voice. It does not cause airway compromise or failed extubation.

Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option B): Produces hoarseness and weak voice but generally does not impair breathing, as the opposite vocal cord compensates. Extubation is usually possible.

Hematoma (Option D): A postoperative hematoma can compress the airway externally, but this typically presents neck swelling, bruising, and rapid respiratory distress in the hours following surgery. Unlike bilateral RLN palsy, symptoms resolve once the hematoma is evacuated.

Key Takeaway:

Breathing difficulty with inability to extubate after total thyroidectomy is most consistent with bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, which causes bilateral vocal cord paralysis and airway obstruction. It is a surgical emergency requiring immediate airway management.

questions.text: A young girl presented to the OPD for examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and has dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathionine β-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.solution:
• The clinical triad of tall stature, marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and cystathionine β-synthase deficiency is diagnostic of Type I Homocystinuria.
  • In this condition, the pathway converting homocysteine → cystathionine → cysteine is blocked.
  • As a result, cysteine becomes an essential amino acid in these patients, and supplementation is required.
  • Treatment also includes pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) supplementation, low-methionine diet, and folate/B12 support when needed.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Methionine (Option B):
    • Already elevated in Type I homocystinuria due to block at cystathionine β-synthase.
    • Supplementation would worsen the metabolic imbalance.
  • Serine (Option C):
    • Although serine condenses with homocysteine in the cystathionine pathway, the defect here is enzyme deficiency, not serine shortage.
    • Supplementation will not correct the defect.
  • Tyrosine (Option D):
    • Tyrosine is unrelated to the homocysteine-cysteine pathway.
    • Supplementation is used in PKU (phenylketonuria), not homocystinuria

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination, was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/position?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Occipitoposterior (OP):

  • Definition: Vertex presentation where the occiput points posteriorly towards the sacrum or sacroiliac joints.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening (because the fetal back is posterior).
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds best heard at the flanks (laterally).
    • Pelvic exam: Cephalic prominence (sinciput) more palpable than occiput; head often unengaged.
  • Variants:
    • Left OP (towards left sacroiliac joint)
    • Right OP (towards right sacroiliac joint, most common)
    • Direct OP (towards sacrum)

Explanation of other options:

Brow (Option A): Partial extension of the fetal head presenting the brow; associated with a large presenting diameter. Not characterised by infra-umbilical flattening or lateral FHS.

Knee (Option B): Rare type of knee presentation where one or both knees present at the pelvic brim. Not associated with the described findings.

Right dorso-anterior (Option D): A transverse lie where the fetal dorsum is anterior, causing a broad maternal abdomen and fetal head/breech palpable in opposite iliac fossae. Does not match infra-umbilical flattening and lateral FHS.

Key Takeaway:

Infra-umbilical flattening with fetal heart sounds best heard laterally is strongly suggestive of an occipitoposterior position.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation of disorientation, agitation, visual hallucinations, paranoid delusions, and altered sensorium within 72 hours of alcohol cessation is classic for delirium tremens (DTs).
  • DTs represent the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal, typically occurring 48-72 hours after the last drink.
  • It is life-threatening and associated with severe autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever, profuse sweating), in addition to hallucinations and confusion.

Alcohol withdrawal stages:

  • Mild withdrawal (6-8 hrs): Anxiety, tremors, nausea, headache, palpitations.
  • Alcoholic hallucinosis (8-12 hrs): Visual/auditory/tactile hallucinations but orientation intact; stable vitals.
  • Withdrawal seizures (12-24 hrs): Generalized tonic-clonic, brief and self-limiting ("rum fits").
  • Delirium tremens (within 72 hrs): Agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucinations (often visual), paranoid delusions, severe autonomic instability.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Wernicke's encephalopathy (Option B): Caused by thiamine deficiency in chronic alcoholics. Presents with the triad of ophthalmoplegia/nystagmus, ataxia, and confusion. It is not primarily linked to acute alcohol withdrawal.

Korsakoff psychosis (Option C): A chronic consequence of untreated Wernicke's encephalopathy. Characterized by anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and impaired recent memory rather than acute agitation and hallucinations.

Alcohol-induced psychosis (Option D): Also known as alcoholic hallucinosis, it presents with hallucinations, but orientation is preserved, unlike in delirium tremens where there is global confusion and altered sensorium.

Key Takeaway:

Delirium tremens is the most severe and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, occurring within 72 hours of cessation. It is characterized by confusion, hallucinations, agitation, and autonomic hyperactivity. Immediate management with benzodiazepines, fluids, electrolyte correction, and thiamine supplementation is essential to reduce mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell-to-cell signaling is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paracrine signaling involves the release of signaling molecules into the extracellular fluid, where they act on neighboring target cells. This mechanism enables localized tissue responses, ensuring proper coordination between adjacent cells without requiring systemic hormone circulation.

Cell-to-Cell Signaling:

Cell-to-cell signaling maintains communication and adaptation among cells through specific molecules, receptors, and signaling pathways.


Signal Transduction Pathway:

  • Receptor activation: Ligand binds to its receptor.
  • Transduction: Intracellular signaling cascade (proteins, second messengers such as cAMP, DAG, IP3).
  • Response: Altered gene expression, enzyme activity, or cellular behavior.

Key Components of Signaling:

  • Signaling molecules: Hormones, cytokines, neurotransmitters, growth factors.
  • Receptors:
    • GPCRs → activate G-proteins.
    • Ion channel receptors → regulate ion flow.
    • Enzyme-linked receptors → initiate enzymatic activity.

Importance:

  • Essential for development, differentiation, immune responses.
  • Maintains homeostasis and regulates metabolism.
  • Involved in tissue repair and disease mechanisms.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Autocrine (Option B): In this mode, cells respond to signaling molecules they secrete themselves (self-regulation). Example: Tumor cells releasing growth factors that act back on themselves. This is different from the localized neighbor-cell effect seen in paracrine signaling.

Endocrine (Option C): Hormones secreted into the bloodstream act on distant targets (e.g., insulin, thyroid hormones). This systemic effect is not what is depicted here, since paracrine signaling acts locally.

Merocrine (Option D): This term refers to a mode of secretion (exocytosis of vesicles, e.g., sweat glands) and not a type of cell-to-cell signaling mechanism.

Reference:

  1. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41392-024-01888-z
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK9924/

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with sudden jerking movements of the limbs towards the body. Developmental regression is noted on examination. EEG reveals hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triad of infantile spasms, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia on EEG is diagnostic of West Syndrome.
  • The drug of choice is ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone).

West Syndrome Overview:

  • Age group: 2-12 months.
  • Genetics: ARX gene mutation in males; associated with ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.
  • Types:
    • Cryptogenic (unknown etiology): normal development prior to onset.
    • Symptomatic: linked with perinatal insults, brain malformations, metabolic disorders.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Infantile spasms (sudden flexor spasms, clusters during drowsiness or awakening).
    • Developmental regression.
    • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG (chaotic high-voltage pattern with multifocal spikes).
  • Management:
    • First-line: ACTH 150 units/m²/day (75 units/m² twice daily) for 2 weeks, taper gradually.
    • Monitoring with EEG at 1, 2, and 4 weeks.
    • Early treatment is critical, as delay >3 weeks worsens prognosis.
  • Alternative treatments:
    • Prednisolone (less effective).
    • Vigabatrin (especially in TSC).
    • Ketogenic diet.
    • Other antiepileptics (valproate, benzodiazepines, lamotrigine, topiramate, zonisamide, IVIG).
  • Side effects and precautions:
    • Hormonal therapy → hypertension, hyperglycemia, electrolyte imbalance, gastric ulcers, infections.
    • Live vaccines contraindicated during and shortly after hormonal therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Phenytoin (Option A): Useful for focal seizures and status epilepticus but ineffective in infantile spasms or hypsarrhythmia.

Levetiracetam (Option C): Effective for focal seizures and status epilepticus but has no proven benefit in West syndrome.

Phenobarbitone (Option D): Commonly used in neonatal seizures and as an enzyme inducer in metabolic disorders, but less effective than ACTH in managing infantile spasms.

Key Takeaways:

  • West syndrome = triad of infantile spasms, regression of milestones, and hypsarrhythmia on EEG.
  • ACTH is the drug of choice.
  • Vigabatrin is preferred in cases associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC).

questions.text: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis in the community and a vaccination drive is launched. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is one of the leading causes of viral encephalitis in endemic parts of Asia. During outbreak situations, the vaccine of choice is the inactivated (killed) JE vaccine, which is given via the intramuscular (IM) route. This vaccine is preferred in vaccination drives as it is safe, stable, and effective in rapidly protecting large populations.
  • The live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine is also available but is mainly utilized in routine immunization programs and not the primary choice during acute outbreak control.

questions.text: One week after having unprotected sexual intercourse, a 25-year-old male develops urethral discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of purulent, yellow urethral discharge appearing within 2-7 days after sexual exposure is characteristic of gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus, oxidase-positive, and grows on Thayer-Martin selective medium.
  • The organism primarily infects the urogenital tract but can also involve the rectum, pharynx, conjunctiva, and disseminate.
  • Transmission occurs via unprotected sexual contact or vertical transmission during childbirth.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option B):

  • Causes nongonococcal urethritis (NGU).
  • Discharge is typically clear or mucoid, not thick, yellow, and purulent.
  • Often presents with mild or asymptomatic infections.
  • More associated with chronic urethritis, prostatitis, infertility.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) (Option C):

  • Classically presents with painful grouped vesicles/ulcers on genitalia.
  • Can cause urethritis, but discharge is not the dominant symptom.
  • Urethritis with HSV is usually accompanied by burning pain and visible genital lesions.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D):

  • Protozoan parasite causing trichomoniasis.
  • In men: may cause urethritis, but often asymptomatic.
  • Discharge: frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling (different from thick purulent discharge in gonorrhea).
  • More symptomatic in women (vaginitis, pruritus, discharge).

questions.text: What is the appropriate term to describe a person who sits naked on their balcony, deriving sexual pleasure from observing others looking at them, while overlooking a park?
questions.solution:
The behavior described in the scenario, where a guy derives sexual gratification by sitting nude on his balcony and observing people who look at him, is Exhibitionism.

Exhibitionism is a paraphilic disorder where a person achieves sexual gratification by exposing their genitals to unsuspecting individuals or by being observed in a state of nudity.

  • In this case, the man derives pleasure from sitting naked on his balcony while others notice him.
  • Variants:
    • Streaking: Running naked in public.
    • Mooning: Displaying bare buttocks.
    • Flashing: Momentary exposure by lifting clothing.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Voyeurism (Option A):

  • Also called Scoptophilia or "Peeping Tom."
  • Refers to sexual pleasure from secretly watching others undress, bathe, or engage in sexual acts.
  • Differs from exhibitionism, where the person enjoys being watched, not watching.

Fetishism (Option B):

  • Refers to sexual gratification from inanimate objects or body parts, such as shoes, undergarments, or leather.
  • The scenario involves exposure and being looked at, not object-based arousal.

Masochism (Option D):

  • Sexual gratification obtained from receiving pain, humiliation, or suffering from a partner.
  • Example: wanting to be beaten or degraded.
  • Not applicable here, since the arousal is from nudity and being seen, not pain.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following human papillomavirus types are considered high-risk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image and history indicate condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts), most caused by HPV types 6 and 11.
  • The biopsy showing squamous atypia raises concern for progression to high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) or malignancy, which is associated with high-risk HPV types.
  • Among the listed options, HPV 18 is a high-risk oncogenic strain. Along with HPV 16, it is strongly linked to cervical, anal, penile, vulvar, and oropharyngeal cancers.
  • HPV 18 is particularly associated with cervical adenocarcinoma.

HPV and oncogenic potential:

  • Low-risk types (HPV 6, 11): Cause benign anogenital warts and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.
  • High-risk types (HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 45): Cause cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cancers of the cervix, vulva, anus, penis, and oropharynx.
  • HPV 2: Associated with common cutaneous warts (verruca vulgaris), not anogenital warts.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

HPV 2 (Option A): Causes common skin warts (verruca vulgaris). It is not linked to anogenital warts or malignancy.

HPV 6 (Option C): A low-risk HPV type causing benign anogenital warts. It does not carry malignant potential.

HPV 11 (Option D): Another low-risk type, associated with genital warts and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis. It is not linked to cancer.

Key Takeaway:

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most important high-risk oncogenic strains, associated with cervical and other anogenital cancers. In contrast, HPV types 6 and 11 are low-risk and cause benign genital warts. Biopsy showing atypia in genital lesions should raise suspicion for infection with a high-risk strain such as HPV 18.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: What would be your immediate course of action in managing a patient who is experiencing bleeding from the surgical site following a tonsillectomy while in the recovery room?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage is a life-threatening complication due to the risk of severe blood loss and airway obstruction.
  • The immediate step is to take the patient back to the operating theater (OT).
  • Once in OT, clots are removed to expose the bleeding site.
  • The bleeding vessel is then cauterized or ligated to achieve definitive hemostasis.
  • This is especially important in primary post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage (within the first 24 hours), which typically arises from inadequate hemostasis during surgery.

Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage can be classified into:

Key principles in management:

  • Airway protection is always the priority.
  • Urgent return to OT for surgical control of bleeding in primary hemorrhage.
  • IV access, resuscitation, and blood grouping/cross-matching are done simultaneously.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa (Option B): Antibiotics and packing may have a role in secondary hemorrhage due to infection, but in primary hemorrhage, definitive surgical control with cautery/ligation is essential.

Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours (Option C): This is unsafe and inappropriate. Anticoagulants worsen bleeding, gargling is ineffective in stopping active hemorrhage and waiting risks fatal airway obstruction or exsanguination.

Do blood transfusion and wait and watch (Option D): Blood transfusion may be required if significant blood loss has occurred, but it does not stop active bleeding. The bleeding source must be surgically controlled immediately.

Key Takeaway:

Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage, particularly primary hemorrhage within 24 hours, requires urgent surgical re-exploration. The correct approach is to shift the patient to OT, evacuate clots, and cauterize or ligate the bleeding vessel, as this is the only way to secure hemostasis and prevent airway compromise.

choices.text: Advice ultrasound and visit after 2 weeks
Internal podalic version followed by vaginal delivery

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation with a history of a classical cesarean section in her previous pregnancy presents with a breech fetus. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper segment of the uterus, which carries a high risk of uterine rupture in subsequent pregnancies. Because of this, vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) is contraindicated, especially when the fetus is in a breech presentation.

  • Planned cesarean at 37 weeks is recommended to:
    • Minimize the risk of spontaneous labor and uterine rupture
    • Ensure fetal maturity
    • Optimize maternal and fetal safety

Contraindications for TOLAC / Indications for Cesarean Delivery:

  1. Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision
  2. Prior extensive myomectomy involving the uterine cavity
  3. More than two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS)
  4. Pelvic abnormalities or suspected cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)
  5. Other obstetric complications such as:
    • Pre-eclampsia or eclampsia
    • Malpresentation (breech, transverse lie)
    • Placenta previa or accreta
  6. Medical complications limiting safe labor
  7. Limited availability of resources for emergency cesarean (anesthesia, surgical team, blood transfusion)
  8. Patient refusal to undergo TOLAC
  9. History of prior uterine rupture

Explanation of other options:

Advice ultrasound and visit after 2 weeks (Option B): Performing an ultrasound at this stage will not alter the management decision. The history of a prior classical cesarean section is the critical factor, and cesarean delivery remains the safest option. Monitoring alone would put the patient and fetus at risk of uterine rupture.

Internal podalic version followed by vaginal delivery (Option C): Internal podalic version is a technique primarily used for the second twin in a transverse lie. It is not indicated for a singleton breech pregnancy and is contraindicated in women with a prior classical cesarean due to high risk of uterine rupture.

External cephalic version at 36 weeks (Option D): External cephalic version (ECV) is performed to turn a breech fetus into cephalic presentation. It is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section because abdominal manipulation can precipitate uterine rupture and endanger both mother and fetus.

Key Takeaway:

  • A prior classical cesarean is an absolute contraindication for VBAC.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK507844/

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
Pseudomembrane is a layer of inflammatory cells and debris

questions.text: A woman who was prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic presents with recurrent diarrhea. Regarding Clostridium difficile infection, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is a toxin-mediated colitis, classically associated with recent broad-spectrum antibiotic use. It may present with mild diarrhea, but in severe cases can progress to fulminant colitis, characterized by hypotension/shock, ileus, toxic megacolon, and multi-organ failure.

Reference: Colitis due to Clostridium difficile toxins: underdiagnosed, highly virulent, and nosocomial - PMC

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. Investigations revealed intramural fibroids measuring 7×5 cm and 5×3 cm at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was normal. What is the appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intramural fibroids can distort the uterine architecture, impair implantation, and reduce fertility.
  • Since this patient wishes to retain fertility, the appropriate management is myomectomy, which removes the fibroids while preserving the uterus.
  • Myomectomy restores normal uterine anatomy, thereby improving the chances of conception.

Techniques:

  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy: For small submucosal fibroids (<3-4 cm).
  • Laparoscopic or open myomectomy: For larger subserous or intramural fibroids like in this case.

Explanation of other options:

Uterine artery embolisation (Option A): Blocks blood supply to fibroids, causing shrinkage. However, it may compromise uterine blood flow and endometrial receptivity, thereby reducing fertility. Not suitable for women desiring future pregnancy.

Artificial reproductive techniques (Option C): May be considered later if infertility persists post-myomectomy. But the primary issue here is mechanical distortion from fibroids, so surgical correction is the first step.

GnRH analogues (Option D): Used temporarily to shrink fibroids preoperatively and reduce intraoperative blood loss. They are not definitive treatments and fertility is not restored long-term.

Key Takeaway:

  • Myomectomy is the treatment of choice for infertility caused by large intramural fibroids in women desiring future fertility.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in the buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is classical for measles (rubeola). The hallmarks include:

  • Prodrome: Cough, coryza, conjunctivitis ("3 C"s").
  • Koplik spots: Bluish-white spots on buccal mucosa, pathognomonic for measles.
  • Rash: Erythematous, maculopapular rash starting on the face and neck, spreading downwards.

The measles virus is a member of the Paramyxoviridae family, genus Morbillivirus. It is an enveloped virus containing single-stranded, negative-sense RNA (ssRNA).

Clinical Stages of Measles:

Complications of Measles:

  1. Secondary Bacterial Infections (due to post-measles immune suppression)
    • Otitis media, bronchopneumonia.
    • Reactivation/worsening of tuberculosis (may cause false-negative Mantoux).
  2. Direct Viral Complications
    • Giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht's pneumonia) in immunocompromised.
    • Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis).
    • Severe diarrhea → malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency.
  3. Central Nervous System Complications
    • SSPE (Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis): Rare, progressive neurodegenerative disorder occurring years later.
    • Post-measles encephalomyelitis.
    • Measles inclusion body encephalitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Naked ssRNA (Option B):

  • Example: Enteroviruses, Hepatitis A virus.
  • These lack an envelope and cause different illnesses (e.g., gastroenteritis, meningitis, hepatitis A). Do not match the clinical picture of measles.

Naked dsRNA (Option C):

  • Example: Reoviridae family (Rotavirus).
  • Causes acute gastroenteritis in children, not cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, or rash.

Enveloped dsRNA (Option D):

  • Rare category. Rotavirus is dsRNA but non-enveloped, while other dsRNA viruses are not human pathogens.
  • No enveloped dsRNA virus is responsible for measles-like presentation.

questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies?
1. Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
2. Baby on artificial feeding
3. Baby of working mother/single parent
4. Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
5. Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, babies on artificial feeding and those with a working mother or single parent fall under the "at-risk" category.
  • These infants are more vulnerable to malnutrition, infection, and inadequate care, requiring closer monitoring.

Criteria for At-Risk Infants:

  • Low birth weight (<2.5 kg).
  • Twins
  • Higher birth order (≥5).
  • Artificial feeding.
  • Weight <70% of expected weight.
  • Failure to gain weight for 3 consecutive months.
  • Children with PEM or recurrent diarrhea.
  • Babies of working mothers or single parents.

These risk factors are used to identify infants who need special attention to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Key Takeaways:

  • At-risk infants include those with low birth weight, artificial feeding, PEM, frequent diarrhea, high birth order, and social risk factors.
  • Early identification allows for targeted interventions to reduce neonatal and infant mortality.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most used nerve for monitoring?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular monitoring is routinely used in anesthesia to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and recovery.
  • The ulnar nerve is the most widely used because it is easily accessible, reliable, and produces a consistent muscle response.
  • Stimulation of the ulnar nerve results in contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle, producing thumb adduction, which is easily observed and quantified.
  • This makes it ideal for evaluating both the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the adequacy of recovery before extubation.

Neuromuscular monitoring:

  • Typically done with peripheral nerve stimulators using train-of-four (TOF), tetanus, or double-burst stimulation.
  • It helps avoid residual paralysis and ensures safe recovery from anesthesia.
  • Adductor pollicis monitoring reflects conditions at the laryngeal muscles and diaphragm reasonably well, though these muscles recover earlier than peripheral ones.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Median nerve (Option B): Stimulating the median nerve causes thumb flexion, but this response is less reliable and less commonly used in routine neuromuscular monitoring.

Radial nerve (Option C): Innervates wrist and finger extensors. These responses are not standardized for neuromuscular monitoring, making it less suitable.

Metacarpal nerve (Option D): This nerve is not used for neuromuscular monitoring, as it does not consistently produce a reliable muscle contraction for assessing blockade.

Key Takeaway:

The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve in neuromuscular monitoring, with the adductor pollicis muscle contraction serving as a reliable marker for assessing depth of blockade and adequacy of recovery under anesthesia.

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum haemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT, and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In atonic postpartum haemorrhage (PPH), the surgical control of bleeding is achieved by stepwise devascularization:

  1. Uterine artery ligation - the first step, as it is the main arterial supply to the uterus. The ascending branch is ligated at the lateral border of the uterus between the upper and lower segments.
  2. Ovarian artery ligation - if bleeding persists, the ovarian artery (from the abdominal aorta, via the infundibulopelvic ligament) is ligated just below the ovarian ligament.
  3. Internal iliac artery ligation - ligation of the anterior division, approximately 5 cm distal to the common iliac bifurcation, reduces pulse pressure by ~85%, promoting clot formation and hemostasis in distal vessels.
  • This sequence progressively reduces uterine perfusion while preserving future fertility.

Explanation of other options:

Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery (Option B): The external iliac artery supplies the lower limb, not the uterus. Its ligation would not control uterine bleeding.

Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery (Option C): The vaginal artery supplies the vagina and lower uterus but is not typically targeted in stepwise devascularization for PPH.

Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery (Option D): The pudendal artery supplies the perineum and external genitalia, not the uterus. Hence, its ligation will not control PPH.

Key Takeaway

  • Stepwise devascularization in atonic PPH: uterine artery → ovarian artery → internal iliac artery.

questions.text: Identify the given structure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pancreatic islet cells (islets of Langerhans) are clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas that regulate glucose metabolism.

  • Cell Types:
    • Alpha cells → secrete glucagon
    • Beta cells → secrete insulin
    • Delta cells → secrete somatostatin
    • PP cells → secrete pancreatic polypeptide
  • Histological Features:
    • Appear as round or irregularly shaped clusters scattered throughout the exocrine pancreas.
    • Surrounded by a delicate connective tissue capsule.
    • Lightly stained compared to surrounding exocrine acinar cells on H&E sections.

These cells play a crucial role in maintaining blood glucose homeostasis.


Lymph node (Option A): Composed of a cortex with follicles, paracortex, and medulla containing lymphoid tissue, not endocrine cell clusters.


Glomerulus (Option B): Refers to a tuft of capillaries in the kidney that participates in filtration; structurally very different from islets.


Spleen (Option C): Contains red pulp and white pulp, organized around central arteries, not small clusters of endocrine cells.


Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7565096/

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertension presents to the emergency department with loss of consciousness, severe chest pain, and diaphoresis. She is grossly unstable, and examination reveals unequal bilateral pulses. ECG shows nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation is classic for aortic dissection: acute chest pain, collapse, diaphoresis, unequal pulses.
  • The investigation of choice in an unstable patient is transoesophageal echocardiography (TEE), as it is rapid, highly sensitive, and can be performed bedside.

Transoesophageal Echocardiography (TEE):

  • Uses a transducer at the end of an endoscope inserted into the oesophagus.
  • Provides high-resolution images, especially for posterior cardiac structures.
  • Sensitivity ~98%, specificity ~90% for detecting dissections of the ascending and descending aorta.
  • Preferred in intubated and unstable patients, and often used intraoperatively.
  • Risks: oesophageal trauma, perforation, aspiration, anaesthesia-related complications.

Clinical Features of Aortic Dissection:

  • Pain: Sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back or interscapular region.
  • Symptoms: Syncope, dyspnea, neurological deficits (hemiplegia, hemianesthesia, paraplegia), bowel ischemia, hematuria, myocardial ischemia.
  • Examination: Hypertension or hypotension, pulse deficits, aortic regurgitation murmur, pulmonary edema.
  • Complications: Acute severe AR, hemopericardium, tamponade, stroke, aneurysm rupture.

Investigations in Aortic Dissection:

  • Chest X-ray (Option D): May show mediastinal widening or pleural effusion but is nonspecific.
  • ECG: Usually nonspecific; absence of ischemia helps distinguish from acute MI.
  • Transthoracic echo: Sensitivity 60-85%; better for proximal dissections.
  • TEE: Best for unstable patients, rapid and accurate.
  • CT/MRI (Option A): >90% sensitivity and specificity; useful in stable patients, detailed mapping of extent and branch vessel involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

MRI (Option A): Highly accurate for defining dissection and branch vessel involvement, but impractical in unstable patients due to time and availability.

Cardiac enzymes (Option C): Elevated in myocardial infarction, not diagnostic for aortic dissection; not helpful in this acute unstable presentation.

X-ray (Option D): Can show widened mediastinum or pleural effusion but lacks sensitivity and specificity to confirm dissection.

Key Takeaways:

  • In suspected aortic dissection with hemodynamic instability, TEE is the investigation of choice.
  • CT or MRI can be considered in stable patients.
  • Rapid diagnosis and management are critical to prevent fatal complications.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A young male presenting with chronic low back pain, morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain is highly suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and spine.
  • Pain and stiffness are worse after rest and improve with activity, which distinguishes it from mechanical causes.
  • Heel pain is due to enthesitis (inflammation at tendon/ligament insertions), a classic feature of spondyloarthropathies.

Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Etiology: Strongly associated with HLA-B27 (positive in ~90% of cases).
  • Pathogenesis: Enthesitis → erosion → new bone formation → syndesmophytes → fusion ("bamboo spine").
  • Clinical features:
    • Chronic back pain and stiffness (onset <40 years).
    • Limited spinal mobility (positive Schober test).
    • Enthesitis (Achilles tendon, plantar fascia).
    • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees).
    • Extra-articular: anterior uveitis, aortic regurgitation, conduction abnormalities, apical pulmonary fibrosis, IBD association.
  • Radiology:
    • Sacroiliitis (blurred margins, sclerosis, erosions).
    • "Squaring" of vertebral bodies.
    • "Bamboo spine" (syndesmophytes bridging vertebrae).
    • "Dagger sign" (ossification of interspinous ligaments).
  • Diagnosis: Modified New York Criteria (clinical + radiological).
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: NSAIDs and physical therapy.
    • For severe disease: TNF inhibitors (infliximab, adalimumab) or IL-17 inhibitors (secukinumab).
    • Sulfasalazine for peripheral arthritis; corticosteroids only for flares.
    • Surgery (hip replacement, spinal osteotomy) in advanced cases.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tuberculosis of the spine (Option A): Also known as Pott's disease, presents with back pain, deformity, abscess, and systemic features like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Not associated with morning stiffness and heel enthesitis.

Disc prolapse (Option C): Causes acute or subacute back pain, often with radiculopathy. Symptoms worsen with activity, not at rest, and there is no enthesitis.

Mechanical pain (Option D): Typically due to strain or posture, improves with rest, and lacks systemic or inflammatory features.

Key Takeaway:

A young male with chronic inflammatory back pain and heel enthesitis most likely has ankylosing spondylitis, an HLA-B27-associated spondyloarthropathy. It is distinguished from mechanical causes by worsening with rest and improvement with activity, and requires long-term anti-inflammatory and biologic therapy for disease control.

questions.text: A primigravida at term presented with labour pain and multiple painful vesicular lesions on her vulva. No rashes were found elsewhere on the body. What will be the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term.

  • Risk: Neonatal herpes is a serious condition, with transmission risk highest (30-50%) if the mother has active lesions during delivery.
  • Management:
    • Treat with Acyclovir to reduce viral shedding and symptom severity.
    • Elective cesarean section is indicated if genital lesions or prodromal symptoms (pain, burning, tingling) are present at the onset of labour to minimise vertical transmission.

Explanation of other options:

Acyclovir and induction of labour (Option B): Inducing labour in the presence of active HSV lesions is contraindicated. Vaginal delivery would expose the neonate to the virus.

Spontaneous delivery (Option C): Allowing vaginal delivery despite active lesions carries a high risk of neonatal herpes, which can be life-threatening.

Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery (Option D): Even after antiviral therapy, vaginal delivery is not recommended if active genital lesions are present at labour onset.

Key Takeaway:

Active genital herpes at term is managed with Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section to prevent neonatal herpes transmission.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be started before supplementing with bisphosphonates
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman with a past history of Colles' fracture presents with lower back pain. Her evaluation shows a T score of -2.5. Which of the following statements regarding the management of her condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bisphosphonates are generally safe for long-term use (around 3-5 years) in most patients, with regular monitoring to evaluate their effectiveness and potential risks such as jaw osteonecrosis or unusual fractures.

The patient's prior pathological wrist fracture along with her T-score confirms the diagnosis of osteoporosis, which heightens the likelihood of future fractures.

Bisphosphonates are the first-line therapy for osteoporosis management.

Commonly prescribed agents include Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid.

Although treatment duration depends on individual response and clinical factors, bisphosphonates may be continued for several years to preserve bone mass and lower fracture risk.

Therapy can be extended up to 10 years, but use beyond this period carries an increased risk of femoral fractures.

Mechanism of action:



Explanation of other options:

Teriparatide should be started before supplementing with bisphosphonates (Option A): Teriparatide, a synthetic form of parathyroid hormone (PTH), is frequently used as a first-line therapy for severe osteoporosis. It promotes new bone formation and is usually prescribed ahead of bisphosphonates in patients with severe disease or those who have recently sustained a fragility fracture.

Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day (Option C): Postmenopausal women are generally advised to consume about 1200 mg of calcium daily, as sufficient calcium intake is essential for bone strength and osteoporosis prevention.

Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium (Option D): Oral calcium is commonly combined with vitamin D3, since vitamin D is vital for calcium absorption and bone health. Postmenopausal women with osteoporosis often need vitamin D supplements to maximize calcium uptake, with vitamin D3 being the preferred form.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with tremors and rigidity, and examination reveals a mask-like facial expression. Which of the following medications would be appropriate for his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The elderly patient shows features consistent with Parkinson's disease, characterized by tremors, rigidity, slowness of movement (bradykinesia), and a reduced facial expression known as "masked facies" for which selegiline can be used.

  • In Parkinson's disease, degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra causes reduced dopamine in the striatum, leading to motor problems like rigidity and tremors.
  • Selegiline, an MAO-B inhibitor, works by blocking dopamine breakdown in the brain, thereby raising its levels and improving motor control.
  • It is frequently given in combination with levodopa/carbidopa as part of therapy.
  • This drug is particularly valuable in the early phase of Parkinson's disease when levodopa/carbidopa by itself is insufficient to manage symptoms.

Explanations of other options:

Clozapine (Option A): Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic mainly prescribed for schizophrenia and other severe mental illnesses, blocks dopamine receptors and may aggravate the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Donepezil (Option B): Donepezil, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in Alzheimer's disease, works by boosting acetylcholine levels in the brain but does not improve the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Haloperidol (Option D): Haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic used in the management of schizophrenia and acute psychosis, acts by blocking dopamine receptors but may exacerbate Parkinsonian symptoms due to its dopamine-blocking effects.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon's hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?
questions.solution:
The surgeon's choice to operate while intoxicated demonstrates reckless disregard for patient safety, which crosses the threshold of civil negligence and falls under criminal negligence.

  • This act is punishable under Section 304A IPC (Indian Penal Code) → now Section 106 BNS (Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) → "Causing death by negligence."
  • It applies when death is caused by a rash or negligent act that does not amount to culpable homicide.
  • Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Civil Negligence Not Amounting to Criminal Negligence (Option B):

  • Civil negligence involves breach of duty resulting in harm, usually leading to damages decided in civil court.
  • The surgeon's conduct went beyond simple negligence - it was a gross and reckless act.
  • Therefore, this case falls under criminal negligence, not civil.

Therapeutic Misadventure (Option C):

  • Refers to unavoidable or unintended complications during treatment that occur despite due care (e.g., rare drug reaction).
  • In this case, the surgeon knowingly operated while intoxicated, which is not accidental but a deliberate reckless act.

Dichotomy (Option D):

  • Dichotomy means the illegal practice of fee-splitting between two medical professionals.
  • It has no relation to negligence or intoxication during surgery, so it is not applicable here.

Key Takeaway:



Reference:

  1. IPC
  2. CORRESPONDENCE TABLE and COMPARISON SUMMARY OF THE BHARTATIYA NYAYA SANHITA, 2023 (BNS) to THE INDIAN PENAL CODE, 1860 (IPC)

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus underwent successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement. Four months later, the child presents with fever, irritability, and neck stiffness. Meningitis is suspected. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The best step in suspected VP shunt-related meningitis is obtaining CSF from the shunt tap, along with blood cultures, as it directly reflects infection within the shunt system.

Shunt-Related Meningitis:

  • Most common complication of VP shunts.
  • Frequently caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis (coagulase-negative staphylococcus).
  • Diagnosed by shunt tapping.
  • Managed with antibiotics and usually shunt removal/revision.

Complications of CSF Shunts:

  • Obstruction: headache, vomiting, papilledema, altered sensorium.
  • Infections:
    • Meningitis → fever, headache, irritability.
    • Peritonitis → abdominal pain, tenderness, distension.
    • Wound infection → erythema, swelling, discharge, dehiscence along shunt tract.

Explanation of Other Options:

Wait and watch (Option A): Unsafe; meningitis requires urgent evaluation.

Check shunt patency by nuclear study (Option B): Useful for malfunction, but not appropriate in suspected infection.

Lumbar puncture (Option D): Less reliable; CSF from shunt tap is preferred for diagnosing shunt-related infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • Always suspect infection in a VP shunt patient with fever and neurological symptoms.
  • Shunt tap + blood culture is the investigation of choice.
  • Definitive management includes antibiotics and often shunt removal.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a PCSK9 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Evolocumab, a monoclonal antibody, is a PCSK9 inhibitor employed in managing elevated cholesterol levels.

PCSK9 inhibitors:

  • These drugs act on PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9), a protein that limits the liver's capacity to clear LDL cholesterol ("bad" cholesterol) from circulation.
  • Elevated LDL cholesterol is considered harmful because it plays a major role in the development of cardiovascular disease.
  • Normally, LDL receptors on liver cells recycle to the surface to remove LDL from the blood, but when PCSK9 binds to these receptors, it blocks their recycling.
  • As a result, LDL accumulates in the bloodstream, raising the risk of heart disease.
  • Evolocumab is given as a subcutaneous injection every 2-4 weeks, based on dosage and patient response.
  • It is commonly prescribed alongside other lipid-lowering agents, like statins, for patients who are unable to achieve target LDL cholesterol levels through diet and exercise alone.

Other PCSK-9 inhibitors:

  • Alirocumab and Evolocumab: Used in familial hypercholesterolemia and cardiovascular disease to lower LDL-C. Administered subcutaneously every 2 weeks or once monthly. Offen combined with statins for enhanced LDL-C reduction.
  • Inclisiran: A newer agent that acts as a small interfering RNA (siRNA), reducing PCSK9 production.

Explanations of other options:

Ezetimibe (Option B): Ezetimibe lowers blood cholesterol by blocking the uptake of dietary and biliary cholesterol in the small intestine and is distinct from PCSK9 inhibitors.

Bempedoic acid (Option C): Bempedoic acid is a newer lipid-lowering drug that targets ATP-citrate lyase, an enzyme in hepatic cholesterol synthesis, and unlike PCSK9 inhibitors, it works through a different mechanism.

Clofibrate (Option D): Clofibrate, a fibrate drug, acts by stimulating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), enhancing fatty acid breakdown and improving lipid levels, and it does not act on PCSK9.

questions.text: What is the classification of the air quality index in Delhi station on November 23, based on the provided Air Quality Index (AQI) chart for 4 consecutive days?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

On November 23, the AQI recorded in Delhi was 407. According to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) classification of AQI in India, any value between 401-500 falls in the Severe category. This denotes serious health impacts on the general population and qualifies as an emergency condition requiring immediate public health interventions.

Air Quality Index (AQI) in India:

The AQI is a standardized tool to report air quality and its potential impact on health. It is derived from the concentration of major pollutants:

  • Particulate matter: PM10, PM2.5
  • Nitrogen dioxide (NO2)
  • Sulfur dioxide (SO2)
  • Carbon monoxide (CO)
  • Ozone (O3)

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4213258/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7182097/

questions.text: A pregnant woman whose niece living in the same household developed varicella was tested for serum antibodies against varicella. Her antibody test result was negative. What does this imply?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer

The varicella-zoster virus (VZV) causes two clinically distinct diseases:

  • Chickenpox (Varicella): Primary infection.
  • Herpes Zoster (Shingles): Reactivation of latent virus in sensory ganglia.

The presence or absence of VZV-specific IgG antibodies in the serum indicates immune status:

  • Positive IgG: Evidence of prior infection or vaccination → Immune.
  • Negative IgG: No prior exposure or vaccination → Susceptible to primary varicella (chickenpox).

In this case, the patient's negative antibody test means she has never had chickenpox and has not been vaccinated. Therefore, she is at high risk of contracting chickenpox after exposure to her infected niece.

This is especially concerning in pregnancy because:

  • First or second trimester infection can cause congenital varicella syndrome (limb hypoplasia, cicatricial skin scarring, ocular and CNS defects).
  • Peripartum infection may result in severe neonatal varicella, with high morbidity and mortality.

Explanation of Other Options:

She is immune to zoster (Option A): Zoster occurs only after prior varicella infection. Since she has no antibodies, she has never had VZV infection and cannot be immune to zoster.

She is susceptible to zoster (Option B): Zoster is a reactivation disease, which requires prior primary infection. Without initial exposure, she cannot develop zoster.

She is immune to chickenpox (Option D): Negative antibody status indicates lack of prior exposure or vaccination, hence no immunity.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has fundal height lag and oligohydramnios.
  • The most common cause of oligohydramnios in the second and third trimesters is renal agenesis.
  • In renal agenesis, absence of kidneys → no fetal urine output → reduced amniotic fluid (since urine is the main source of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks).

Diagnostic criteria for oligohydramnios:

  • Amniotic fluid volume < 500 mL
  • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) ≤ 5 cm
  • Single Deepest Vertical Pocket (SDVP) ≤ 2 cm

Explanation of other options:

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option B): Causes polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing, not oligohydramnios.

Cardiac abnormalities (Option C): May reduce placental perfusion and contribute to growth restriction, but oligohydramnios is not the classic finding.

Ureteral stricture (Option D): Can lead to hydronephrosis and reduced urine output, but bilateral renal agenesis is the more common and classic cause of severe oligohydramnios.

Key Takeaway:

Oligohydramnios at 26 weeks with lagging fundal height is most commonly due to renal agenesis (absent fetal urine production).

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6375007/.

questions.text: A patient with a pituitary tumor secreting excess growth hormone had surgery, but the tumor could not be completely excised. What is the preferred first-line therapy in this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Octreotide is the first-line therapy for patients with growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumors when surgical removal is incomplete.

Octreotide, a synthetic analogue of somatostatin, suppresses growth hormone (GH) release from the pituitary and can be administered intravenously or subcutaneously, with a longer-lasting effect than natural somatostatin.

Medical management is the choice when curative surgery is not possible or when GH levels remain elevated after resection.

Explanations of other options:

Leuprolide (Option A): Leuprolide, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, suppresses the secretion of LH and FSH and is mainly used in treating prostate cancer, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and precocious puberty.

Goserelin (Option B): Goserelin, a GnRH agonist like leuprolide, is mainly utilized for managing prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis.

Nafarelin (Option C): Nafarelin is a GnRH agonist mainly prescribed for the management of endometriosis and precocious puberty.

questions.text: A patient who had a stroke 2 days ago now presents with uncontrollable, violent, and jerking movements of the limbs on one side of the body. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation is consistent with hemiballismus, a hyperkinetic movement disorder marked by involuntary, forceful, flinging movements of the extremities on one side. This condition typically follows a vascular insult (stroke) that damages the subthalamic nucleus.

Basal Ganglia and Movement Disorders:

  • Hypokinetic Disorders
    • Parkinsonism: Caused by dopamine deficiency in the substantia nigra pars compacta.
    • Clinical features: Akinesia, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, resting tremor, shuffling gait, stooped posture, micrographia, reduced facial expression, and mood/cognitive changes.
  • Hyperkinetic Disorders
  • Hemiballismus: Lesion of the subthalamic nucleus → decreased inhibition of the thalamus → excessive, uncontrolled movements.
  • Huntington's Disease: Degeneration of striatal neurons in the indirect pathway → choreiform, dance-like movements.
  • Dystonia: Dysregulation of the direct pathway → sustained, twisting, and abnormal postures.

Anatomical Role of Basal Ganglia Structures:

  • Striatum (Caudate + Putamen): Major input center receiving cortical signals. (Options C & D ruled out)
  • Globus Pallidus (GPe, GPi): Processes inhibitory and excitatory motor signals. GPi exerts tonic inhibition on the thalamus.
  • Substantia Nigra:
    • Pars compacta: Dopamine production (degenerates in Parkinsonism).
    • Pars reticulata: Inhibitory output to the thalamus via GABA. (Option B ruled out)
  • Subthalamic Nucleus: Provides excitatory glutamatergic input to GPi and SNr. Damage → loss of inhibition → hyperkinetic state → hemiballismus. (Correct Answer)

Key Neurotransmitters:

  • Dopamine: From substantia nigra (pars compacta), modulates direct & indirect pathways.
  • GABA: Major inhibitory transmitter (striatum, GPi, GPe, SNr).
  • Glutamate: Major excitatory transmitter (cortex → striatum; subthalamic nucleus → GPi/SNr).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Substantia nigra (Option B): Lesions here reduce dopamine and produce Parkinsonism (hypokinetic features: rigidity, tremor, bradykinesia), not violent flinging movements.

Putamen (Option C): As part of the striatum, it primarily influences voluntary motor control, but isolated lesions here are not associated with hemiballismus.

Caudate nucleus (Option D): Involved in cognitive and limbic aspects of motor control; its degeneration is classic in Huntington's disease, producing chorea rather than hemiballismus.

questions.text: What is the standard unit for measuring the brightness of light emitted from a single point source?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The candela (cd) is the SI base unit of luminous intensity, representing the brightness of light emitted by a source in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of visible light perceived by the human eye and is one of the seven fundamental units in the International System of Units (SI).

Photometry and Light Measurement:

Photometry is the science of measuring visible light, taking into account the spectral sensitivity of the human eye. It plays a key role in:

  • Illumination engineering (street lighting, architectural lighting)
  • Display technologies (television, computer monitors)
  • Medical imaging (ensuring optimal illumination)
  • Astronomy (measuring stellar brightness)

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In normal pregnancy, extravillous trophoblasts invade maternal spiral arteries and remodel them into low-resistance, high-capacitance vessels, ensuring adequate uteroplacental blood flow.
  • First wave (10-12 weeks): invasion up to decidua.
  • Second wave (16-18 weeks): invasion into myometrium.
  • In preeclampsia, this second wave fails → spiral arteries remain narrow and muscular → placental ischemia.
  • Placental ischemia triggers release of anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng) → systemic endothelial dysfunction → hypertension, proteinuria, and organ involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts (Option A): Villous trophoblasts form chorionic villi for maternal-fetal exchange, not for spiral artery remodeling.

Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts (Option B): Radial arteries are upstream uterine arteries, not directly remodeled by cytotrophoblasts.

Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts (Option D): Arcuate arteries supply radial arteries; they are not the target of trophoblast invasion.

Key Takeaway:

  • Preeclampsia results from failure of spiral artery remodeling by extravillous trophoblasts, leading to placental ischemia and systemic maternal endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops profuse, watery, "rice-water" stools. The enterotoxin of the causative agent binds to which of the following receptors on intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of acute, voluminous, "rice-water" diarrhea is the pathognomonic sign of cholera, an infection caused by Vibrio cholerae. The disease's profound secretory diarrhea is mediated by the potent cholera enterotoxin, which initiates its pathogenic cascade by binding specifically to the GM1 ganglioside receptor located on the apical surface of intestinal epithelial cells.

Pathogenesis of Cholera Toxin:

The mechanism of action is a well-defined, multi-step process:

  1. Bacterial Adhesion: After ingestion, cholerae utilizes its toxin-coregulated pilus (TCP) to adhere to the epithelial surface of the small intestine, primarily the jejunum.
  2. Toxin Structure: The cholera toxin is a classic A-B toxin, composed of one A (Active) subunit and five B (Binding) subunits.
  3. Receptor Binding and Internalization: The pentameric ring of B subunits binds with high affinity to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the enterocyte membrane. This interaction facilitates the endocytosis of the entire toxin molecule.
  4. Activation and Cellular Effect:
    • Once inside the cell, the A subunit is cleaved into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • The A1 fragment is the enzymatically active component. It ADP-ribosylates the Gs alpha subunit of the adenylate cyclase complex, locking it in a constitutively active ("on") state.
    • This leads to a massive, unregulated increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP).
    • The elevated cAMP levels hyperactivate the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) chloride channel, causing a dramatic secretion of chloride, sodium, bicarbonate, and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic secretory diarrhea.

Clinical Features of Cholera:

  • Abrupt onset of profuse, painless, watery diarrhea.
  • Stool described as "rice-water" effluent: grey, opalescent liquid with mucus flecks and a characteristic fishy odor.
  • Massive fluid loss (>1 liter per hour) leading to rapid severe dehydration.
  • Hypovolemic shock features: tachycardia, hypotension, sunken eyes, poor skin turgor.
  • Electrolyte losses:
    • Profound hypokalemia (due to potassium loss).
    • Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (due to bicarbonate loss).
  • Complications from dehydration and electrolyte imbalance:
    • Painful muscle cramps.
    • Acute renal failure (pre-renal azotemia).
    • Life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias (secondary to severe hypokalemia).
    • Paralytic ileus (due to electrolyte imbalance).

Explanation of Other Options:

Cerebroganglioside (Option A): These gangliosides are primarily present in neural tissue and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders; they are not involved in cholera pathogenesis.

GM2 ganglioside receptor (Option B): This receptor is linked with Tay-Sachs disease due to hexosaminidase A deficiency, not cholera toxin activity.

Sphingomyelin (Option D): A membrane phospholipid important in lipid metabolism; defective metabolism causes Niemann-Pick disease, but it is not a receptor for cholera toxin.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cholera toxin: Increases cAMP via adenylate cyclase activation → massive chloride and water efflux → profuse watery diarrhea.
  • Heat-stable toxin (ST) of E. coli: Increases cGMP via guanylate cyclase activation → watery diarrhea through a distinct pathway.

questions.text:
As a medical professional at a primary health center (PHC) located in a region prone to frequent seismic activity, which measures would you take to ensure preparedness for an emergency?
1. Ensure availability of financial and other essential resources for disaster management
2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
3. Conduct disaster simulations and assess the response
4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Preparedness for disasters in seismic-prone areas focuses on proactive planning and readiness at the PHC level. The key measures include:

  1. Ensure availability of financial and other essential resources:
    • Securing funds, medical supplies, equipment, and trained personnel ensures that the PHC can respond efficiently during an earthquake or other emergencies.
    • This step forms the backbone of a robust disaster management plan.
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers:
    • Community education on earthquake safety, evacuation procedures, and first aid reduces panic and ensures organized response.
    • Public awareness campaigns can include posters, pamphlets, drills, and announcements using loudspeakers.
  3. Conduct disaster simulations and assess the response:
    • Simulation exercises (mock drills) help identify gaps in the disaster plan and improve coordination among staff and emergency services.
    • Evaluating these drills allows for continuous improvement of preparedness strategies.

These actions align with standard disaster preparedness protocols.

Role of Statement 4 (Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials) in Disaster Management:

  • Following instructions from higher officials via phone or radio is a reactive measure that occurs during the event itself.
  • Preparedness involves proactive steps taken before a disaster, not instructions received during the emergency.

questions.text: A male patient completed a full course of anti-tuberculosis therapy. Sputum examinations were performed at the end of both the intensive phase and the continuation phase, and both results were negative. What is the correct classification of the patient's treatment outcome?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

According to World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for tuberculosis treatment outcomes:

A patient is classified as "cured" if:

  1. They complete the full course of TB treatment.
  2. Sputum smear or culture results are negative at the end of the intensive phase and at the end of the continuation phase.

In this patient, both criteria are fulfilled: treatment was completed and microbiological confirmation showed negativity after both phases. Therefore, the correct classification is "cured".

Explanation of Other Options:

Treatment completed (Option B): This classification applies when a patient completes TB therapy but does not have follow-up sputum smear or culture results to confirm negativity. Since this patient had documented negative results at both phases, he is not classified under "treatment completed".

Lost to follow-up (Option C): A patient is considered lost to follow-up if they interrupt treatment for two consecutive months or more before completing the regimen. This patient adhered to the therapy, so this category does not apply.

Treatment failed (Option D): Treatment failure is defined by:

  1. Persistence of positive sputum smears or cultures at 5 months or later during therapy.
  2. Clinical deterioration despite ongoing treatment.

In this case, sputum results were negative and there was no clinical deterioration, so the patient does not meet criteria for treatment failure.

questions.text: What is the appropriate management for a 35-year-old woman with choriocarcinoma who presents with metastases to the lung, spleen, and kidney, had a previous molar pregnancy removed 6 months ago, a pretreatment serum hCG level of 10,000 IU/mL, a uterine tumour measuring 6 cm, and failed chemotherapy with methotrexate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has stage IV gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) with extra-pulmonary metastases (spleen and kidney) and a WHO prognostic score of 11.

According to FIGO/WHO guidelines:

  • Stage IV disease (metastasis to any site beyond the lungs) is high-risk, regardless of score.
  • High-risk GTN (score ≥7) requires multi-agent chemotherapy, most commonly the EMACO regimen.
  • Low risk: 0-6 → single-agent (methotrexate ± folinic acid)
  • High risk: ≥7 → multi-agent (EMACO regimen)

Explanation of options:

Methotrexate with folinic acid (Option A): Used in low-risk GTN, not suitable for high-risk metastatic disease.

Methotrexate (Option B): Monotherapy is insufficient for high-risk GTN, especially after prior treatment failure.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Considered only in localised disease or uncontrolled bleeding, but does not address metastatic disease.

Key Takeaway:

High-risk choriocarcinoma (FIGO stage IV or WHO score ≥7) requires multi-agent chemotherapy - EMACO is the regimen of choice.

Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/initial-management-of-high-risk-gestational-trophoblastic-neoplasia

questions.text: What is the most effective way to verify the placement of the endotracheal tube in a 30-year-old male patient who has been intubated for surgery by a final-year resident?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most accurate and reliable method for confirming correct endotracheal tube placement is capnography, which measures end-tidal CO₂ concentration.
  • Continuous detection of CO₂ in exhaled air confirms that the tube is in the trachea and not the esophagus.
  • This method provides immediate, real-time, and continuous monitoring, making it the gold standard during anesthesia and resuscitation.

Malposition of the endotracheal tube can cause life-threatening complications, including hypoxia, esophageal intubation, or unilateral ventilation. Clinical methods alone are not sufficient; hence capnography is essential.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

X-ray chest (Option A): Helpful for confirming tube depth and detecting complications (eg, pneumothorax) but not practical for immediate confirmation at the bedside.

Auscultation (Option B): Checking for bilateral breath sounds is useful but unreliable, as air entry may still be heard with esophageal intubation or if the tube is inserted into one bronchus.

Chest rise (Option D): Visible rise of the chest does not rule out esophageal intubation, as bag-mask ventilation can also cause chest movement. It is only a supportive sign, not definitive.

Key Takeaway:

End-tidal CO₂ monitoring (capnography) is the gold standard for confirming endotracheal tube placement. While clinical signs like auscultation and chest rise are helpful, they cannot reliably exclude esophageal intubation.

questions.text: A female patient presents with six weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure is normal. Investigations show a beta-hCG of 1400 mIU/mL. Ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium with normal adnexa. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) since transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy despite a positive beta-hCG. At levels close to the discriminatory zone (~1500 mIU/mL), an intrauterine gestational sac should normally be visible on ultrasound.

  • The best next step is to repeat beta-hCG after 48 hours to assess its trend:
    • Normal intrauterine pregnancy: beta-hCG doubles every 48 hours.
    • Ectopic pregnancy: beta-hCG plateaus or rises slowly.
    • Early pregnancy loss: beta-hCG declines.
  • This helps guide further imaging or intervention.

Explanation of other options:

Repeat ultrasound after 3 days (Option B): Ultrasound is less sensitive at this stage, as the pregnancy may be too early to visualize. Beta-hCG dynamics provide more useful information before repeating the scan.

Measurement of progesterone (Option C): Serum progesterone can indicate viability (<5 ng/mL suggests nonviable pregnancy), but it cannot determine the location (intrauterine vs. ectopic). Hence, it is not the preferred test.

Laparoscopy (Option D): Diagnostic and therapeutic laparoscopy is indicated only if the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if ectopic pregnancy is confirmed. It is too invasive as a first step in this stable patient.

Key Takeaway:

  • In a patient with pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) and stable vitals, the next step is serial beta-hCG measurement after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy, or early pregnancy loss.
