questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is observed. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The case describes a dermatophytic infection with the following key clues:

  • Red pigment production on culture (reverse side of colony).
  • Pencil-shaped macroconidia.

These features are classic for Trichophyton rubrum. It is the most common dermatophyte causing infections in humans, especially tinea corporis, cruris, and axillaris.

Macroscopic Colony Appearances of Trichophyton and Microsporum:

Microscopic Features of Trichophyton and Microsporum:

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was initiated on a new medication, and after two days developed the condition shown below. Which drug is most likely responsible for this effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows purple toe syndrome, a complication associated with Warfarin use.

Explanations of other options:

Heparin (Option B): Heparin, an anticoagulant used in a manner similar to warfarin, may lead to bleeding, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), and osteoporosis with prolonged therapy. The drug of choice for treating heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is a direct thrombin inhibitor, such as dabigatran.

Dabigatran (Option C): Dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor used for anticoagulation, generally does not lead to a hypercoagulable state.

Rivarox (Option D): Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that acts as a direct factor Xa inhibitor and, like others in its class, does not usually induce hypercoagulability.

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, and the cervix is dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipitotransverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical findings are consistent with deep transverse arrest:

  • Station 0 → head engaged but not descending further.
  • Right occipitotransverse (ROT) position → sagittal suture lies in the transverse bispinous diameter.
  • Caput (2+) and molding (2+) → suggest prolonged arrest and early cephalopelvic disproportion.
  • No progress for 2 hours despite good contractions → confirms arrest.

In this scenario, cesarean section is the safest option to prevent fetal distress and maternal complications.

Explanation of other options:

Midpelvic forceps (Option A): Not appropriate at station 0 with molding and caput; risk of trauma is high.

Vacuum-assisted delivery (Option B): Used when head is low (station +2 or more) and descent is possible. Not suitable at midpelvic arrest.

Wait for an hour (Option C): Already 2 hours in second stage with no descent; waiting further increases risks without benefit.

Key Takeaway

  • Deep transverse arrest at station 0 with caput and molding is best managed by lower segment cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or expectant management.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7905427/

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Many children from a particular community coming to a hospital were detected to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the community's water. If a case-control study has to be conducted to determine whether the chemical exposure and ALL are associated, what should be taken as the control group?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

In a case-control study, the primary goal is to compare individuals with the disease (cases) to those without the disease (controls) to examine differences in exposure to a potential risk factor.

  • Controls should ideally be:
    • Free from the disease in question (here, ALL).
    • Similar to cases in other characteristics like age, sex, and environment.
    • Representative of the population from which the cases arise, to minimize selection bias.

In this scenario, children coming to the same OPD who do not have ALL fulfill these criteria. They are comparable to the cases in demographic and environmental characteristics but are not affected by the disease, allowing a valid comparison of exposure (cytotoxic waste in water).

Explanation of Other Options:

Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease (option A): Although they are disease-free, they are already exposed to the suspected risk factor. This could bias the study, as controls ideally should represent the exposure distribution of the population that produced the cases.

Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease (option B): This group has the disease but is not exposed, so they cannot serve as controls, as controls must be disease-free.

All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status (option D): This describes cases, not controls. Including them would defeat the purpose of comparing exposed vs. non-exposed groups.

questions.text: Which type of alopecia is commonly associated with inflammatory alopecia in a 30-year-old male patient who presents with tinea capitis infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tinea capitis is a superficial fungal infection of the scalp caused by dermatophytes (Trichophyton and Microsporum species).
  • While ectothrix and endothrix types typically cause non-inflammatory alopecia, Favus and Kerion are the inflammatory variants associated with scarring alopecia.
  • Kerion:
    • Caused by Trichophyton verrucosum (often zoonotic, eg, cattle).
    • Severe inflammatory reaction with boggy, tender swelling, pustules, abscesses, and hair loss.
    • May cause patchy scarring alopecia if untreated.
  • Favus:
    • Caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.
    • Chronic infection leading to yellow cup-shaped crusts (scutula).
    • Produces a honeycomb appearance and results in permanent scarring alopecia.

Types of Tinea Capitis and Alopecia Patterns

Endothrix and Favus (Option A): Endothrix infections are non-inflammatory and do not typically cause scarring. Favus is inflammatory, but this pair is partially correct, not fully.

Ectothrix and Endothrix (Option B): Both are non-inflammatory forms, producing hair breakage but not scarring alopecia.

Kerion and Endothrix (Option D): Kerion is inflammatory, but Endothrix is not. Hence, this combination is incorrect.

Key Takeaway:

The inflammatory forms of tinea capitis associated with scarring alopecia are Favus and Kerion. Early recognition and treatment with systemic antifungals (eg, griseofulvin, terbinafine) are essential to prevent permanent hair loss.

questions.text: A male patient with COPD was started on theophylline therapy. By the next day, he observed an increase in urine output. Through which receptor is this effect of the drug mediated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rise in urine output seen in this patient on theophylline occurs due to its action on adenosine A1 receptors.

Theophylline acts as a nonselective antagonist at adenosine receptors, blocking adenosine activity at A1, A2A, A2B, and A3 subtypes.

Its inhibition of renal A1 receptors specifically results in enhanced glomerular filtration and promotes diuresis.

Explanations of other options:

Interleukin-10 (Option A): Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that helps control immune activity by preventing excessive inflammatory injury. It does not play a direct role in producing diuresis or in the pharmacological actions of theophylline.

Histone deacetylase (Option B): Histone deacetylases are enzymes that influence gene regulation by stripping acetyl groups from histone proteins. They do not contribute to the diuretic action of theophylline.

Beta 2 adrenergic receptors (Option D): Beta-2 adrenergic receptors are mainly located in the lungs, where their stimulation leads to bronchodilation. They are absent in the kidneys.

Key takeaway:

Adenosine A1 receptors are present in the kidneys and play a role in controlling fluid and electrolyte homeostasis. Inhibition of these receptors by theophylline results in enhanced urine output and diuresis.

questions.text: The Pathanamthitta district of Kerala was affected by floods and the government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. Which other chemical will be distributed along with it?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Floods predispose to two major categories of health problems:

  1. Leptospirosis: Spread through exposure to water contaminated with urine of infected animals. Doxycycline is distributed as a chemoprophylactic measure.
  2. Vector-borne diseases: Floodwaters create ideal breeding conditions for mosquitoes, leading to a rise in malaria, dengue, and other arboviral infections.

To address this, Malathion, an organophosphate insecticide, is distributed and used for mosquito control (space spraying, fogging). This complements doxycycline prophylaxis, targeting both leptospirosis and mosquito-borne infections simultaneously.

questions.text: A patient with known atherosclerosis undergoes circumflex artery bypass with successful stent placement. He is already receiving lisinopril, verapamil, and metoprolol. Which additional drug should be given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patients undergoing PCI with stent placement require dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) to prevent thrombosis and ischemic complications.
  • P2Y12 receptor blockers (clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) are added along with aspirin to reduce the risk of death, reinfarction, and stroke.

Post-PCI Management - Key Points:

  • Aspirin: continued indefinitely.
  • P2Y12 receptor blockers: added for 1-12 months depending on stent type and patient risk profile.
  • Clopidogrel: 300 mg loading → 75 mg daily.
  • Ticagrelor: 180 mg loading → 90 mg twice daily.
  • Prasugrel: 60 mg loading → 10 mg daily.
  • Newer drug-eluting stents: reduce restenosis but require prolonged DAPT.

Explanation of Other Options:

PDE 3 inhibitor (Option A): Used in heart failure and peripheral vascular disease (e.g., cilostazol, milrinone) but not in post-PCI routine management.

Direct oral anticoagulant (Option B): Indicated in atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism, or mechanical heart valves, but not routinely required post-PCI unless another indication exists.

PDE 5 inhibitor (Option D): Includes sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil; used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension, not for stent management in IHD.

Key Takeaways:

  • After PCI with stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + P2Y12 blocker) is the standard of care.
  • P2Y12 blockers (clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) prevent stent thrombosis and improve long-term outcomes.
  • Choice of drug depends on bleeding risk and patient profile.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines with which strain could have prevented it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical and pathological findings are classic for Yellow Fever, a severe viral hemorrhagic fever caused by a Flavivirus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nakayama Strain (Option B): A formalin-inactivated mouse brain vaccine used against Japanese encephalitis, not yellow fever.

Weigl's Strain (Option C): Developed against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, unrelated to flaviviruses.

Jeryl Lynn Strain (Option D): Live-attenuated vaccine strain used against mumps (in MMR vaccine), not protective against yellow fever.

questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits cytochrome complex IV, a component of the electron transport chain responsible for ATP synthesis?
questions.solution:
Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain.
  • It binds tightly to the heme group at the enzyme's active site, preventing electron transfer from cytochrome c to oxygen.
  • As a result, the electron transport chain halts, causing accumulation of reducing agents such as NADH and FADH2.
  • Since Complex IV is the terminal step where electrons are passed to oxygen to form water, cyanide poisoning stops oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation, leading to cellular hypoxia despite normal oxygen availability.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Carbon dioxide (Option B):

  • CO2 does not directly inhibit Complex IV.
  • In blood, CO2 mainly exists as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), which have no direct effect on the electron transport chain.

Oligomycin (Option C):

  • Oligomycin does not affect Complex IV.
  • Instead, it inhibits ATP synthase (Complex V) by binding to the Fo subunit, blocking proton flow through the enzyme and preventing ATP production, while electron transport continues.

Ouabain (Option D):

  • Ouabain does not act on the electron transport chain.
  • It inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the plasma membrane, altering ionic gradients.
  • Its action is relevant in cardiotonic activity but unrelated to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation.

Reference: ETC inhibitors

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post-cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and drowsiness. She has a respiratory rate of 10/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and bilaterally absent knee reflexes. What is the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture points to magnesium sulfate toxicity, not diabetic or eclamptic complications:

  • Absent deep tendon reflexes (knee reflexes) → classic early sign of magnesium toxicity
  • Respiratory rate of 10/min → respiratory depression (seen when serum magnesium ~12 mEq/L)
  • Oliguria → reduced renal excretion → drug accumulation
  • Blood glucose (240 mg/dL) is elevated but not sufficient to explain the CNS depression seen

Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity

Monitoring:

  • Observe deep tendon reflexes, respiratory rate, and urine output
  • Reflex loss at ~9 mg/dL, respiratory depression at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL), cardiac arrest >30 mg/dL

Serum Magnesium Levels:

  • 5-9 mg/dL → therapeutic
  • 9 mg/dL → loss of patellar reflexes
  • ~12 mEq/L → respiratory depression
  • 30 mg/dL → cardiac arrest

Management:

  1. Stop magnesium infusion immediately
  2. Calcium gluconate 10 mL of 10% IV over 3 minutes → antidote
  3. Furosemide for enhanced excretion (if renal function allows)
  4. Intubation & ventilation if severe respiratory depression

Explanation of other options:

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option B): Presents with dehydration, Kussmaul respiration (not hypoventilation), and altered sensorium. Here, absent reflexes point away from DKA.

Eclampsia (Option C): Involves seizures and hypertension-related complications, but drowsiness with absent reflexes and low RR strongly indicate drug toxicity.

Diabetes insipidus (Option D): Causes polyuria, polydipsia, and hypernatremia, not oliguria and CNS depression.

Key Takeaway

  • Absent reflexes + oliguria + respiratory depression in a preeclamptic woman on magnesium sulfate = magnesium sulfate toxicity.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32443079/

questions.text: A patient involved in a motor vehicle accident was brought to the emergency department 2 hours post-injury. He was stable, with GCS 15/15 and reactive pupils. Examination revealed bruising and tenderness over the left lower chest wall with petechiae, severe tenderness in the left hypochondrium, and blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. What is the most appropriate investigation in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In trauma patients presenting with abdominal or thoracic injury suspicion, the FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is the investigation of choice in the ER.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST)

  • Purpose: Rapid bedside ultrasound to detect free intraperitoneal, pericardial, or pleural fluid.
  • Utility: Helps quickly identify hemoperitoneum, hemothorax, or pericardial tamponade.
  • Advantages:
    • Non-invasive and portable
    • Performed simultaneously with resuscitation
    • Detects as little as ~100 mL of blood
    • Reproducible and rapid
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent
    • Less reliable in obese patients or with excessive bowel gas
    • Low sensitivity for hollow viscus injury and retroperitoneal trauma
    • Cannot fully define the extent of organ damage

Explanation of other options:

X-ray (Option B): Useful for fractures or chest injuries but not reliable for intra-abdominal bleeding.

DPL (Option C): Sensitive for intraperitoneal bleeding and still used in resource-limited areas, but invasive and largely replaced by FAST/eFAST. Contraindicated in pregnancy, prior laparotomy, and obvious laparotomy cases.

CT scan (Option D): Gold standard for detailed evaluation of solid organ injury but requires a hemodynamically stable patient. Not ideal in this hypotensive patient.

Key Takeaway:

In a hemodynamically unstable trauma patient, the first-line ER investigation is FAST, as it rapidly detects intraperitoneal, pleural, or pericardial fluid and guides immediate management.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old infant who was brought in by their mother due to complaints of light sensitivity, difficulty opening the eyes, and excessive tearing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm in a 2-month-old infant represents the classic triad of congenital glaucoma.
  • These symptoms are caused by elevated intraocular pressure leading to corneal edema and discomfort.
  • The age of presentation (infancy), together with these characteristic findings, makes congenital glaucoma the most likely diagnosis.

Primary congenital glaucoma:

  • Types:
    • Newborn/true congenital: Raised IOP develops during intrauterine life, globe already enlarged at birth; presents within the first month.
    • Infantile: Onset ≤3 years.
    • Juvenile: Onset >3 years.
  • Pathogenesis: Trabeculodysgenesis, absent angle recess, abnormal iris insertion (flat insertion shows scleral spur and ciliary body; concave insertion hides them).
  • Clinical features:
    • Triad: lacrimation, photophobia, blepharospasm (often with eye rubbing).
    • Corneal edema: earliest sign, can lead to opacity.
    • Corneal enlargement: >13 mm indicates abnormal, >16 mm suggests poor prognosis.
    • Haab's striae: breaks in Descemet's membrane visible as lines.
    • Deep anterior chamber, optic disc cupping/atrophy, raised IOP (not acute), axial myopia due to elongation.
  • Management: Direct goniotomy followed by trabeculotomy is preferred.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ophthalmia neonatorum (Option A): Neonatal conjunctivitis, often due to gonococcal or chlamydial infection, presents with conjunctival redness and purulent discharge. It does not cause photophobia with blepharospasm, corneal edema, or globe enlargement.

Congenital dacryocele (Option C): Caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, producing a bluish cystic swelling at the medial canthus with epiphora. It does not cause corneal edema, corneal enlargement, or increased IOP.

Congenital cataract (Option D): Presents with leukocoria and abnormal red reflex, sometimes leading to strabismus. It does not cause photophobia with excessive tearing or blepharospasm due to raised IOP.

Key Takeaway:

The triad of photophobia, epiphora, and blepharospasm in an infant is diagnostic of congenital glaucoma. Early recognition and surgical intervention (goniotomy → trabeculotomy) are essential to preserve vision and prevent long-term complications such as optic nerve damage and buphthalmos.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is given indomethacin. What effect is this drug likely to have on the fetus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indomethacin, a non-selective COX inhibitor, can lead to early closure of the ductus arteriosus when administered during pregnancy.

questions.text: The following test is done to assess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image demonstrates the Pen test, which evaluates the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.
  • This muscle is supplied by the median nerve (specifically, the recurrent branch of the median nerve).
  • In the test, the patient is asked to abduct the thumb perpendicular to the palm while holding or reaching toward a pen; inability to do so suggests median nerve palsy.

Clinical tests for the median nerve:

  • Pen test:
    • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis.
    • Action: Abduction of thumb perpendicular to palm.
  • Oschner's clasp test:
    • Muscles: Flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus (for index and middle fingers).
    • Finding: "Pointing index sign"; due to inability to flex index finger fully.
  • Thumb opposition test:
    • Muscle: Opponens pollicis.
    • Action: Opposition of thumb to little finger.
    • Normal finding: Formation of an "O-sign."

Management of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative: Splints, physiotherapy, and observation.
  • Surgical: If no recovery is observed -
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): explored after 9 months.
    • Low median nerve palsy (forearm level): explored after 12 months.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option A): Innervates finger extensors. Its injury causes finger drop but does not affect thumb abduction.

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Supplies intrinsic hand muscles (interossei, adductor pollicis). Ulnar nerve palsy causes claw hand, not weakness of thumb abduction.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option C): Supplies biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis. Injury leads to loss of elbow flexion and lateral forearm sensation, not thumb weakness.

Key Takeaway:

The Pen test assesses the median nerve via the abductor pollicis brevis. Failure indicates median nerve dysfunction, commonly seen in carpal tunnel syndrome or traumatic injury.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a diabetic patient who has a visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye and further investigations reveal preretinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's features-visual acuity of 6/9, preretinal hemorrhages, and optic disc neovascularization-are characteristic of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), which is an advanced stage of diabetic eye disease.
  • In PDR, retinal ischemia triggers abnormal growth of fragile new blood vessels. These vessels are prone to rupture, resulting in preretinal hemorrhage and sometimes tractional retinal detachment.
  • The first-line therapy is pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP). This laser procedure destroys ischemic retinal tissue, lowering the drive for neovascularization.
  • The overall goal of PRP is to halt disease progression, reduce the risk of further bleeding, and protect remaining vision.

Abbreviated ETDRS Classification of Diabetic Retinopathy

  • Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):
    • No retinopathy: review annually (12 months).
    • Very mild NPDR: only microaneurysms present; most patients can be reviewed in 12 months.
    • Mild NPDR: includes microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, and cotton-wool spots, but not reaching moderate NPDR criteria. No IRMA or marked venous beading. Follow-up in 6-12 months depending on severity, systemic control, and patient factors.
    • Moderate NPDR: shows marked retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA. Venous beading may be limited to one quadrant. Cotton-wool spots often present. Review around 6 months.
    • Severe NPDR: defined by the 4-2-1 rule - severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants, venous beading in ≥2 quadrants, or moderate IRMA in ≥1 quadrant. Review in 4 months.
    • Very severe NPDR: presence of two or more of the above criteria. Review every 2-3 months.
  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):
    • Mild to moderate PDR: neovascularization at the disc (NVD) or elsewhere (NVE), but not sufficient for high-risk features. Treatment is individualized based on severity, systemic stability, and compliance with follow-up. If not treated, review within 2 months.
    • High-risk PDR: NVD >1/3-disc area, or any NVD with vitreous haemorrhage, or NVE >1/2-disc area with vitreous haemorrhage. Requires urgent intervention, ideally immediate treatment, especially in symptomatic patients with clear retinal view.
    • Advanced diabetic eye disease: characterized by tractional retinal detachment, persistent vitreous haemorrhage, or neovascular glaucoma. Requires vitreoretinal surgery along with laser treatment.
  • Management of PDR:
    • Pan-retinal Photocoagulation (PRP):
      • Aims to reduce metabolic demand by ablating ischemic retina, suppressing Vaso proliferative factor release, and converting hypoxic tissue into inert scars.
      • Commonly performed using Argon, frequency-doubled YAG, or diode lasers.
      • Treatment usually begins with the inferior quadrant.
      • The central macular area is preserved, leaving a circular zone of ~2.5 disc diameters around the fovea untouched.
      • Typically requires 2000-3000 laser burns, delivered in 2-4 sessions.
    • Anti-VEGF therapy: agents such as bevacizumab, ranibizumab, or aflibercept help control neovascularization.
    • Vitreoretinal surgery: indicated for tractional retinal detachment or persistent vitreous haemorrhage not resolving with laser or anti-VEGF.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Intravitreal corticosteroids (Option B): Useful for diabetic macular Edema, but they do not address ischemia or regress neovascularization. They are not the treatment of choice for PDR with optic disc new vessels.
  • Focal laser photocoagulation (Option C): This is used for localized leakage in clinically significant macular Edema, not for diffuse ischemia or optic disc neovascularization.
  • Vitrectomy (Option D): Reserved for advanced disease, particularly dense non-clearing vitreous haemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment. It is not the initial step when active proliferative retinopathy is identified with preserved vision.

Key Takeaway:

The appearance of optic disc neovascularization in diabetic retinopathy marks progression to the proliferative stage, which carries a high risk of vision-threatening complications. The standard and most effective treatment is pan retinal photocoagulation, aimed at reducing VEGF stimulus and preventing severe sequelae.

questions.text:
After a road traffic accident, a patient arrives at the emergency department. On examination, he is awake and alert, with:

1. BP: 90/60 mmHg
2. Respiratory rate: 40/min
3. Pulse: 120 bpm

An X-ray is provided showing pathology. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray demonstrates a right-sided pneumothorax. Given the patient’s tachypnea, tachycardia, and borderline hypotension, immediate decompression is required.

  • Definitive management: Insertion of an intercostal chest tube (tube thoracostomy) to evacuate air and allow lung re-expansion.
  • This restores normal pleural pressure, improves ventilation, and stabilizes hemodynamics.

Radiographic Features of Pneumothorax


  • Radiolucent (black) area without lung markings
  • Lung edge seen as a thin sharp radiopaque line, retracted toward the hilum
  • In tension pneumothorax:
    • Mediastinal shift to the opposite side
    • Depression of ipsilateral diaphragm
    • Collapsed lung on affected side

Special views to detect small pneumothorax:

  • Expiratory film: Enhances visibility as lung volume decreases
  • Lateral decubitus view (affected side up): Helps detect small pleural air
  • Supine patients: A horizontal beam lateral film may reveal anterior pneumothorax
  • Investigation of choice (IOC): CT chest - highly sensitive for small or loculated pneumothoraces.

Explanation of other options:

Pericardiocentesis (Option B): Indicated for pericardial tamponade, not pneumothorax.

Thoracotomy (Option C): Reserved for massive hemothorax, uncontrolled bleeding, or persistent large air leaks, not the first-line treatment here.

Pleurodesis (Option D): Elective procedure for recurrent pneumothorax, not in an acute traumatic case.

Key Takeaway:

In a trauma patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray, the next step is chest tube insertion to decompress the pleural cavity and allow lung expansion.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441885/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7390330/

[DT1]https://share.google/images/ckFyz48pasqlWBV9P

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the type of fixation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray suggests the use of a spanning external fixator, which is commonly applied across a joint (in this case, the knee) to stabilize periarticular fractures.
  • A spanning fixator immobilizes both the bone and the joint, allowing soft tissue recovery while maintaining skeletal alignment.
  • It is especially useful in cases of high-energy trauma, open fractures, comminuted fractures, and when definitive fixation must be delayed due to swelling or soft tissue compromise.

Spanning Fixator:

  • Definition: An external fixation device that stabilizes a fracture or joint instability by spanning across the adjacent joint.
  • Indications:
    • Complex periarticular fractures (eg, distal femur, proximal tibia).
    • Temporary stabilization in polytrauma.
    • Severe soft tissue injury requiring staged fixation.
  • Advantages:
    • Quick application with minimal soft tissue dissection.
    • Provides fracture stabilization while soft tissues recover.
    • Adjustable and can be converted to definitive fixation later.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Pin site infection risk.
    • Risk of joint stiffness if used for long periods.
    • Aesthetic issues due to external frame.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Fracture tibia, Ilizarov fixator (Option A): The Ilizarov is a circular external fixator used for complex deformity correction, bone lengthening, or non-unions. It is not the device shown in this periarticular case.


Fracture tibia, spanning fixator (Option B): While spanning fixators can be used for tibial fractures, the X-ray corresponds to a periarticular fracture near the knee joint, not a shaft tibia fracture.

Fracture femur, spanning fixator (Option C): A femur spanning fixator could be used in distal femur fractures, but the image and context point specifically to a periarticular knee application, making this option less accurate.

Key Takeaway:

A spanning fixator applied across the knee is most often used for periarticular fractures of the knee as a temporary or staged stabilization method, particularly in high-energy trauma with soft tissue compromise.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18978542/
  2. External-fixators

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MRI is contraindicated in cases where there is a risk of metallic intraocular foreign bodies.
  • The strong magnetic field can displace or rotate the metallic fragment, leading to further ocular damage, hemorrhage, or loss of vision.
  • In suspected metallic foreign bodies, safer options are CT scans, X-rays, or ultrasonography (in the absence of globe rupture).

Intraocular foreign bodies (IOFBs):

  • Definition: Objects that penetrate and remain inside the eye. They pose a serious threat to vision and may cause blindness.
  • Common materials:
    • Metallic (most frequent: iron, steel)
    • Others: stone, glass, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood
  • Tissue reaction:
    • Inorganic inert: glass, plastic → minimal reaction
    • Toxic metals: lead, aluminium, copper → significant inflammation
    • Organic: wood → granulomatous and giant-cell reaction

Diagnosis:

  • History: Nature of injury often indicates likely foreign body type.
  • Examination: Slit-lamp, gonioscopy, fundoscopy. Signs may include subconjunctival hemorrhage, corneal/iris scars, lens opacities, or visible IOFB.
  • Investigations:
    • X-ray: may detect radiopaque bodies but less sensitive.
    • CT scan: investigation of choice; accurately localizes both metallic and non-metallic IOFBs.
    • Ultrasonography (B-scan): helpful for radiolucent IOFBs if globe integrity is preserved.
    • MRI: contraindicated if metallic IOFB is suspected.

Treatment:

  • Foreign body removal depends on material, location, and risk.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: electromagnet extraction.
    • Non-magnetic: microsurgical removal.
  • Approach depends on site:
  • Anterior chamber → corneal incision
    • Iris → sector iridectomy
    • Lens → extracapsular extraction ± lens removal
    • Vitreous/retina → pars plana vitrectomy
  • Post-removal care: topical/systemic antibiotics, corticosteroids, cycloplegics for pain and inflammation.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

B-scan ultrasonography (Option A): Useful for detecting IOFBs, especially radiolucent ones like wood or plastic, and for posterior segment evaluation. It is safe provided there is no suspicion of an open globe rupture.

CT scan (Option B): The investigation of choice for suspected IOFBs. Provides accurate localization of metallic and non-metallic fragments without the risks associated with MRI.

X-ray (Option C): A simple, inexpensive test that can detect radiopaque foreign bodies. Less sensitive than CT but still safe and useful in initial screening.

Key Takeaway:

In cases of suspected metallic intraocular foreign bodies, MRI is contraindicated due to the risk of magnetic displacement and severe ocular injury. CT scan is the gold standard investigation, while B-scan and X-ray can also assist in diagnosis depending on the clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, a second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and a third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of recurrent early pregnancy losses and preterm delivery due to severe preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS).

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS)

Pathophysiology:

  • Antiphospholipid antibodies bind to β2-glycoprotein I, causing platelet activation and endothelial dysfunction → thrombosis.
  • Decreased Protein C/S activity and increased prothrombin activation worsen the prothrombotic state.

Clinical Features:

  • Thrombosis: Venous, arterial (stroke, MI), renal, or small-vessel.
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia, autoimmune hemolytic anaemia.
  • Pregnancy complications:
    • ≥3 unexplained miscarriages <10 weeks
    • ≥1 unexplained fetal death ≥10 weeks
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency <34 weeks
    • Fetal growth restriction or unexplained IUFD

Diagnosis (Sydney criteria - 1 clinical + 1 laboratory):

  • Clinical: Thrombosis, pregnancy morbidity (as above).
  • Lab: Positive lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, or anti-β2 glycoprotein-I antibody (medium/high levels, persistent ≥12 weeks apart).

Management in pregnancy:

  • APS with thrombosis: Therapeutic LMWH + low-dose aspirin (LDA).
  • APS with pregnancy morbidity but no thrombosis: Prophylactic LMWH + LDA.
  • Refractory APS: Add hydroxychloroquine or IVIG/prednisone (low dose).
  • Avoid warfarin and Xa inhibitors during pregnancy.

Explanation of other options:

Syphilis (Option A): Can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, or congenital infection, but not the recurrent early losses with preeclampsia described here.

TORCH infections (Option C): Lead to congenital malformations, IUGR, and occasional losses, but typically not recurrent miscarriages with maternal preeclampsia.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (Option D): Associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, polyhydramnios, and preeclampsia, but not with recurrent early miscarriages.

Key Takeaway:

  • Recurrent early miscarriages combined with preterm delivery due to severe preeclampsia strongly indicate Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS), which requires LMWH and aspirin during pregnancy.

Reference:

  1. https://sso.uptodate.com/contents/antiphospholipid-syndrome-obstetric-implications-and-management-in-pregnancy?search=APLA&source=search_result&selectedTitle=7~150&usage_type=default&display_rank=6

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with salaam spells with hypsarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice for management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 10-month-old with hypsarrhythmia and salaam seizures, typical of infantile spasms, is best treated with ACTH as the first-line therapy when not associated with tuberous sclerosis.

ACTH acts as a strong anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant, helping to control spasms by suppressing abnormal brain activity.

Explanations of other options:

Valproate (Option A): Valproate, an anticonvulsant widely used for different seizure types such as generalized and absence seizures, is not effective for managing infantile spasms.

Topiramate (Option B): Topiramate, another anticonvulsant, is prescribed for several seizure types including atypical absence, myoclonic, and atonic seizures, but it is generally not used for treating infantile spasms.

Phenobarbital (Option D): Phenobarbital, a barbiturate with anticonvulsant properties, is often given to neonates for febrile seizures or status epilepticus, but it is not considered the first-line treatment for infantile spasms.

questions.text: A male patient presented with the fracture of Tibia following a road traffic accident. He was managed appropriately, but after 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic triad of dyspnoea, hypoxemia, and petechial rash appearing 24-72 hours after a long bone fracture strongly suggests fat embolism syndrome (FES).
  • It occurs due to fat droplets released from the bone marrow into the bloodstream after trauma. These emboli lodge in pulmonary and systemic capillaries, leading to respiratory failure, neurological changes, and skin/mucosal petechiae.
  • This is a life-threatening condition requiring prompt recognition and supportive management (oxygen therapy, fluids, sometimes steroids).

Fat embolism syndrome:

  • Common causes: Long bone fractures (femur, tibia), pelvic fractures, orthopaedic surgery, burns.
  • Clinical features:
    • Respiratory distress (dyspnoea, tachypnoea, hypoxemia).
    • Neurological changes (confusion, agitation, seizures).
    • Petechial rash (chest, axilla, conjunctiva, oral mucosa).
  • Diagnostic criteria (Gurd and Wilson):
    • Major: Respiratory insufficiency, cerebral signs, petechial rash.
    • Minor: Tachycardia, pyrexia, retinal changes, jaundice, renal dysfunction, sudden anemia, thrombocytopenia, ↑ESR, fat macroglobulinemia.
  • Treatment: Supportive care-oxygen, fluids, mechanical ventilation if needed, DVT prophylaxis, and sometimes corticosteroids.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Air embolism (Option B): Usually occurs after trauma to large veins, surgery, or catheter procedures. Presents acutely with respiratory collapse, not with a delayed rash and neuro signs.

Venous thromboembolism (Option C): Can occur after fractures but causes pulmonary embolism without petechial rash. Typically presents with chest pain, tachypnoea, and hypoxemia.

Pulmonary hypertension (Option D): A chronic condition of elevated pulmonary artery pressure, not an acute complication of fracture with petechiae.

Key Takeaway:
In a patient with long bone fracture who later develops dyspnea, altered mental status, and petechial rash, the diagnosis is fat embolism syndrome, confirmed clinically and managed with supportive care.

Reference:

Fat embolism

questions.text: A middle-aged male with chronic renal failure on maintenance dialysis suddenly collapsed and was brought to the emergency with labored breathing. ECG revealed tall, tented T waves. Which of the following ABG values best represents the acid-base abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ABG pattern of low pH with markedly reduced bicarbonate is diagnostic of metabolic acidosis.

Metabolic Acidosis:

  • Definition:
    • Caused by a primary fall in serum bicarbonate or accumulation of hydrogen ions.
    • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO₃.
    • Compensation: Hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing) leads to ↓ pCO₂.
  • Types:
    • High anion gap acidosis (AG > 12 mEq/L)
    • Normal anion gap acidosis (AG 6-12 mEq/L)
  • Causes:
    • Mnemonic: MUDPILES (High AG):
      • M: Methanol
      • U: Uremia (renal failure)
      • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis
      • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
      • I: Iron, Isoniazid
      • L: Lactic acidosis
      • E: Ethylene glycol
      • S: Salicylates (late phase)
    • Mnemonic: HARD UP (Normal AG):
      • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
      • A: Acetazolamide
      • R: Renal tubular acidosis
      • D: Diarrhea
      • U: Ureteral diversion
      • P: Pancreatic fistula, GI fistulas
  • Clinical Features:
    • General: Lethargy, confusion, nausea/vomiting, fatigue, deep rapid breathing (Kussmaul).
    • Specific:
      • DKA: fruity odor, polyuria, polydipsia
      • Uremia: pruritus, fluid overload
      • Lactic acidosis: hypotension, shock
      • Toxins: methanol → visual symptoms; ethylene glycol → oxalate crystals

Explanation of Other Options:

pH 7.14, pCO₂ 20 mmHg, HCO₃ 34 mEq/L (Option B): Suggests acidemia, but the elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis, which is inconsistent with renal failure and hyperkalemia.

pH 7.54, pCO₂ 34 mmHg, HCO₃ 27 mEq/L (Option C): Indicates alkalosis. The slightly reduced pCO₂ suggests respiratory alkalosis, with near-normal bicarbonate. This does not fit the picture of metabolic acidosis in this case.

pH 7.40, pCO₂ 40 mmHg, HCO₃ 27 mEq/L (Option D): Reflects normal acid-base status with no abnormality, which is not compatible with the clinical scenario.

Key Takeaways:

  • In chronic renal failure with collapse and tall T waves, severe metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia is most likely.
  • Always correlate ABG findings with both pH and bicarbonate to identify the primary disorder.

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP increases the risk of Ml/stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In quintile 1, there is no risk of Ml/stroke

questions.text:
A researcher wants to investigate whether there is an association between C-reactive protein (CRP) levels and the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) or stroke. The study population was divided into quintiles, and the results are summarized below:

Which of the following statements is true regarding the relationship between CRP and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

CRP is an acute-phase reactant and a marker of systemic inflammation. Inflammation plays a key role in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction and stroke.

In this study, the relative risk increases progressively with higher CRP quintiles, demonstrating a dose-response relationship:

  • Quintile 1 (CRP 0.1-1.0 mg/L): RR = 1.0 → Baseline reference group
  • Quintile 2 (CRP 1.1-2.0 mg/L): RR = 1.3 → 30% higher risk than baseline
  • Quintile 3 (CRP 2.1-3.0 mg/L): RR = 1.7 → 70% higher risk than baseline
  • Quintile 4 (CRP 3.1-4.0 mg/L): RR = 2.1 → More than double the risk of baseline
  • Quintile 5 (CRP 4.1-5.0 mg/L): RR = 2.8 → Almost triple the risk compared to baseline

This monotonic trend clearly shows that higher CRP levels are associated with a progressively increasing risk of MI and stroke.

questions.text: What would be the suitable course of action for managing a 15-year-old girl who is non-adherent to wearing spectacles for her myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct choice is spherical equivalent spectacles.
  • For pediatric patients with myopic astigmatism, spectacles remain the safest and most effective initial treatment.
  • This method offers correction for both nearsightedness and the astigmatic component in a non-invasive and reversible manner.
  • At the age of 15, the eyes are still undergoing development; hence, permanent surgical procedures are not advised.
  • Spectacles are particularly useful in children as they avoid surgical risks, provide adequate visual improvement, and serve as a temporary solution until refractive stability is achieved.

Management of astigmatism involves multiple approaches depending on age, degree of astigmatism, and compliance:

Optical options

  • Spectacles: Cylindrical correction or spherical equivalent spectacles are the first-line treatment in children and adolescents.
  • Rigid contact lenses: Appropriate for cases with up to 3 diopters of astigmatism.
  • Toric contact lenses: Used for higher levels of astigmatism, generally above 3 diopters.

Refractive procedures

  • Phototherapeutic keratectomy: Excimer laser procedure useful in irregular astigmatism, corrects up to 3 diopters.
  • LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): Corneal reshaping surgery, effective up to 5 diopters, but only considered in adults with stable refraction.
  • Intraocular lenses: Toric intraocular lenses, including collamer lenses, may be used in adults when other corrective methods fail or are unsuitable.

Surgical options

  • Penetrating keratoplasty or Deep Lamellar Anterior Keratoplasty (DLAK): Considered in advanced cases such as corneal scarring or when optical and refractive measures are ineffective.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

LASIK (Option A): A surgical technique that reshapes the cornea after creating a flap. It is not appropriate in patients younger than 18 years because refractive stability is not yet established. Additionally, the patient's poor compliance with spectacles raises concerns about whether she would adhere to the strict postoperative care required after LASIK.

Femto LASIK (Option C): This is a modern variant of LASIK in which a femtosecond laser is used to create the corneal flap. However, it remains a LASIK procedure and therefore carries the same restrictions, including the need for stable refraction and good compliance. For a 15-year-old, it is not an acceptable choice.

Implantable Collamer Lens (Option D): Involves surgical placement of a synthetic lens in front of the natural lens to correct refractive errors. This method is invasive and intended for adults with stable refraction. It is not a reasonable option for a 15-year-old who struggles even with spectacle adherence.

Key Takeaway:

In adolescents with myopic astigmatism, spectacles are the first line and most suitable treatment. They are safe, reversible, and effective, while surgical interventions such as LASIK, Femto LASIK, and collamer lens implantation are postponed until adulthood, when the refraction is stable and the patient can reliably adhere to postoperative care.

questions.text: A patient taking aspirin developed occult blood in the stool. This happens because aspirin inhibits which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspirin-induced inhibition of thromboxane can cause gastrointestinal bleeding, leading to occult blood appearing in the stool.

Explanation of other options:

Phospholipase A2 (Option A): Phospholipase A2 is essential for liberating arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids, serving as the precursor for prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes. Aspirin does not block PLA2 directly; instead, it works further along the pathway by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins and thromboxanes.

Phospholipase C (Option C): Phospholipase C functions in cell signaling by breaking down phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) into diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol triphosphate (IP3). Both DAG and IP3 serve as second messengers, playing key roles in calcium signaling and activation of protein kinase C.

Phospholipase D (Option D): Phospholipase D participates in lipid signaling by breaking down phosphatidylcholine into phosphatidic acid, which serves as a precursor for various signaling molecules.

Key takeaway:

Thromboxane A2 is a strong pro-thrombotic and pro-inflammatory mediator that stimulates platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.

By inhibiting COX-1, aspirin lowers thromboxane A2 production, thereby decreasing platelet aggregation and reducing clot formation.

This effect, however, can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, sometimes presenting as occult blood in the stool.

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has a mechanical mitral valve and requires lifelong anticoagulation to prevent valve thrombosis.
  • Warfarin is teratogenic and increases the risk of fetal malformations and bleeding complications.
  • In the third trimester, the safest approach is to switch from warfarin to low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) to reduce fetal/neonatal risks, while still ensuring maternal anticoagulation.
  • LMWH is preferred over unfractionated heparin (UFH) because it has:
    • Better efficacy in preventing valve thrombosis
    • Longer half-life (allows fewer doses)
    • Lower risk of osteoporosis and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)

Guideline-based approach:

  • First trimester: Prefer LMWH if warfarin dose ≥5 mg (due to high teratogenic risk).
  • Second trimester: Warfarin may be continued if maternal risk is high and fetal risk is acceptable.
  • Third trimester (near term): Switch back to LMWH or UFH to minimise maternal bleeding and fetal complications at delivery.

Explanation of other options:

Stop warfarin and start heparin (Option B): UFH is less effective than LMWH and requires continuous infusion or frequent dosing, making LMWH the preferred choice.

Continue warfarin (Option C): Unsafe in late pregnancy; increases fetal bleeding risk during delivery.

Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin (Option D): Aspirin may be added in select patients, but the essential step here is anticoagulation with LMWH.

Key Takeaway:

  • In late pregnancy, warfarin should be discontinued and replaced with LMWH to minimise fetal and peripartum risks, while still protecting the mother against valve thrombosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presents with grade II/I uterine prolapse and cystocele. She complains of the involuntary passage of urine while coughing and sneezing. What type of urinary incontinence is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leakage of urine on coughing, sneezing, or exertion is the hallmark of stress urinary incontinence (SUI).
  • The association of uterine prolapse and cystocele further supports this diagnosis, as descent of the bladder neck and loss of the normal urethrovesical angle lead to funnelling and leakage.

Pathophysiology of Stress Urinary Incontinence:

  • Descent of the bladder neck below the levator ani muscle
  • Loss of the urethrovesical angle → causes funnelling of the bladder neck and proximal urethra
  • Pelvic floor weakness due to childbirth trauma, pudendal nerve damage, or intrinsic sphincter deficiency

Risk Factors:

  • Advancing age
  • Obesity (BMI > 20)
  • Pregnancy and vaginal delivery
  • Chronic cough, constipation, heavy lifting
  • Smoking
  • Cognitive/functional impairment

Explanation of other options:

Overflow incontinence (Option A): Occurs due to incomplete bladder emptying, leading to dribbling. Causes include outlet obstruction (e.g., enlarged prostate) or detrusor underactivity.

Urge incontinence (Option B): Caused by detrusor overactivity; presents with sudden urgency and involuntary leakage, often linked with an overactive bladder.

Neurogenic bladder (Option D): Due to neurological lesions disrupting bladder innervation, causing storage and emptying dysfunctions.

Key Takeaway:

Involuntary urine leakage on coughing or sneezing in a woman with prolapse and cystocele is diagnostic of stress urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7), arising from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, supplies the flexor muscles of the arm and gives sensory supply to the lateral aspect of the forearm through its terminal branch, the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

Key functions affected in this case:

  • Elbow flexion → Impaired due to paralysis of biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis.
  • Forearm supination → Weakened because the biceps brachii is affected (though not completely lost, as the supinator is still functional).
  • Sensory loss → Seen over the lateral forearm due to involvement of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.



Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Median nerve (Option A): Supplies most forearm flexors and thenar muscles. Sensory loss occurs over the lateral palm and first three fingers, not the lateral forearm. It does not control major elbow flexors or supination.
  • Radial nerve (Option B): Innervates the extensors of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Injury causes wrist drop and sensory loss over the posterior arm/forearm and dorsum of the hand-not the lateral forearm.
  • Ulnar nerve (Option D): Supplies intrinsic hand muscles and some forearm flexors. Sensory loss occurs over the medial hand and little finger, not the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Energy requirements during pregnancy increase progressively to support fetal growth:

  • First trimester (up to 12-13 weeks): Nutritional needs are generally unchanged.
  • Second trimester (≈13-28 weeks): Recommend an additional ~300 kcal/day.
  • Third trimester (≈29-40 weeks): Recommend an additional ~300-450 kcal/day.

This patient is at 12 weeks, approaching the second trimester; therefore, advising an additional 300 kcal/day is appropriate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with fatigue and constipation for 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago, lactational failure, and secondary amenorrhea since delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad is diagnostic of Sheehan syndrome (postpartum hypopituitarism) due to ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

  1. Lactational failure (prolactin deficiency),
  2. Amenorrhea (gonadotropin deficiency), and
  3. History of massive postpartum haemorrhage with transfusion,

Key Features of Sheehan Syndrome:

  • Symptoms: Fatigue, constipation, weight gain, cold intolerance, hypoglycemia, hypotension, amenorrhea, loss of pubic/axillary hair, and inability to lactate.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Hormone profile → low ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, GH.
    • MRI → empty sella or pituitary atrophy.
  • Treatment: Lifelong hormone replacement (hydrocortisone, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, GH if needed).

Explanation of other options:

Hypothyroidism (Option B): Explains fatigue and constipation, but does not cause lactational failure or amenorrhea post-delivery with a history of PPH.

Premature ovarian failure (Option C): Causes amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency, but does not cause lactational failure, adrenal insufficiency, or hypothyroidism.

Delayed blood transfusion reaction (Option D): Presents with fever, jaundice, and hemolysis after transfusion, not chronic amenorrhea and lactational failure.

Key Takeaway:

  • In a postpartum woman with a history of massive haemorrhage, followed by lactational failure and secondary amenorrhea, always suspect Sheehan syndrome (postpartum hypopituitarism).

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman has experienced headaches for the past 6 months and has been taking analgesics frequently. In the last 3 days, her headache worsened, but improvement was noted after discontinuing the analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of long-term analgesic use, worsening of headache, and relief after stopping the drugs is typical of medication overuse headache (MOH).

  • Nature of MOH:
    • A secondary headache disorder caused by frequent use of pain-relieving drugs.
    • Unlike primary headaches (migraine, tension-type, cluster), MOH develops due to drug overuse.
    • Leads to a vicious cycle: recurrent headaches → increased analgesic intake → further worsening of headaches.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Demographic: Age <50 years, female sex, low education level.
    • Comorbidities: Anxiety, depression, musculoskeletal pain, GI symptoms.
    • Lifestyle: Smoking, physical inactivity, metabolic syndrome, high caffeine (>540 mg/day).
    • Drugs involved: Aspirin, NSAIDs (ibuprofen), opioids, and tranquilizers.
  • Management:
    • Patient education: Limit acute headache drugs to ≤2 days/week.
    • Drug withdrawal:
      • Abrupt discontinuation in most cases.
      • Gradual tapering for opioids, barbiturates, benzodiazepines (2-4 weeks).
    • Preventive medications: Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, TCAs, anticonvulsants (e.g., topiramate).
    • Bridge therapy: Short-term NSAIDs (naproxen, indomethacin), tizanidine, antiemetics, or IV DHE (Raskin protocol).
    • Adjuncts: Hydration, magnesium, lidocaine infusion for withdrawal symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tension headache (Option B): Presents as a dull, bilateral, pressure-like pain often linked with stress, neck stiffness, and fatigue; not associated with analgesic overuse.

Chronic migraine (Option C): Characterized by recurrent throbbing headaches with prodromal symptoms (fatigue, neck pain, mood changes) and features like photophobia, phonophobia, osmophobia, and nausea/vomiting.

Cluster headache (Option D): Causes severe unilateral retro-orbital pain with ipsilateral symptoms (lacrimation, nasal congestion). Predominantly affects men, unlike this patient.

Key Takeaways:

  • MOH should be suspected in patients with chronic headaches who regularly use analgesics.
  • Management requires drug withdrawal, patient counseling, and preventive therapy.

References: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538150/

https://www.healthline.com/health/headache/types-of-headaches#primary-headaches

questions.text: A patient recently began antihypertensive therapy and now presents with the condition shown in the image. Which antihypertensive drug is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Considering the history and symptoms, the patient most likely has angioedema, a known adverse effect of lisinopril, an ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitor.

Angioedema is characterised by swelling of the lips, face, tongue, throat, and sometimes the limbs. Though uncommon, it is a potentially serious allergic reaction that needs urgent medical care.

Management includes the use of antihistamines and corticosteroids, while subcutaneous epinephrine may be administered in cases involving laryngospasm.

Explanations of other options:

Nifedipine (Option B): Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, lowers blood pressure by blocking calcium entry into arterial smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilation. Common side effects include headache, flushing, and dizziness.

Atenolol (Option C): Atenolol, a selective beta-1 blocker, decreases the action of catecholamines on the heart, leading to reduced heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output. Side effects may include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities.

Clonidine (Option D): Clonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, works centrally by suppressing norepinephrine release at nerve terminals and decreasing sympathetic activity from the CNS. Its side effects include bradycardia and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is contraindicated in a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis who is being treated with metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When taken with alcohol, metronidazole can trigger a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache, and even psychosis.

Explanations of other options:

Grapefruit Juice (Option A): Grapefruit juice has no interaction with metronidazole and can be safely consumed at the same time.

Benzodiazepines (Option C): Benzodiazepines are prescribed for anxiety, insomnia, and various psychiatric disorders, and they do not have any notable interactions with metronidazole.

MAO/SSRI (Option D): These are antidepressant medications, and no significant interactions have been identified between them and metronidazole.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a fever and massive splenomegaly. The spleen was 15 cm on palpation and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The phrenicocolic ligament is a peritoneal fold extending from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm.

  • It acts as a shelf supporting the spleen from below.
  • By this positioning, it prevents vertical and downward displacement of the spleen into the left lower quadrant.
  • This anatomical support becomes especially relevant in massive splenomegaly, where the spleen enlarges but is restricted from descending further by this ligament.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Lienorenal ligament (Option A):

  • Also called the splenorenal ligament.
  • Connects the spleen to the left kidney.
  • Contains the splenic vessels and tail of the pancreas.
  • Provides posterior support to the spleen but does not prevent its downward descent.

Gastrosplenic ligament (Option B):

  • Connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen.
  • Contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery.
  • Provides anteromedial stabilization, but does not limit vertical descent.

Lienophrenic ligament (Option D):

  • Also known as the splenophrenic ligament.
  • Connects the spleen to the diaphragm superiorly.
  • Provides upward support, thus preventing upward displacement of the spleen, not downward movement.

Reference:

  1. [The ligament system of the spleen and its significance for surgical interventions] - PubMed
  2. Splenic Anomalies of Shape, Size, and Location: Pictorial Essay - PMC

questions.text: You are conducting an experiment on mitochondrial respiration. When malate/pyruvate is added, respiration proceeds normally. When succinate is added, respiration is also normal. However, upon adding another substance in the presence of pyruvate/succinate and malate, respiration is completely blocked. Which of the following substances was most likely added?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The experiment tests inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC).
  • The ETC consists of five protein complexes (I-V) located in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • Complexes I-IV are involved in electron transport and proton pumping, while Complex V (ATP synthase) is responsible for ATP production.
  • Oligomycin binds to ATP synthase (Complex V) and blocks its proton channel, thereby preventing protons from re-entering the mitochondrial matrix. This halts ATP synthesis and effectively stops respiration in the presence of substrates.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rotenone (Option A): Inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase), preventing electron transfer to ubiquinone. However, respiration would still occur when succinate (Complex II substrate) is provided.

Antimycin A (Option B): Inhibits Complex III (cytochrome bc1), blocking transfer from ubiquinone to cytochrome c. This would stop respiration regardless of substrate, but the clinical scenario points toward ATP synthase inhibition, not Complex III.

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D): Acts as an uncoupling agent. It dissipates the proton gradient, allowing electron transport to continue but without ATP synthesis. Respiration would actually increase, not be completely blocked

questions.text: A militant presents with fever and a rash that began on the trunk and spread to the extremities, sparing palms and soles. On examination, a louse is noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described presentation is typical of epidemic typhus, a severe louse-borne rickettsial disease caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The combination of fever, truncal rash (centrifugal spread sparing palms and soles), and the presence of a louse in a high-risk individual (militant in crowded conditions) is diagnostic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rickettsia akari (Option A): Causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by rodent mites. Characterized by an eschar at the bite site followed by fever and a vesicular rash that spares palms and soles.

Rickettsia conorii (Option B): Causes Indian tick typhus (Mediterranean spotted fever), transmitted by ticks. Rash typically begins on extremities, spreads to trunk, and may involve palms and soles; eschar may be present.

Rickettsia typhi (Option D): Causes endemic (murine) typhus, transmitted by rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis). Similar to epidemic typhus clinically but milder, and does not occur as epidemics.

Key Takeaway:

Eschar-producing organisms include:

  • Bacillus anthracis (cutaneous anthrax)
  • Rickettsia akari (rickettsialpox)
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Rickettsia conorii (Indian tick typhus, Mediterranean spotted fever)
  • Rickettsia africae (African tick bite fever)

questions.text: What is a drug called Mitomycin-C used for in medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mitomycin-C is an antineoplastic antibiotic that works by cross-linking DNA and inhibiting cell replication.
  • It is applied topically to surgical sites to prevent fibroblast proliferation and reduce scar formation.
  • It is particularly useful in subglottic stenosis, where it is applied after airway dilation or surgical excision of fibrotic tissue.
  • Its antifibrotic property decreases the risk of restenosis and improves the long-term outcome of airway surgery.
  • Mitomycin-C has been widely investigated as an adjunct in procedures where excessive scarring can cause recurrence of disease, and in airway surgery, it helps preserve airway patency.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rhino cerebral mucormycosis (Option B): This is a life-threatening fungal infection that requires amphotericin B as the drug of choice along with aggressive surgical debridement. Mitomycin-C has no role here.

Adenoidectomy (Option C): A routine surgical removal of hypertrophied adenoid tissue. The procedure does not involve the use of antifibrotic agents like Mitomycin-C, as scarring in the nasopharynx is not a concern.

Tympanoplasty (Option D): A surgical repair of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain. Mitomycin-C has no role in this procedure since fibrosis prevention is not a therapeutic goal.

Key Takeaway:

Mitomycin-C, though originally an anticancer drug, is used topically in ENT surgery for its antifibrotic effect. Its most notable role is in the management of subglottic stenosis, where it prevents restenosis by inhibiting fibroblast proliferation.

questions.text: A patient from the Mediterranean region travels to Africa and develops malaria. After receiving primaquine, the patient subsequently develops hemolytic anemia. Which pathway deficiency in the enzyme could potentially be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The pathway deficiency responsible is the Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP pathway) and enzyme deficiency is G6PD.

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also called the Pentose Phosphate Pathway, is critical for generating NADPH in red blood cells.

  • NADPH keeps glutathione in its reduced form, which protects RBCs from oxidative injury caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • The key enzyme is Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD), which is both the first and the rate-limiting step of the pathway.
  • Drugs such as primaquine produce oxidative stress by increasing ROS formation.
  • In patients with G6PD deficiency, there is insufficient NADPH, leading to depletion of reduced glutathione. This results in:
    • Oxidative damage to hemoglobin → Heinz body formation
    • Membrane injury → intravascular hemolysis
  • Hence, G6PD deficiency (HMP pathway defect) is the underlying cause of hemolytic anemia after primaquine administration.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Glycolysis (Option A):

  • This pathway provides ATP for red blood cell metabolism.
  • Enzyme defects here (e.g., pyruvate kinase deficiency) can cause chronic hemolysis, but they are not linked to oxidative stress or drug-induced hemolysis.

Gluconeogenesis (Option B):

  • A metabolic pathway occurring mainly in the liver and kidneys for glucose production.
  • RBCs lack mitochondria and cannot perform gluconeogenesis.
  • Thus, it has no role in protecting RBCs against oxidative stress.

Luebering-Rapoport pathway (Option D):

  • A glycolytic bypass unique to RBCs that produces 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG).
  • 2,3-BPG regulates oxygen release from hemoglobin.
  • This pathway does not provide NADPH and is unrelated to oxidative injury.

Reference: HMP pathway

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting with pharyngitis, when a throat swab is collected and sent for culture, in which colored bin should the used swab be disposed of?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Biomedical waste disposal follows a color-coded segregation system to minimize infection risk, protect healthcare workers, and ensure safe disposal.

A throat swab used for culture is considered infectious waste because it comes in contact with body fluids and may harbor pathogens until culture proves otherwise. Therefore, it must be discarded in the yellow bin, which is specifically designated for potentially infectious clinical waste.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old student in school?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India, children at 10 years of age are given a Td (Tetanus + reduced diphtheria toxoid) booster. This booster helps maintain immunity developed during infancy and early childhood and ensures continued protection into adolescence.

Earlier, TT (Tetanus toxoid alone) was administered, but now Td has replaced TT to provide dual protection (against both tetanus and diphtheria) while reducing the reactogenicity of high-dose diphtheria toxoid found in DPT.

National Immunization Schedule:

Reference:

  1. https://www.pmc.gov.in/en/NIS-for-Infants-Children-and-Pregnant-Women
  2. https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/41016395871489662752.pdf

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presents with sudden-onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray reveals unilateral hyperinflation of the lung. Which of the following statements is true for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute dyspnea in a previously healthy child with unilateral lung hyperinflation on X-ray strongly suggests foreign body aspiration.
  • Auscultation typically shows focal reduction in air entry, which is diagnostic in such cases.

Lower Airway Foreign Body Aspiration - Key Points:

  • Epidemiology:
    • Choking is a leading cause of morbidity/mortality in children <4 years.
    • Most common in toddlers and older infants.
  • Common Aspirated Objects:
    • Food: nuts, seeds, candies, raw fruits/vegetables.
    • Inorganic: coins, pins, balloons, toy parts, magnets.
  • Location: Most often in bronchus > trachea > larynx.
  • Types of Obstruction:
    • Partial obstruction: Ball-valve mechanism → localized hyperinflation due to air trapping.
    • Complete obstruction: Leads to distal atelectasis, infection, bronchiectasis.
  • Clinical Course:
    • Initial event: coughing, choking, gagging; sometimes spontaneous expulsion.
    • Asymptomatic interval: misleading lull period with lodged foreign body.
    • Later: recurrent cough, fever, hemoptysis, pneumonia, atelectasis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • History of choking event is crucial.
    • Plain X-ray may miss radiolucent objects (80-96%).
    • Expiratory X-ray: asymmetric hyperinflation, air trapping.
    • CT chest: high sensitivity but radiation exposure.
    • Bronchoscopy: definitive diagnostic and therapeutic tool.
  • Treatment:
    • Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for removal.
    • Antibiotics if secondary infection develops.

Explanation of Other Options:

Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal (Option B): Flexible bronchoscopy is useful for diagnosis but is not the procedure of choice for removal. Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for safe and effective extraction of the foreign body.

In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation (Option C): Hyperinflation occurs in partial obstruction due to the ball-valve effect, where air enters during inspiration but cannot exit during expiration. Complete obstruction instead leads to atelectasis and collapse of the distal lung.

The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Option D): Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) is a viral illness, often caused by parainfluenza virus, presenting with barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. X-ray shows the "steeple sign" from subglottic narrowing, not unilateral hyperinflation, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Key Takeaways:

  • Unilateral hyperinflation in a child = foreign body aspiration until proven otherwise.
  • Auscultation with focal decreased air entry is a diagnostic clue.
  • Rigid bronchoscopy remains the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A woman during her routine examination presents with the following Xray finding. What is her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows multiple benign cartilaginous growths arising in small bones of the hand, consistent with enchondromas.
  • When enchondromas occur in multiple sites, the condition is called multiple enchondromatosis.
  • If lesions are unilateral, it is known as Ollier's disease; if associated with soft tissue haemangiomas, it is called Maffucci syndrome.

  • These are benign tumours of hyaline cartilage, usually diagnosed in childhood, and most frequently involve the phalanges and metacarpals.

Multiple enchondromatosis:

  • Clinical features: Asymmetric limb shortening, finger swelling, impaired joint movement, pathological fractures.
  • Course: Tumours usually stop developing after puberty; growth in adulthood may suggest malignant transformation.
  • Malignant potential: 20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma, especially if lesions enlarge after puberty.
  • Treatment: Observation for stable lesions; surgery if deformity, fractures, or malignancy suspected.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Multiple brown tumour (Option A): Seen in hyperparathyroidism due to excessive osteoclastic activity. X-rays show osteolytic lesions with fibrous tissue and haemorrhagic areas, not enchondromas.
  • Fibrous dysplasia (Option B): Appears as a ground-glass/smudged radiographic lesion, not discrete cartilaginous tumours. It results from replacement of normal bone with fibro-osseous tissue.
  • Multiple exostoses (Option D): Also known as hereditary multiple osteochondromas, these appear as bony outgrowths (exostoses) projecting from the bone surface, not intramedullary cartilage tumours as seen in enchondromas.

Key Takeaway:

Multiple enchondromas, often seen in Ollier's disease or Maffucci syndrome, present as benign cartilaginous tumours of small bones. They carry a significant risk of malignant transformation into chondrosarcoma, warranting lifelong follow-up.

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image.
questions.solution:
The wound pattern depicted in the image is consistent with a defense wound, sustained when the victim instinctively attempts to ward off an attack.

  • These injuries typically occur when the victim tries to grasp or block the weapon.
  • Common sites: palms, fingers, forearms, wrists, and backs of hands.
  • A double-edged weapon can cause cuts on both the palm and fingers, while a single-edged weapon usually produces a solitary cut.
  • A characteristic defense wound is often located between the base of the thumb and index finger.

Classification of defense wounds:

  1. Active defense wounds - occur when the victim actively tries to seize or grab the weapon.
    1. Injuries: Irregular, ragged cuts due to loosening of skin tension while gripping; fractures of metacarpals, digits, or carpal bones.
  2. Passive defense wounds - result when the victim raises arms or legs to block the blow.
    1. Sites: Extensor surfaces of forearms, wrists, back of hands, knuckles, posterior lower limbs, or back. Rarely on shin/feet.
    2. Injuries: Fractures of the carpal bones, metacarpals, and digits (mostly blunt trauma).

Medicolegal importance:

  • Presence of defense wounds is a strong indicator of homicide.
  • They may be absent if the victim was:
    • Unconscious,
    • Attacked from behind,
    • Taken by surprise,
    • Or under the influence of drugs/alcohol.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Antemortem wound (Option B):

  • These injuries occur during life and show vital reactions: bleeding, tissue bridging, clot formation, inflammatory changes, or healing.

Postmortem wound (Option C):

  • Inflicted after death, hence vital reactions are absent.
  • Appear with clean, dry edges, no bleeding, no inflammation, and no tissue infiltration.

Hesitation cuts (Option D):
