  • Also called tentative cuts or trial wounds.
  • Consist of multiple superficial cuts, typically preceding a deeper incised wound.
  • Common in suicidal attempts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male reports weakness that worsens by evening and improves with rest. He also complains of drooping eyelids, difficulty speaking, and problems with swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation of fatigable weakness that improves with rest, along with ptosis and bulbar symptoms (speech and swallowing difficulty), is most characteristic of myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Fatigability: Muscle strength declines with repeated use, typically more severe in the evening or after exertion.
  • No sensory/CNS signs: Pure motor involvement helps differentiate from other neuromuscular disorders.
  • Common initial features:
    • Ptosis
    • Diplopia
  • Progression of weakness:
    • Bulbar muscles → chewing, swallowing, speaking difficulty
    • Limb muscles → proximal limb weakness
    • Respiratory muscles → can result in respiratory failure and aspiration; ventilatory support may be required.
  • Characteristic sign:
    • Cogan's lid twitch - brief upward overshoot of the eyelid after sustained downward gaze.

Explanation of other options:

Lambert-Eaton syndrome (Option B): Presents with proximal muscle weakness and autonomic symptoms (dry mouth, constipation). Unlike myasthenia gravis, weakness improves with activity.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option C): X-linked disorder with early childhood onset, progressive weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, gait abnormalities, and intellectual disability. Weakness does not improve with rest.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): A multisystem autoimmune disease presenting with malar rash, arthritis (≥2 joints with synovitis), and systemic features, not isolated neuromuscular fatigability.

Key Takeaways:

  • Myasthenia gravis = fatigable motor weakness that improves with rest.
  • Ocular and bulbar symptoms are common early features.
  • Differentiated from Lambert-Eaton by worsening with activity.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482346/

choices.text: Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. The fundus image of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct option is Hard exudate, diabetes mellitus.
  • The image displays bright, yellowish, and well-defined deposits, which are characteristic of hard exudates.
  • These deposits consist of lipids and proteins that leak from damaged retinal capillaries.
  • In the macula, these exudates can form a star-shaped pattern.
  • The most common cause of hard exudates is diabetic retinopathy, a complication of diabetes mellitus. While they can also be found in hypertensive retinopathy, their appearance and the specific pattern in the macula are most frequently associated with diabetes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Soft exudate, hypertension (Option A): Soft exudates, also known as cotton-wool spots, are cloudy, ill-defined, whitish patches, not the bright yellow, well-defined deposits seen in the image.

Flame-shaped hemorrhages, hypertension (Option C): Flame-shaped hemorrhages are red and represent bleeding from retinal vessels, which appear different from the yellow exudates in the image.

Soft exudate, central retinal vein occlusion (Option D): Soft exudates are caused by ischemia and axonal swelling, and although they can be seen in central retinal vein occlusion, they are not the primary finding shown in the image, which depicts hard exudates.

Key Takeaway:

Hard exudates are bright yellow, well-defined lipid deposits that form due to fluid leakage from damaged blood vessels, most caused by diabetic retinopathy. They are distinct from other findings like soft exudates and haemorrhages.

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied with Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, Cl: 4 mEq/L. Identify the compartment from which the fluid has been obtained.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Very low Na+ (~10 mEq/L) and very high K+ (~140 mEq/L) are hallmark intracellular values.
  • Chloride is minimal (~4 mEq/L) inside cells, further supporting an intracellular origin.
    Together, this triad (low Na+, high K+, low Cl-) is classic for intracellular fluid (ICF), contrasting with extracellular compartments where Na+ is high and K+ is low.

Electrolyte Composition in Different Fluid Compartments


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Interstitial (Option A): Interstitial fluid mirrors extracellular composition-high Na+, low K+, and higher Cl--not the low Na+/high K+/very low Cl- pattern seen here.

Extracellular fluid (Option C): By definition (plasma + interstitial), ECF is Na+-rich and K+-poor; these values are the opposite.

Plasma (Option D): A subtype of ECF with high Na+ and low K+ plus substantial proteins; the sample's electrolytes clearly do not fit plasma chemistry.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3414807/

questions.text: Which of the following medications is least likely to induce pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metformin, a biguanide antidiabetic drug that lowers hepatic glucose production and enhances insulin sensitivity, is not linked to pulmonary fibrosis.

Explanations of other options:

Methysergide (Option B): Methysergide, a serotonin receptor blocker once used to manage migraines and cluster headaches, is associated with pulmonary fibrosis, particularly when taken long-term.

Bleomycin (Option C): Bleomycin, an anticancer drug used in the treatment of testicular tumors, lymphomas, and head and neck malignancies, is well known for causing pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect.

Nitrofurantoin (Option D): Nitrofurantoin, an antibiotic mainly prescribed for urinary tract infections, carries a risk of pulmonary fibrosis, particularly with long-term use.

Key takeaway:

Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease marked by scarring and thickening of lung tissue, which impairs lung function and causes breathing difficulties.

Clinical features: gradually worsening shortness of breath, tiredness, dry cough, fine crackles, and digital clubbing.

Radiology: shows peripheral reticular markings with traction bronchiectasis, and in advanced stages, may reveal a "honeycomb" lung pattern.

  • Histology: Features of usual interstitial pneumonia are seen

Medications known to induce pulmonary fibrosis include:

  • Methotrexate
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Carmustine
  • Bleomycin
  • Busulfan
  • Amiodarone
  • Methysergide

questions.text: A woman with hysteria develops hyperventilation and subsequently presents with carpopedal spasms. What is the most likely underlying acid-base abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The patient's hyperventilation causes excessive CO₂ washout, resulting in respiratory alkalosis.
  • Reduced CO₂ leads to increased blood pH (alkalemia).
  • Alkalosis decreases ionized calcium levels, which increases neuromuscular excitability, producing tetany and carpopedal spasms.

Clinical features of respiratory alkalosis:

  • Neurological: Dizziness, confusion, circumoral numbness, paresthesias, seizures (severe cases).
  • Cardiovascular: Palpitations, arrhythmias, chest tightness, ECG changes.
  • Neuromuscular: Tetany, muscle twitching, weakness, carpopedal spasms.
  • Laboratory findings: ↑ pH, ↓ PaCO₂, ↓ ionized calcium, ↓ K⁺, ↓ PO₄.

Management:

  • Treat underlying cause.
  • Reassure and address anxiety.
  • Rebreathing techniques (paper bag if required).
  • β-blockers for symptomatic patients.
  • Careful monitoring during mechanical ventilation.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A): Caused by hypoventilation due to pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle weakness, or drug-induced depression of ventilation. Presents with ↑ PaCO₂, not hyperventilation.

Metabolic acidosis (Option B): Occurs in renal failure, diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, or toxin ingestion (methanol, ethylene glycol). Characterized by ↓ HCO₃⁻, not seen in this patient.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D): Associated with excessive bicarbonate intake, vomiting, diuretic use, hypokalemia, or mineralocorticoid excess. Not related to hyperventilation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hyperventilation → ↓ CO₂ → Respiratory alkalosis.
  • Low ionized calcium due to alkalosis causes tetany/carpopedal spasms.

questions.text: The average life expectancy for a woman in Japan is 87 years. Due to recent advances in cervical cancer testing, life expectancy increases by 15 years. The healthcare utility value is 0.8. Which of the following can be calculated from the data provided?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • The parameter set in the question includes additional life years gained and a utility value, which directly relates to the calculation of Quality-Adjusted Life Years (QALYs).
  • Formula: QALY = Additional Life Years × Utility Value
  • Additional life expectancy = 15 years
  • Utility value = 0.8
  • QALY = 15 × 0.8 = 12 QALYs.

Thus, the correct measure that can be calculated is QALY.

Explanation of Other Options:

HALE (Health-Adjusted Life Expectancy) (option A): HALE accounts for the average number of years lived in full health, by adjusting overall life expectancy for years spent in ill-health. To calculate HALE, population morbidity data are required, which are not provided here.

DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Year) (option B): DALY measures the burden of disease, combining:

DALY = Years of life lost (YLL) + Years lived with disability (YLD).

No data about premature mortality (YLL) or disability (YLD) are given, so DALY cannot be derived.

DFLE (Disability-Free Life Expectancy) (option C): DFLE estimates the number of remaining years lived without disability. Since no information about the presence or absence of disability is available, DFLE cannot be calculated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. Which enrichment medium is used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's clinical presentation of bloody diarrhea with fever suggests enteroinvasive pathogens such as Salmonella or Shigella.

  • Selenite F broth is a selective enrichment medium designed for isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species from fecal specimens.
  • It contains selenite which inhibits coliform bacteria and other gut commensals, while allowing Salmonella and Shigella to grow.
  • This is particularly important because stool contains a large number of normal gut flora that would otherwise overgrow and mask the pathogenic bacteria.

Principle of Enrichment Media:

  • Enrichment broths are liquid media containing inhibitory substances that suppress the growth of unwanted commensals while selectively enhancing the growth of suspected pathogens.
  • These are especially useful in specimens with heavy contamination by normal flora such as stool and sputum.

Examples of Enrichment Media:

  • Selenite F broth → for Salmonella & Shigella.
  • Tetrathionate broth → used for Salmonella Typhi.
  • Gram-negative broth → used for Shigella.
  • Alkaline peptone water (APW) → for Vibrio cholerae.
  • Lim broth → for Group B Streptococcus from genital specimens.

Explanation of Other Options:

Robertson cooked meat broth (Option A): It is a general-purpose enrichment and maintenance medium used for anaerobic bacteria such as Clostridium spp. It is not selective for Salmonella or Shigella and not useful for stool culture.

Alkaline peptone water (Option B): It is a selective enrichment medium with high pH that favors growth of Vibrio spp., especially V. cholerae, the causative agent of cholera (which typically causes profuse watery diarrhea, not bloody stools).

Brain heart infusion broth (Option D): It is a nutrient-rich, non-selective medium supporting growth of many organisms, including bacteria and fungi. It is used for blood cultures, cerebrospinal fluid, and other sterile body fluids, but not appropriate for enteric pathogens in stool.

questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The optic chiasma is positioned just above the anterior communicating artery (AComA) in the suprasellar cistern.

  • AComA aneurysms are the most common intracranial aneurysms.
  • These aneurysms can compress the optic chiasma, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes).
  • Clinical presentation may include vision loss, headache, and if ruptured, subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Anterior choroidal artery (Option B):

  • Branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • Supplies the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of internal capsule.
  • Aneurysms are rare and usually cause contralateral motor deficits, not compression of the optic chiasma.

Middle cerebral artery (Option C):

  • Does not run close to the optic chiasma.
  • MCA aneurysms typically affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (Option D):

  • Courses superior to the optic chiasma.
  • ACA aneurysms generally do not compress the chiasma directly.
  • ACA infarcts are classically associated with contralateral leg weakness due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

Reference: 

Anterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm Related to Visual Symptoms - PMC

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma, with a strong family history suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma (HNPCC / Lynch syndrome). Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC), also called Lynch syndrome, is caused by defects in mismatch repair (MMR) genes.
  • MMR normally corrects base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops during DNA replication.
  • Mutations in hMSH2 and hMLH1 (located on chromosome 2) are the most common genetic defects in Lynch syndrome.
  • Failure of mismatch repair results in microsatellite instability, increasing the risk of colorectal cancer and extracolonic malignancies (endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Nucleotide excision repair (Option B):
    • Removes bulky DNA adducts such as thymine dimers caused by UV light.
    • Defects cause Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), Cockayne syndrome, and Trichothiodystrophy (TTD).
    • Not linked to hereditary colorectal cancers.
  • Base excision repair (Option C):
    • Fixes small, non-helix-distorting base lesions such as oxidative DNA damage, alkylation, or deamination.
    • Defects associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP), as well as neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's).
    • Not the mechanism in HNPCC.
  • Point mutation (Option D):
    • Refers to a single nucleotide change (e.g., missense, nonsense mutations).
    • While point mutations can cause various cancers, HNPCC is specifically linked to mismatch repair deficiency, not a general point mutation defect

Key Takeaway:


Reference: Hereditary cancer syndromes

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the occurrence when a therapist experiences a combination of conscious and unconscious emotions towards their patient during psychotherapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Countertransference is the phenomenon where a therapist projects their own conscious and unconscious feelings onto a patient during psychotherapy.
  • These responses are shaped by the therapist's personal history, unresolved conflicts, and emotional patterns, often treating the patient as though they were a significant figure from the therapist's past.
  • This can interfere with therapy by creating biased, exaggerated, or diminished emotional reactions, which may affect objectivity.
  • Effective management requires supervision, training, and self-awareness, enabling therapists to recognize and address these reactions without letting them harm the therapeutic process.

Transference vs Countertransference:

  • Transference: The patient redirects unconscious feelings and emotions from past relationships (such as parental or significant others) toward the therapist.
  • Countertransference: The therapist's feelings toward the patient, shaped by their own internal experiences.
  • Both are largely unconscious processes and can be positive or negative.
  • When unrecognized, they can interfere with the therapeutic alliance and treatment outcomes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transference (Option B): Refers to the patient's unconscious redirection of emotions toward the therapist, not the therapist's emotions toward the patient.

Dissociation (Option C): A defense mechanism where a person separates from thoughts, feelings, or experiences, often in response to trauma. It does not involve the therapist-patient dynamic.

Preoccupation (Option D): Persistent focus or fixation on specific thoughts or feelings that interfere with functioning. This is not the term for therapist emotions toward patients.

Key Takeaway:

Countertransference describes the therapist's emotional responses (both conscious and unconscious) to the patient, while transference refers to the patient's emotions toward the therapist. Recognizing these processes is essential for maintaining effective, unbiased psychotherapy.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
• Superfecundation is the fertilization of two or more ova released in the same menstrual cycle from separate acts of coitus, which may involve different partners.
  • In this case, twins were born but DNA analysis showed different paternity for one of the children.
  • This clearly indicates heteropaternal superfecundation, where two ova were fertilized by sperm from different men within the same cycle.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Superfetation (Option A):

  • Refers to conception occurring during an ongoing pregnancy (different cycles).
  • Leads to fetuses of unequal gestational ages.
  • Does not explain this case, since the twins are of the same gestational age but different paternity.

Suppositious Child (Option C):

  • A child that is fraudulently substituted or falsely claimed as one's own.
  • This is a matter of misrepresentation, not biology.

Atavism (Option D):

  • The reappearance of ancestral traits after skipping generations (e.g., a child with a tail-like appendage).
  • Has no connection with paternity or multiple fertilizations.

Key Takeaway:

  • Superfecundation → Fertilization of different ova in the same cycle by separate acts of intercourse.
  • Superfetation → Fertilization of an ovum released in a different menstrual cycle, leading to embryos of different gestational ages.
  • Considered extremely rare since after ~12 weeks, the decidual reaction usually prevents further implantation

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image used for patients with COVID-19 infection.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is commonly used in COVID-19 patients who require high concentrations of oxygen while minimizing aerosol spread.
  • It delivers 60-90% oxygen through a reservoir bag and one-way valves that prevent rebreathing of exhaled gases.
  • By limiting re-inhalation of carbon dioxide and reducing aerosol dispersion, it becomes especially suitable in infectious respiratory illnesses such as COVID-19.

Non-rebreathing mask:

  • Components: Face mask, reservoir bag, one-way valves.
  • Oxygen delivery range: 10-15 L/min flow rate.
  • Indications: Severe hypoxemia, acute respiratory distress, and pre-oxygenation prior to intubation.
  • Advantages: Provides high FiO₂, prevents rebreathing, and reduces aerosol generation compared to nebulizers.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Venturi mask (Option A): Provides a fixed oxygen concentration (24-50%) and is typically used in COPD patients who require controlled FiO₂ to avoid CO₂ retention. It is not suitable for severe COVID-19 hypoxemia requiring high-flow oxygen.

Hudson mask (Option B): A simple face mask that delivers 40-60% oxygen but lacks a reservoir bag. It cannot deliver as high FiO₂ as NRBM and offers less protection against aerosol spread.

Nebulizer (Option C): Used for aerosolized drug delivery. In COVID-19 patients, nebulizers increase the risk of aerosol generation and viral transmission, making them unsafe for oxygen therapy in this setting.

Key Takeaway:

For COVID-19 patients with significant oxygen demand, the non-rebreathing mask is the preferred choice because it delivers a high concentration of oxygen while minimizing the risk of aerosol generation.

questions.text: A little boy was playing in a garden. Suddenly, he collapsed and was rushed to the hospital. His friend who played with him in the garden informed the doctors that he ate one of the fruits in the garden post which he seemed to have developed these symptoms. He also had irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote.
questions.solution:
• The child's presentation (irritability, restlessness, flushed dry hot skin, urinary retention, constipation, dilated pupils, delirium) is typical of anticholinergic toxicity, caused by Datura
  • Datura contains toxic alkaloids such as hyoscyamine, hyoscine (scopolamine), and traces of atropine.
  • Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is the antidote. It increases acetylcholine levels, thereby counteracting the muscarinic blockade caused by Datura alkaloids.
  • Dose: 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeated as necessary.

Clinical features of Datura poisoning:

  • Dry mouth & throat, dysphagia, difficulty speaking
  • Flushed face, dilated pupils, photophobia, diplopia
  • Delirium, restlessness, hallucinations
  • Hot, dry skin ("red as a beet, dry as a bone, mad as a hatter, blind as a bat, hot as a hare")
  • Urinary retention & constipation
  • Severe cases → coma, respiratory paralysis, death

Treatment:

  • Decontamination: activated charcoal, cathartics
  • Antidote: Physostigmine
  • Supportive care: maintain airway, control agitation, monitor vitals

Explanation of Incorrect Options

  • Datura, Pralidoxime (Option A):
    • Pralidoxime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning, where it reactivates acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates.
    • It has no role in anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.
  • Yellow oleander, Digoxin (Option C):
    • Yellow oleander (Thevetia peruviana) poisoning produces cardiac glycoside toxicity with arrhythmias and conduction abnormalities.
    • Treatment involves digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digibind), not digoxin itself (digoxin is a drug, not an antidote).
  • Yellow oleander, Physostigmine (Option D):
    • Although Physostigmine counters anticholinergic symptoms, it is not effective in cardiac glycoside poisoning.
    • Yellow oleander toxicity is treated with Digibind and supportive care, not Physostigmine.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 5-year-old child who visited the pediatrician due to bilateral knee joint pain, normal bone mineral density, and the provided X-ray image of the joints?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's presentation of knee pain, normal bone mineral density, and classic X-ray findings points toward scurvy, a disorder caused by vitamin C deficiency.
  • The hallmark radiological finding is the white line of Frankel at the metaphysis, representing abnormal calcification.
  • Other supportive signs include Trümmerfeld zone, Pelkan spurs, Weinberger's ring, and subperiosteal fractures.
  • The presence of these radiological markers in the setting of bone pain strongly favors scurvy over rickets or genetic bone dysplasias.

X-ray findings of scurvy:

  • White Line of Frankel: Dense zone of provisional calcification at the metaphysis.
  • Trümmerfeld zone: Lucent band beneath Frankel line due to defective bone formation.
  • Pelkan Spurs: Beak-like metaphyseal outgrowths.
  • Weinberger's Ring: Ring sign around epiphysis.
  • Ground-glass appearance of bone.
  • Subperiosteal hemorrhage and fractures are common.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rickets (Option B): Caused by vitamin D deficiency. X-ray shows cupping, fraying, and widening of metaphyses, rachitic rosary, and bowing of long bones. Unlike scurvy, bone mineral density is decreased.

Metaphyseal dysplasia (Option C): Genetic disorder affecting metaphyseal bone growth. Radiology shows irregular, sclerotic, fragmented metaphyses, not Frankel's line or Pelkan spurs. Usually presents with growth disturbances.

Pycnodysostosis (Option D): Rare genetic disorder due to defective osteoclast function. X-rays show generalized osteosclerosis, thick cortices, and short stubby fingers. Normal or increased bone density, not the characteristic scurvy lines.

Key Takeaway:

Scurvy should be suspected in children with bone pain, normal bone mineral density, and X-ray findings of Frankel line, Trümmerfeld zone, Pelkan spurs, and subperiosteal hemorrhage. It is due to vitamin C deficiency and responds well to supplementation.

questions.text: A 12-week-old infant presents with fever, cyanosis, and fatigue. A chest X-ray is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The chest X-ray demonstrates the classic "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign, which is most often associated with the supracardiac type of TAPVC.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathophysiology:

  • In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not drain into the left atrium. Instead, they connect abnormally to the right atrium, either directly or through systemic veins.
  • TAPVC is not dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus for survival.

Common Sites of Abnormal Venous Drainage:

  • Supracardiac (most frequent): via the superior vena cava
  • Cardiac type: through the right atrium or coronary sinus
  • Infracardiac type
  • Mixed type

Clinical Presentation:

  • Cyanosis combined with signs of heart failure
  • Presence of an ASD leads to a wide, fixed split of the second heart sound

Chest X-ray Findings:

  • Supracardiac TAPVC produces the "snowman" or "figure-of-8" appearance

Management:

  • Definitive treatment is surgical repair
  • Prostaglandins are not used, since this lesion is not ductal-dependent

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Chest X-ray typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option C): Characterized radiographically by an "egg-on-a-string" sign.

Pericardial Effusion (Option D): Produces a globular or "water bottle" shaped cardiac silhouette.

Key Takeaway:

In a cyanotic infant with heart failure and a chest X-ray showing a snowman/figure-8 sign, think of supracardiac TAPVC. Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Reference:

Partial and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.text: What type of consent is obtained when a patient agrees to a procedure after being informed about its benefits and complications?
questions.solution:
Informed consent is the process in which a patient is given complete information about a medical procedure-including its purpose, benefits, risks, complications, and possible alternatives-and then voluntarily agrees to undergo the procedure after fully understanding this information.

It is a fundamental principle in both medical ethics and legal practice. The patient retains the right to either accept or refuse the proposed intervention.

Key aspects:

  • The patient must be made aware of the diagnosis/condition.
  • The treatment/procedure and its expected outcomes must be explained.
  • Risks, benefits, and alternatives should be clearly discussed.
  • The patient must have the opportunity to ask questions and make a free, voluntary decision.

While consent generally means voluntary permission (expressed or implied), informed consent is required for all significant procedures unless exceptions apply.

Exceptions to informed consent include:

  • Emergencies
  • Therapeutic privilege (when disclosure may cause more harm than benefit)
  • Therapeutic waiver (when patient defers decision-making to the doctor)
  • Medico-legal postmortems
  • Psychiatric examination/treatment ordered by court
  • Police-ordered medical examination of arrested individuals (Sec 51 & 52 BNSS)
  • Treatment of notifiable diseases for the interest of public health

Substituted consent (Proxy consent):

  • If a patient is unable to provide informed consent (e.g., unconscious), consent must be obtained from a close relative in a priority order:
    • Spouse → Adult child → Parent → Sibling.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Implied consent (Option B):

  • Consent inferred from a patient's actions or behavior, not explicitly stated.
  • Example: visiting a hospital for illness implies consent for general physical examination.
  • This form of consent is legally valid, but not sufficient for invasive or high-risk procedures.

Opt-out / Presumed consent (Option C):

  • Commonly used in organ donation laws.
  • Assumes consent unless the patient has specifically refused.
  • Not applicable to routine medical or surgical procedures.

Passive consent (Option D):

  • Not formally recognized in medical ethics.
  • Implies lack of objection rather than active agreement.
  • Insufficient for significant medical procedures.

Reference: Informed Consent - StatPearls

questions.text: A child presents with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and knee joint pain. Urine examination shows hematuria and proteinuria, while laboratory investigations reveal normal platelet counts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and renal involvement with normal platelet counts is typical of Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP):

  • A systemic small-vessel vasculitis, mainly seen in children.
  • Clinical triad: palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and arthritis/arthralgia.
  • Renal involvement is common, presenting as hematuria and proteinuria.
  • Preceding upper respiratory tract infection is often noted.

Etiology

  • More frequent in males.
  • Exact cause unknown.
  • Immune-mediated small-vessel vasculitis, often post-upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition (e.g., HLA-B34, DRB1) in some cases.

Pathophysiology

  • Inflammation of capillaries in skin, joints, intestines, kidneys.
  • Immune complex deposition (IgA dominant).
  • Leakage of fluid and RBCs into tissues.
  • Triggered by infections or immune dysregulation.

Clinical Features

  • Palpable purpura: purplish-red, raised lesions over buttocks and legs.
  • Arthritis/arthralgia: knee and ankle involvement common.
  • Abdominal pain: colicky, may be associated with vomiting, diarrhea, GI bleeding, or intussusception.
  • Renal manifestations: hematuria, proteinuria, occasionally chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical: palpable purpura + ≥1 of: abdominal pain, arthritis/arthralgia, biopsy-proven IgA deposition, or renal involvement.
  • Labs: elevated ESR/CRP; platelet counts normal.

Complications

  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic kidney disease/renal failure.
  • Rare neurological involvement (seizures, neuropathy).

Treatment

  • Mild cases: hydration, rest, analgesics.
  • Moderate to severe: corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone).
  • Resistant cases: immunosuppressants may be required.

Explanation of Other Options:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A): Presents with purpura and thrombocytopenia, but lacks abdominal pain, arthritis, or renal findings.

Dengue (Option B): Viral infection with fever, rash, myalgia, and thrombocytopenia, but renal involvement is uncommon.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option C): Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis; affects medium/small vessels, associated with asthma, eosinophilia, systemic vasculitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • HSP is a small-vessel IgA vasculitis common in children.
  • Triad: palpable purpura + abdominal pain + arthritis/arthralgia.
  • Normal platelet counts help differentiate it from ITP and dengue.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy, recently treated with chemotherapy, presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia, elevated creatinine, and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation is consistent with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS), characterized by metabolic derangements following chemotherapy.

  • The most crucial initial step in management is vigorous hydration, which helps prevent uric acid crystal deposition and supports renal clearance.

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS):

  • Caused by rapid tumor cell breakdown releasing intracellular metabolites.
  • Typical biochemical abnormalities:
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hyperuricemia
  • Can lead to acute kidney injury and multiorgan dysfunction.
  • Most common in hematologic malignancies (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, ALL).

Clinical Features:

  • Abdominal symptoms: pain, distension.
  • Urinary symptoms: dysuria, oliguria, hematuria, flank pain.
  • Hypocalcemia manifestations: vomiting, anorexia, cramps, tetany, seizures, altered sensorium.
  • Usually occurs 12-48 hours post-chemotherapy, though can occur spontaneously in high tumor burden malignancies.

Prevention and Monitoring:

  • Pre-treatment labs: uric acid, electrolytes, calcium, phosphorus, creatinine.
  • Adequate hydration prior to chemotherapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Probenecid (Option B): A uricosuric agent that enhances uric acid excretion but increases risk of uric acid nephropathy and stones; contraindicated in TLS.

Allopurinol (Option C): A xanthine oxidase inhibitor used prophylactically to prevent uric acid accumulation but not the immediate management in established TLS.

Rasburicase (Option D): A urate oxidase enzyme that degrades uric acid; useful in high-risk or established TLS but hydration is the first-line step.

Key Takeaways:

  • TLS is an oncologic emergency with severe metabolic consequences.
  • Hydration is the first and most important management step.
  • Allopurinol and rasburicase are adjuncts for prevention or treatment after stabilization.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK518985/

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a gastric tumour extending to the pancreas and showing metastasis to the liver indicates advanced stage gastric carcinoma, which is not resectable with curative intent. In such cases, the priority is palliation to relieve symptoms like gastric outlet obstruction and to improve quality of life. Palliative gastrojejunostomy provides a bypass for gastric contents and reduces obstructive symptoms. This is then followed by systemic chemotherapy, which helps control tumour progression and improve survival.

Treatment of stomach cancer:

  • Surgical treatment (curative): The only definitive option, but requires absence of distant metastasis.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Improves surgical outcomes in resectable disease. The FLOT regimen (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) has shown superior survival compared to the older ECF regimen (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-FU).
  • Types of resection:
    • Total gastrectomy: For proximal or diffuse lesions.
    • Subtotal gastrectomy: For distal lesions, with Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative surgery: For inoperable or metastatic cases, gastrojejunostomy is done to relieve obstruction.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Radical gastrectomy (Option B): This would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible.

Whipple's procedure (Option C): This is a surgery primarily used for pancreatic cancer. Since the present case involves gastric cancer with liver metastasis, this procedure is not appropriate.

Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D): This could be considered for resectable localized tumours, but in the presence of liver metastasis, it is not an ideal option for curative intent.

Key takeaway: In patients with advanced gastric carcinoma with liver metastasis and local invasion, the management is palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy, not radical curative surgery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. His elder brother passed away due to a stroke at the age of 40. The CT abdomen is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of loin pain, hematuria, hypertension, and family history of early stroke strongly indicates autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  • The CT findings of multiple bilateral renal cysts confirm the diagnosis.
  • Stroke in the brother suggests possible intracranial berry aneurysm, a known extrarenal complication of ADPKD.

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD):

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; mutations in PKD1 (chromosome 16) or PKD2 (chromosome 4).
  • Pathogenesis: Abnormal polycystin protein → cyst formation → renal enlargement and progressive loss of function.
  • Intrarenal features:
    • Hypertension (most common presenting feature).
    • Hematuria, polyuria, nocturia.
    • Loin pain due to hemorrhage, infection, or stones.
    • Progressive renal failure (usually by 5th-6th decade).
  • Extrarenal features:
    • Polycystic liver disease (most common extrarenal).
    • Cysts in pancreas, spleen, ovaries.
    • Berry aneurysms → subarachnoid hemorrhage, stroke.
    • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation.
  • Investigations:
    • CECT: investigation of choice.
    • Ultrasound: screening and diagnosis.
    • IVP: shows spider leg deformity, bell-shaped pelvis, "Swiss cheese" appearance.
    • Renal function tests: elevated urea and creatinine.
  • Management:
    • Control hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs).
    • Supportive: treat infections, nephrolithiasis.
    • Drainage or deroofing of symptomatic cysts.
    • Definitive: renal transplantation once end-stage renal disease develops.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Renal cell carcinoma (Option A): Can cause hematuria and loin pain, but typically appears as a solid renal mass rather than multiple bilateral cysts.

Tuberculosis of the kidney (Option C): Causes hematuria, dysuria, and flank pain with sterile pyuria. CT may show calcifications or contracted kidneys ("putty kidney"), not diffuse cysts.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (Option D): Presents in infancy/childhood with hepatic fibrosis and severe renal failure, not in adulthood with preserved renal function until later decades.

Key Takeaway:

ADPKD presents with hypertension, hematuria, loin pain, and a positive family history. CT imaging reveals multiple bilateral cysts, and extrarenal complications (like berry aneurysm leading to stroke) are common. Definitive treatment is renal transplantation.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an elderly male patient who experienced scrotal pain and discharge, as indicated in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and discharge, along with the image showing extensive necrosis, which is highly suggestive of Fournier's gangrene.
  • This is a rapidly progressive necrotizing infection of the perineum, genitalia, and surrounding soft tissues, similar to necrotizing fasciitis.
  • It commonly occurs in immunocompromised states such as diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malnutrition, and vascular disease.
  • Clinical progression usually follows distinct phases:
    • Prodromal: Fever and lethargy
    • Early: Severe genital pain, edema, erythema
    • Progressive: Skin darkening, crepitus from gas-forming organisms
    • Gangrene: Purulent discharge, necrotic tissue, systemic toxicity
  • Management is aggressive and involves:
    • Immediate resuscitation with fluids
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (to cover both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria)
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue
    • Urinary/fecal diversion if required to prevent contamination
    • Repeated wound evaluation, VAC dressings, and later skin grafting for reconstruction

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Torsion of the testis (Option A): This presents as sudden, severe scrotal pain with rapid swelling and absent cremasteric reflex. It leads to ischemia and gangrene of the testis if untreated but does not present with soft tissue necrosis and foul-smelling discharge.

Acute epididymo-orchitis (Option B): Typically caused by bacterial infections (eg, E. coli, Chlamydia, Gonorrhea), leading to painful, tender scrotal swelling with fever and dysuria. It is not associated with necrosis or crepitus.

Scrotal carcinoma (Option C): Usually presents as a painless, indurated mass or ulcer with everted edges and an indurated base. It is a chronic, slow-growing lesion and not an acute necrotizing infection like Fournier's gangrene.

Key Takeaway:

Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive necrotizing infection of the perineum and genitalia caused by mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. It requires urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics, as delay in management significantly increases mortality.

questions.text: A male patient presents with impotence and absent femoral pulse. Pain in the gluteal region is observed. At which level has pathology occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triad of impotence, gluteal claudication, and absent femoral pulses is classical for Leriche's syndrome, which occurs due to occlusion at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • Pathology at this level compromises blood flow to the lower limbs and pelvic organs, explaining the combination of symptoms.
  • Gluteal pain occurs due to ischemia in the buttock muscles, impotence results from impaired pelvic circulation, and absent femoral pulses reflect poor distal flow.

Leriche's Syndrome (Aortoiliac Occlusion):

  • Clinical triad: Claudication (especially buttock/thigh), impotence, absent femoral pulses.
  • Pathophysiology: Progressive atherosclerotic disease at the bifurcation of the aorta into the common iliac arteries.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical exam showing absent femoral pulses.
    • Doppler and duplex ultrasonography.
    • CT/MR angiography for localization and severity.
  • Treatment:
    • Lifestyle modification and antiplatelet therapy for mild disease.
    • Endovascular stenting or aortobifemoral bypass graft for severe occlusion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Bilateral popliteal arteries (Option A): Occlusion here causes calf and foot ischemia with absent pedal pulses, but femoral pulses remain palpable, and impotence is not a feature.

Bilateral internal iliac arteries (Option B): This could explain impotence and buttock pain due to reduced pelvic and gluteal blood flow, but femoral pulses would still be present since flow through the external iliac and femoral arteries is intact.

Bilateral femoral arteries (Option D): This causes calf claudication and absent distal pulses, but gluteal pain and impotence are not explained, as pelvic circulation is unaffected.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of impotence, gluteal pain, and absent femoral pulses is pathognomonic for Leriche's syndrome due to aortoiliac bifurcation occlusion, making this the correct site of pathology.

Reference:

NIH Link.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring location for an intraperitoneal abscess to develop?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The subhepatic region (beneath the liver) is the most common site for intraperitoneal abscess formation.
  • This site is prone because of its anatomical position close to the biliary system and gastrointestinal tract, which allows infections to spread easily into this dependent space.
  • Position-based variations:
    • In a recumbent or lying down patient, the Morrison’s pouch (right subhepatic space) is the typical site of collection.
    • In an upright patient, the pelvis (Pouch of Douglas) is the most common site overall.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Suprahepatic (Option A): This area is located above the liver, often associated with subphrenic abscesses. Although abscesses can develop here, it is not the most common site.

Left lobe of the liver (Option C): Abscesses may occur within the liver, but this is not the typical site of intraperitoneal abscess formation.

Left side below diaphragm (Option D): This area may occasionally harbor subphrenic abscesses, but it is far less common compared to the subhepatic space.

Key Takeaway:

The subhepatic space (Morrison’s pouch) is the most common site for intraperitoneal abscess formation, particularly in recumbent patients, while the pelvis is the most common site overall in upright patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is scheduled for a tooth extraction due to dental caries. In which of the following conditions is prophylaxis against infective endocarditis not required?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patients with atrial septal defect (ASD) generally do not require prophylaxis for infective endocarditis (IE) unless associated with additional complications such as large shunts or right-sided failure. Hence, ASD alone is not considered a high-risk condition.

Infective Endocarditis (IE):

  • Infection of the endocardial surface of the heart, most often involving valves.
  • Prophylaxis is recommended only for high-risk groups undergoing invasive procedures such as dental extraction.

High-Risk Conditions Requiring Prophylaxis:

  • Prosthetic heart valves (Option D) - both mechanical and bioprosthetic.
  • History of infective endocarditis (Option A) - prior infection increases recurrence risk.
  • Congenital heart disease (CHD):
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD (Option C)
    • Repaired CHD with prosthetic material (first 6 months)
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects
  • Cardiac transplant patients with valvulopathy.

Procedures where prophylaxis is indicated:

  • Dental: Extractions, periodontal procedures, root canal, implants.
  • Respiratory: Tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy, bronchoscopy with biopsy.
  • GI/GU: Endoscopy with biopsy, colonoscopy, cystoscopy (in high-risk patients).

Prophylaxis Regimen:

  • Amoxicillin: 2 g orally, 30-60 min before procedure.
  • Penicillin allergy alternatives: Clindamycin 600 mg or Azithromycin 500 mg orally.

Causative Organisms in Infective Endocarditis:


Explanation of other options:

Prior history of infective endocarditis (Option A): Requires prophylaxis since recurrence risk is high.

Unrepaired cyanotic CHD (Option C): Considered high-risk, prophylaxis mandatory.

Prosthetic heart valves (Option D): Strongest indication for prophylaxis due to high risk of infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • IE prophylaxis is restricted to a select group of high-risk patients.
  • Atrial septal defect alone does not warrant prophylaxis.
  • Amoxicillin is the standard prophylactic drug; alternatives available for penicillin allergy.

questions.text: A patient presents with prostate carcinoma, which has now spread to the vertebra. What is the route of spread to the lumbar vertebra?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the vertebra most commonly occurs through Batson's plexus, also known as the vertebral venous plexus.
  • This venous network is valveless, which allows retrograde flow of blood from the pelvic venous system to the spinal venous system.
  • This retrograde pathway facilitates the direct hematogenous spread of malignant cells from the prostate to the lumbar vertebrae, explaining the frequent skeletal metastases in advanced prostate cancer.

Routes of Spread in Prostate Carcinoma:

  • Haematogenous spread (most common): Via Batson's plexus → skeletal metastases (pelvic bones, lumbar vertebrae).
  • Local spread: To bladder, seminal vesicles, and rectum.
  • Lymphatic spread: To pelvic and para-aortic nodes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transcoelomic spread (Option B): Refers to tumor dissemination across peritoneal surfaces (e.g., ovarian carcinoma), not typical of prostate carcinoma metastasis.

Inferior vesical vein (Option C): Drains the prostate into the internal iliac vein but does not provide a direct channel to the vertebral venous system.

Internal iliac vein (Option D): Drains pelvic organs, including the prostate, but is not the route responsible for vertebral metastasis.

Key Takeaway:

The characteristic spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae occurs through Batson's plexus, a valveless venous network that allows retrograde flow and facilitates skeletal metastases.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The findings of severe abdominal pain, history of alcohol use, and fluid collections near the pancreas on CT strongly indicate acute pancreatitis. The most specific and sensitive biochemical marker for this condition is serum lipase, which remains elevated longer than amylase and confirms the diagnosis when it is more than three times the upper limit of normal.

Clinical diagnosis (requires 2 of 3):

  • Abdominal pain characteristic of acute pancreatitis
  • Serum amylase and/or lipase at least 3× the upper limit of normal
  • Imaging showing features of pancreatitis

Radiological signs:

  • Sentinel loop sign: Localized dilated loop of small bowel near the inflamed pancreas
  • Colon cut-off sign: Abrupt termination of gas at the splenic flexure with collapsed distal colon

Investigations of choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Gold standard for assessing necrosis, inflammation, fluid collections, and complications. It is best performed after 72 hours for accurate staging.

Morphological types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  • Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis: Oedema and swelling without necrosis
  • Necrotising pancreatitis: Parenchymal necrosis, severe, associated with high morbidity and mortality

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Serum GGT (Option A): This enzyme is elevated in chronic alcohol use and liver disease but is not a specific marker for pancreatitis.

CEA (Option B): Carcinoembryonic antigen is a tumour marker, especially for colorectal and pancreatic malignancies, and is not relevant in acute pancreatitis.

Serum bilirubin (Option D): May rise in cases of biliary obstruction or gallstone pancreatitis, but it is not the primary diagnostic enzyme for pancreatitis.

Key takeaway:

The most reliable biochemical marker for acute pancreatitis is serum lipase, while CECT is the imaging investigation of choice for assessing severity, necrosis, and complications. Radiological signs such as sentinel loop and colon cut-off sign can support early suspicion on plain X-ray.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with prostate carcinoma presents to you with a PSA of 9 ng/mL with a small tumour focus. His Gleason score is 6. What will be your most likely management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this patient, the features indicate low-risk prostate cancer: PSA <10 ng/mL, Gleason score 6 (3+3), and small tumour volume. For such patients, the most appropriate management is active surveillance, which avoids unnecessary treatment-related morbidity while monitoring for disease progression.

Gleason scoring system:

  • 6 (3+3): Low-grade, resembles normal tissue, low risk of spread
  • 7 (3+4 or 4+3): Intermediate risk, moderate likelihood of spread
  • 8 (4+4, 3+5, 5+3): High risk, aggressive and likely to spread
  • 9 or 10 (4+5, 5+4, 5+5): Very high-grade, highly aggressive with rapid progression

Management strategies for prostate cancer:

  • Active surveillance: Recommended for low risk localized disease. Involves regular PSA monitoring, digital rectal examination, and repeat biopsies to detect progression.
  • Radical prostatectomy (Option A ruled out): Preferred for localized intermediate or high-risk cancer, particularly in younger patients with good life expectancy. Involves risks of urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction.
  • External beam radiation (Option B ruled out): Used as definitive therapy for localized disease, especially when surgery is contraindicated. Not first-line for low-risk cases.
  • Brachytherapy (Option C ruled out): Involves radioactive seed implantation, suitable for select patients but again not the initial choice in low-risk disease like in this patient.

Key takeaway:

For elderly patients with low-risk prostate cancer (PSA <10, Gleason 6, small tumour focus), the preferred management is active surveillance rather than aggressive surgery or radiation, thereby minimizing treatment-related complications while keeping the disease under careful monitoring.

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's presentation with acute dysphagia and X-ray showing a round opacity in the coronal plane on PA view is classic for a foreign body in the esophagus.
  • Objects like coins, button batteries, or bottle caps usually lodge in the esophagus and appear circular on frontal X-ray.
  • This correlates with the child's difficulty swallowing and confirms the diagnosis.

Management of Ingested Foreign Bodies:

Emergency (Immediate endoscopic removal):

  • Esophageal obstruction (child cannot swallow saliva).
  • Button/disk batteries in the esophagus.
  • Sharp or pointed objects.

Urgent (Within 12-24 hours):

  • Coins and blunt objects in the esophagus.
  • Incomplete obstruction.
  • Multiple magnets or magnets + ferromagnetic object.

Non-Urgent (Observation possible):

  • Blunt objects already in the stomach (<2.5 cm) that are expected to pass spontaneously.
  • Asymptomatic disc battery in the stomach (can wait up to 48 hrs).
  • Blunt objects that fail to progress beyond the stomach within 3-4 weeks.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A): Causes stridor, wheezing, and respiratory distress. Aligns in the sagittal plane and appears round on lateral view, not PA.

Artifact (Option C): Caused by external items such as clips or clothing. It would not correlate with acute dysphagia or appear lodged in the esophagus.

Soft tissue calcification in the neck (Option D): Can be seen in lymph nodes or vessels but does not mimic a discrete foreign body and is not associated with sudden swallowing difficulty.

Key Takeaway

  • Esophageal foreign body: Appears round on PA view (coronal plane), presents with dysphagia.
  • Tracheal foreign body: Appears round on lateral view (sagittal plane), presents with respiratory symptoms.
  • Management urgency depends on type of object and degree of obstruction.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's history of breast cancer surgery with axillary dissection and now presenting with painless arm swelling is highly suggestive of lymphedema.
  • Lymphedema occurs due to lymphatic obstruction or removal of axillary lymph nodes, resulting in accumulation of protein-rich lymph fluid in the subcutaneous tissue.
  • It is one of the most common long-term complications after mastectomy or axillary clearance.

Complications of Mastectomy:

  • Lymphedema
    • Swelling of the ipsilateral arm due to lymphatic obstruction.
    • Clinical signs:
      • Stemmer's sign: Inability to pinch the skin on the dorsum of the fingers/toes due to fibrosis.
      • Square toe/finger appearance due to chronic swelling.
    • Usually develops gradually and is painless in the early stages.
    • Risk factors: axillary node dissection, radiation therapy, infection, obesity.


  • Wound infection / Flap necrosis
    • Blackening of wound edges, may progress to infection.
  • Post-mastectomy pain syndrome
    • Chronic pain due to nerve injury or scar tissue.
  • Nerve injuries:
    • Long thoracic nerve: Winging of scapula.
    • Thoracodorsal nerve: Weak adduction of the shoulder.
    • Intercostobrachial nerve: Dysesthesia of medial upper arm.
    • Medial pectoral nerve: Pectoralis muscle atrophy.
  • Lymphangiosarcoma
    • Stewart-Treves syndrome - develops after many years of chronic untreated lymphedema and typically presents with purplish nodules or plaques rather than painless swelling. (Option B ruled out)
  • Other complications:
    • Axillary vein injury or thrombosis (Option C ruled out)
    • Seroma
    • Shoulder dysfunction
    • Pain and numbness
    • Axillary hyperesthesia
    • Hematoma, seroma, shoulder stiffness.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cellulitis (Option D): presents with redness, warmth, pain, and fever, none of which are present in this case, making it different from post-mastectomy lymphedema.


Key Takeaway:

Post-mastectomy lymphedema is the most frequent chronic complication due to impaired lymphatic drainage. It presents as painless swelling of the arm, whereas venous thrombosis and cellulitis are painful conditions, and lymphangiosarcoma occurs only in chronic untreated lymphedema after many years.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 25-year-old patient who has been experiencing abdominal pain and fever for the past three days, based on the provided chest X-ray taken in an upright position?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The upright chest X-ray demonstrates free air under the diaphragm, a hallmark sign of pneumoperitoneum, which most commonly results from a hollow viscus perforation (such as a perforated peptic ulcer or perforated intestine).
  • The combination of acute abdominal pain, fever, and air under the diaphragm strongly supports this diagnosis.
  • Leakage of gastric or intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity causes peritonitis, requiring urgent surgical intervention.

Pneumoperitoneum - Key Points:

  • Causes: Perforated peptic ulcer (most common), bowel ischemia, obstruction with perforation, trauma, colonoscopy injury.
  • Radiological signs:
    • Free subdiaphragmatic gas (best seen under right hemidiaphragm on erect CXR).
    • Rigler's sign - visualization of both sides of bowel wall due to free gas.
    • Cupola sign - lucency beneath central diaphragm.
  • Best investigation: CT abdomen - detects even small amounts of intraperitoneal air.
  • Management: Urgent resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and surgical repair of perforation.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Gastric volvulus (Option B): Involves abnormal rotation of the stomach leading to obstruction. Presents with severe epigastric pain, retching, and inability to pass an NG tube (Borchardt's triad). Does not produce free air under the diaphragm.


Liver abscess (Option C): Presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and malaise. Imaging shows a hypodense lesion on CT or a cystic lesion on USG. It does not cause free peritoneal air.


Empyema thoracis (Option D): Refers to pus in the pleural cavity, causing fever, cough, and chest pain. Imaging shows pleural fluid with loculation, but not free subdiaphragmatic gas.


Key Takeaway:

Free air under the diaphragm on upright chest X-ray is diagnostic of pneumoperitoneum, most often due to a hollow viscus perforation. This is a surgical emergency requiring prompt recognition and management.

questions.text: According to the CEAP classification, What will be the stage in this patient as the patient presents with the same problem again and again?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CEAP classification system (Clinical-Etiological-Anatomical-Pathophysiological) is the standard framework for describing chronic venous disorders.
  • In this case, the patient has recurrent symptoms due to varicose veins, which directly corresponds to C2 (varicose veins >3 mm in diameter).
  • Recurrent disease is denoted by the suffix "r," for example, C2r (recurrent varicose veins).

CEAP Classification for Chronic Venous Disorders

Clinical (C) Classification

  • C0: No visible or palpable venous disease
  • C1: Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins (1-3 mm)
  • C2: Varicose veins (>3 mm)
  • C3: Edema
  • C4a: Pigmentation, eczema
  • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis, atrophie blanche
  • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Healed venous ulcer
  • C6: Active venous ulcer

Modifiers:

  • a = asymptomatic
  • s = symptomatic
  • r = recurrent (after previous treatment or healing)

Etiological (E) Classification

  • Ec: Congenital
  • Ep: Primary
  • Es: Secondary (post-thrombotic)
  • En: No venous cause identified

Anatomical (A) Classification

  • As: Superficial veins
  • Ap: Perforator veins
  • Ad: Deep veins
  • An: No venous location identified

Pathophysiological (P) Classification

  • Pr: Reflux
  • Po: Obstruction
  • Pr,o: Reflux and obstruction
  • Pn: No venous pathophysiology identified

Pigmentation/Eczema

LDS

Atrophic blanche

Corona phlebectatica

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

C1 (Option B): Represents telangiectasias or reticular veins, not large symptomatic varicose veins.

C4a (Option C): Used when there are skin changes such as pigmentation or venous eczema.

C5 (Option D): Refers to a healed venous ulcer, which is not the case here.

Key Takeaway: Recurrent symptomatic varicose veins fall under CEAP stage C2r, highlighting the presence of varicose veins with recurrence following earlier management.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557410/

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The key detail is that the patient had cholecystectomy 2.5 years ago and now presents with CBD stone and obstructive jaundice.
  • CBD stones detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy are classified as recurrent stones.
  • These stones form within the biliary system after surgery, most often due to biliary stasis, infection, or sphincter dysfunction.
  • Clinical presentation often includes Charcot's triad (fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) or Reynold's pentad (Charcot's triad + hypotension + confusion).

Types of Common Bile Duct (CBD) Stones:

  • Retained stones: Detected within 2 years post-cholecystectomy.
  • Recurrent stones: Detected after 2 years post-cholecystectomy (this patient’s case).
  • Primary stones (Option A): Form de novo in the CBD, usually brown pigment stones due to infection or bile stasis (eg, PSC, Caroli disease).
  • Secondary stones (Option B): Originate in the gallbladder and migrate into CBD; most common type, usually cholesterol stones.
  • Tertiary stones (Option C): Rare, form within bile ducts due to chronic infection or parasites.

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound: Detects gallstones and CBD dilatation, but less sensitive for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Excellent non-invasive imaging for biliary tree pathology.
    • MRCP of CBD stone
    • ERCP of a distal CBD stone
  • ERCP: Diagnostic and therapeutic; allows sphincterotomy and stone removal.
  • Blood tests: Show elevated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, WBC (if cholangitis).

Management:

  • ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction → first-line treatment.
  • Stenting if immediate extraction not possible.
  • Percutaneous removal or surgical options (choledocholithotomy, choledochojejunostomy) if endoscopy fails.
  • Renal transplantation not relevant here; definitive treatment focuses on duct clearance and preventing recurrence.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Primary (Option A): Refers to de novo stones forming in CBD; not necessarily related to prior cholecystectomy.

Secondary (Option B): Stones that migrated from gallbladder to CBD; would be seen before or within 2 years of surgery.

Tertiary (Option C): Associated with infection or parasites, rare compared to recurrent CBD stones.

Key Takeaway:

Stones found in the common bile duct more than 2 years after cholecystectomy are termed recurrent stones. They are usually managed by ERCP with stone extraction, and untreated cases risk cholangitis, pancreatitis, and biliary stricture.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient with jaundice reveal elevated bilirubin and markedly raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Other liver enzymes (AST, ALT) are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of elevated bilirubin and ALP with normal transaminases (AST, ALT) is characteristic of obstructive jaundice. This pattern indicates impaired bile flow due to blockage, leading to accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the bloodstream.

Comparison of Different Types of Jaundice


Explanation of other options:

Haemolytic jaundice (Option B): Results from increased RBC breakdown. Causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia; ALP and transaminases remain normal.

Hepatic jaundice (Option C): Due to intrinsic liver disease. Shows both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin elevation with marked rise in AST/ALT.

Prehepatic jaundice (Option D): Essentially overlaps with haemolytic jaundice; unconjugated bilirubin rises with normal ALP.

Key Takeaways:

  • Obstructive jaundice: Raised bilirubin + ALP with normal AST/ALT.
  • Haemolytic jaundice: Unconjugated bilirubin ↑ with normal ALP.
  • Hepatic jaundice: Mixed bilirubin pattern with markedly raised AST/ALT.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's history of sterile pyuria along with imaging showing extensive calcification replacing renal tissue is typical of Putty kidney, which represents the late stage of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB).
  • In this stage, the kidney becomes non-functioning and shrunken, filled with calcified caseous material, and is often referred to as a "cement" or "putty-like" kidney.

Features of Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB):

  • Bladder involvement: Early pallor around ureteric orifice on cystoscopy → progresses to fibrosis → small contracted "thimble bladder."
  • Ureter involvement: Strictures, beaded appearance.
  • Kidney involvement:
    • Earliest sign: moth-eaten calyces on IVU.
    • Hydronephrosis, strictures.
    • Late stage: complete destruction with calcification → Putty kidney.
  • Male genital involvement: Beaded vas deferens, calcified nodular prostate, discharging sinuses; testis usually spared.

Investigations:

  • Urine tests: Sterile pyuria, hematuria.
  • IVU: Moth-eaten calyces, strictures, hydronephrosis, shrunken bladder.
  • CECT: Investigation of choice for early GUTB.
  • RGP: Defines ureteral strictures.

Treatment:

  • First-line: Antitubercular therapy (short course).
  • Advanced disease: Nephrectomy may be required if kidney is non-functioning.
  • Supportive measures for strictures and bladder involvement.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Nephrocalcinosis (Option B): Represents diffuse calcium deposition in renal parenchyma, typically due to metabolic disorders (hyperparathyroidism, RTA, hypercalcemia). Pattern is diffuse, not "putty-like."


Staghorn calculus (Option C): A branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces, usually struvite stone from Proteus infection. Appears as radiopaque branching structure, not diffuse calcification.


Psoas calcification (Option D): Calcification within the psoas muscle from old abscess, trauma, or parasitic disease; located outside kidney, not replacing renal parenchyma.


Key Takeaway: Putty kidney is a late manifestation of renal tuberculosis, marked by complete destruction of renal parenchyma and replacement with calcified material, often associated with sterile pyuria and a non-functioning kidney.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following categories of patients comes under green?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a mass-casualty triage system, patients are divided into categories by urgency of care.
  • The green category includes ambulatory patients-those who can walk, have non-life-threatening injuries, and can tolerate a delay in treatment without significant risk of deterioration.
  • They are often called "walking wounded".

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Moderate priority (Option B): Refers to the yellow category, where patients are injured but stable enough to wait for a few hours before intervention.

High priority (Option C): Refers to the red category, which requires immediate life-saving intervention.

Dead patients (Option D): Classified as black, representing expectant/unsalvageable cases. They are not treated in triage systems where resources are limited.

Key Takeaway:

In triage, ambulatory and stable patients fall under the green category, as they can tolerate treatment delays while resources are directed toward red and yellow categories.

questions.text: Please determine the extent of burn injuries in a preschool-aged child portrayed in the attached image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In paediatric patients, the Rule of Nines is modified because the head accounts for a larger proportion of body surface area compared to adults, and the lower limbs account for less.
  • In this scenario, the child has:
    • Complete back involvement = 18%
    • Partial anterior trunk (upper and lower chest) = ~9%
    • Adding these areas together gives 27%, which falls in the 25-30% range.

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition mentioned below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image and clinical description are consistent with Fournier's gangrene, a rapidly progressive, necrotizing infection of the perineum, scrotum, and genitalia.
  • The hallmark feature is that it is caused by mixed bacterial flora, both aerobes and anaerobes.
  • Common organisms include Escherichia coli, Bacteroides, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • The synergy between aerobic and anaerobic bacteria contributes to rapid tissue necrosis, gas formation, and systemic sepsis.

Fournier's Gangrene Overview:

  • Definition: A type of necrotizing fasciitis involving the perineum, genitalia, and perianal regions.
  • Risk factors: Diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, immunosuppression, malnutrition, chronic alcoholism.
  • Clinical features:
    • Severe perineal/genital pain and swelling.
    • Fever, lethargy, systemic toxicity.
    • Skin changes progress through erythema, edema, dusky discoloration, crepitus, and eventually gangrene.
    • May progress to septic shock if untreated.
  • Diagnosis: Largely clinical; imaging (CT/MRI) may be used to define extent.
  • Management:
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation and supportive care.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics covering aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue, often with repeated procedures.
    • Adjuncts: Urinary or fecal diversion may be performed if contamination is severe, but it is not always compulsory.
    • Definitive care: Reconstruction with skin grafts or flaps once infection controlled.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy (Option A): Incorrect, as Fournier's gangrene is not due to Clostridium perfringens alone, so anti-gas gangrene serum is not indicated.

Bilateral orchiectomy is generally performed (Option C): Incorrect, as the testes are usually spared because their blood supply arises from the testicular artery (aortic origin), not from scrotal vessels. Orchiectomy is rarely required.

Compulsory urinary diversion is performed (Option D): Incorrect, urinary diversion is not mandatory in all cases. It is done only when there is extensive perineal involvement risking wound contamination.

Key Takeaway:

Fournier's gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum and genitalia caused by mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Management requires urgent antibiotics, aggressive debridement, and supportive measures. Orchiectomy and diversion procedures are rarely required and are not routine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with pain in the thigh during walking. Investigation reveals the following finding as given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has symptoms of intermittent claudication (thigh pain on exertion) due to aorto-femoral arterial occlusive disease.
  • When the disease involves the aorta extending into the distal iliac arteries, the surgical procedure of choice is aortofemoral bypass.
  • This surgery establishes a new conduit between the aorta and femoral arteries using a synthetic graft, restoring blood flow to the lower extremities.
  • Graft materials:
    • Knitted/woven Dacron → requires preclotting.
    • Collagen-impregnated Dacron or PTFE → no preclotting needed.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

PTA with stenting (Option A): Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stent placement is useful in localized iliac or femoral lesions. It is less effective in extensive aorto-femoral occlusion involving long segments.

Femoroiliac bypass (Option B): Indicated for isolated iliac artery block, not when the disease extends into the aorta and both iliac systems.

Aorto-iliac bypass (Option D): Similar to an aortobifemoral bypass but typically performed when disease is limited to the aorto-iliac region. In this patient, thigh symptoms and block extending further warrant aortofemoral bypass.

Key Takeaway:

In patients with extensive aorto-femoral arterial occlusive disease-causing claudication, the best surgical option is an aortofemoral bypass, as it restores bilateral lower limb circulation and relieves symptoms more effectively than localized procedures.

choices.text: Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following interventions is linked to a longer lifespan?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Of the options provided, caloric restriction is the best-documented intervention linked to extending lifespan.

Explanations of other options:

Regular moderate exercise for 30 min (Option A): It offers several health benefits, including enhanced cardiovascular function, improved metabolism, and a lower risk of chronic illnesses. However, unlike caloric restriction, its impact on directly extending lifespan is less well established, though it does support a longer health span.

Decrease stress (Option B): Chronic stress leads to multiple harmful health outcomes that can shorten lifespan. While stress management strategies may enhance overall health and potentially extend longevity, the connection is more indirect and inconsistent.

Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors (Option D): Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) lower stomach acid and are used in managing GERD and peptic ulcers. Although effective for symptom control, they do not contribute to increased lifespan.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with cough, fatigue, and weight loss was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma after bronchoscopy. Examination of the resected specimen revealed a 1 cm hilar lymph node containing black pigment. What is the most likely pigment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anthracotic pigment, a carbon-derived black deposit, is often found in the lungs and lymph nodes, particularly in people with a history of chronic smoking or long-term exposure to polluted environments and is also associated with squamous cell carcinoma.

  • In anthracosis, macrophages in the lungs ingest anthracotic pigment particles and carry them to regional lymph nodes.
  • Histopathology reveals macrophages loaded with carbon deposits.
  • In lung cancer cases, especially squamous cell carcinoma, hilar lymphadenopathy with black pigmentation is frequently observed because of the close connection between the lungs and lymphatic drainage of carbon particles.
  • The following image shows anthracotic pigments.

Explanation of other options:

Melanin (Option B): Melanin,the pigment that gives color to skin and hair and provides UV protection, may be present in melanomas (a skin cancer), but it is generally not seen in lung tissue or lymph nodes. The following image depicts melanin pigment in a melanoma.



Lipochrome (Option C): Lipochrome refers to yellow-brown pigments formed from lipid breakdown as shown below. Microscopically, it presents as fine, granular deposits within the cytoplasm, usually around the nucleus. Although it can accumulate in different tissues, it is not commonly linked to lung conditions or lymph node involvement.



Hemosiderin (Option D): Hemosiderin, an iron-storage pigment formed from haemoglobin breakdown, typically has a brown colouration. However, it does not present as a black pigment in smoking-related lung conditions or cancer. The black arrow shows interstitial hemosiderin deposition.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male presents with abdominal distension, pedal edema, and decreased urine output. His serum creatinine is 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next best management option?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has features suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), a complication of advanced liver disease characterized by renal dysfunction due to severe splanchnic vasodilation and reduced renal perfusion.
  • Initial therapy involves albumin infusion along with vasoconstrictors such as octreotide, which improves renal perfusion.

Key management of HRS:

  • Stop diuretics.
  • Albumin infusion: 1 g/kg/day (maximum 100 g/day).
  • Vasoconstrictors: Terlipressin (preferred), norepinephrine (low dose), or the combination of midodrine + octreotide with albumin.
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation, with renal recovery following transplantation.

Mechanism of octreotide + albumin:
