  • Octreotide: A somatostatin analogue that reduces splanchnic vasodilation.
  • Albumin: Expands plasma volume, improving renal perfusion and decreasing hypoperfusion-related renal failure.

Explanation of other options:

Methylprednisolone (Option A): Used in severe alcoholic hepatitis with high Maddrey's discriminant function; not effective for HRS.

Heparin (Option B): Anticoagulant with no role in HRS; increases bleeding risk in cirrhotic patients.

Torsemide (Option C): A loop diuretic, contraindicated in HRS as it worsens hypovolemia and further reduces renal perfusion.

Key Takeaways:

  • HRS is a functional renal failure due to advanced cirrhosis and splanchnic vasodilation.
  • Initial therapy: Albumin + vasoconstrictor (octreotide, terlipressin, or norepinephrine).
  • Definitive therapy: Liver transplantation.

questions.text: A patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which jugular venous pressure (JVP) finding is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF), characterized by chaotic atrial activity leading to ineffective atrial contraction. The absence of effective atrial systole causes the a wave in JVP to be absent, making it the classical venous finding in AF. The pulse deficit indicates irregular AV nodal conduction, with some atrial impulses not producing ventricular contractions.

Key Features of Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Mechanism: Abnormal atrial automaticity and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Pulse: Irregularly irregular.
  • Symptoms: Palpitations, breathlessness, syncope; systemic embolism may occur even if asymptomatic.
  • ECG Findings:
    • QRS complexes: Normal but irregular.
    • P waves: Absent, replaced by fibrillatory waves.
    • Ventricular rate: Rapid (120-160/min at onset), slower in chronic AF due to AV nodal fatigue/therapy.

  • JVP: Absent a wave.

Management Overview:

  • Paroxysmal AF:
    • Beta-blockers (first-line in CAD, hypertension, heart failure).
    • Class Ic (propafenone, flecainide) and Class III (amiodarone, dronedarone).
    • Rate control: Digoxin, verapamil.
    • Catheter ablation for drug-resistant cases.
  • Persistent AF:
    • Rhythm control with cardioversion (pharmacological/electrical).
    • Anticoagulation if AF ≥48h.
    • Rate control with digoxin, β-blockers, or calcium channel blockers.
  • Thromboprophylaxis:
    • Anticoagulation guided by CHA2DS2-VASc score.
    • INR 2.0-3.0 for warfarin; DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban, dabigatran) as alternatives.

CHA2DS2-VASc Score for Stroke Risk in AF:


  • Score 0 → no anticoagulation
  • Score 1 → aspirin
  • Score ≥2 → anticoagulation (warfarin/DOACs)

Explanation of other options:

Absent p wave (Option A): ECG hallmark of AF, but JVP finding is absent a wave, not absent p wave.

Cannon a wave (Option C): Seen in AV dissociation (atrium contracting against closed tricuspid valve).

Raised JVP with normal waveform (Option D): Occurs in CHF, RV infarction, or SVC obstruction-not typical of AF.

References:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34506629/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34506629/

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with progressive abdominal distension. Clinical examination showed shifting dullness, and the liver span measured less than 7 cm. Histopathology demonstrated intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions within hepatocytes. What do these inclusions contain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In alcoholic liver disease, hepatocytes characteristically contain Mallory-Denk bodies, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions made up of intermediate filaments, mainly cytokeratin 8 and 18.

They appear as shown below.



Mallory hyaline bodies may also appear in several other conditions

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson's disease
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency; Alcoholic liver disease
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Chronic cholestatic disorders
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis (but not in secondary biliary cirrhosis)

Explanation of other options:

Actin (Option B): Actin, a structural protein of microfilaments, is not usually involved in forming eosinophilic inclusions in alcoholic liver disease.

Microtubules (Option C): Microtubules play a role in cell division and intracellular transport but are not responsible for eosinophilic inclusion formation in hepatocytes.

Fibronectin (Option D): Fibronectin, an extracellular matrix protein involved in tissue repair and fibrosis, is not linked to the development of intracytoplasmic inclusions in hepatocytes, including those seen in alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a poor prognosis in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

β-2 microglobulin is considered one of the most important indicators of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma.

  • High β-2 microglobulin levels are associated with greater tumour load and a more aggressive course of the disease.
  • The prognosis of multiple myeloma is assessed using:
    • Durie-Salmon staging system (older method)
    • International Staging System (ISS): A three-stage classification that estimates survival based on β2-microglobulin and albumin levels.


Explanation of other options:

Calcium levels (Option B): Although hypercalcemia is frequently seen in multiple myeloma, it usually appears as a late complication and is not as strong a predictor of poor prognosis as β-2 microglobulin.

Serum creatinine (Option C): An increase in serum creatinine reflects kidney damage, a frequent complication of multiple myeloma. Although renal function impacts overall prognosis, serum creatinine is not considered a prognostic marker in the same way as β-2 microglobulin.

Protein levels (Option D): Protein levels are often raised and act as markers of disease activity, but they are not direct indicators of poor prognosis.

questions.text: A software engineer visits the outpatient clinic with complaints of easy fatigue. He reports working 12-14 hours daily on the computer and eating mostly junk food with minimal fruit and vegetable intake. His hemoglobin is 9 g/dl, and MCV is 80 fl. What is the most probable cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation, combined with a history of inadequate diet and lab results showing Hb 9 g/dL with an MCV of 80 fl (microcytic anaemia), is highly indicative of iron deficiency anaemia.

  • Iron deficiency anaemia may arise from inadequate dietary intake, poor absorption, increased demand (such as in pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (like from the gastrointestinal tract).
  • Typical features include koilonychia, hair loss, atrophic glossitis, oesophageal webs, pica, and intestinal malabsorption, all of which impact overall nutrition.


Explanation of other options:

Cyanocobalamin deficiency (Option A): Cyanocobalamin deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, usually presenting as macrocytic anemia with increased MCV, rather than the microcytic anemia observed in this patient.

Folic acid deficiency (Option C): Folic acid deficiency results in megaloblastic anaemia, which manifests as macrocytic anaemia with elevated MCV, rather than the microcytic anaemia seen here.

Hereditary spherocytosis (Option D): Hereditary spherocytosis is a disorder characterized by abnormally shaped red blood cells (spherocytes), causing hemolysis and resulting in normocytic anaemia with a normal MCV.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complained of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The history of chronic perianal discharge and pain lasting for years strongly points toward a fistula in ano.
  • It is defined as a chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen and an external opening on the perineum, buttock, or even (rarely) vagina in women.
  • Patients often report recurrent episodes of purulent or bloody discharge that relieve discomfort temporarily, and many have a history of previous anorectal abscesses.

Fistula in Ano:

  • Causes:
    • Idiopathic/cryptoglandular infection (most common).
    • Secondary to Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, actinomycosis, LGV, malignancy.
  • Clinical features:
    • Persistent or intermittent purulent discharge.
    • Pain relieved after discharge.
    • Recurrent perianal abscess.
    • Occasionally, passage of flatus or feces through the external opening.
  • Complications:
    • Chronic infection.
    • Secondary abscess formation.
    • Rare malignant transformation in longstanding cases.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pilonidal sinus (Option A): Found in the natal cleft above the anus, caused by hair penetration into skin. Presents with midline pits and abscesses, not with a direct connection to the rectum.

Carbuncle (Option B): A cluster of boils (staphylococcal infection of hair follicles) leading to a painful swollen lump with multiple pus-discharging points, usually on the nape, back, or thighs, not chronic perianal lesions.

Boil (Option C): A single perifollicular abscess presenting as a tender nodule with a pus point. While it can occur near the anus, it is acute and self-limited, not chronic and recurrent like a fistula.

Key Takeaway:

A fistula in ano is characterized by chronic recurrent perianal discharge and pain due to an abnormal communication between the anorectal canal and perianal skin. Differentiating it from pilonidal sinus, boils, and carbuncles depends on location, chronicity, and presence of internal communication with the rectum.

questions.text: A female patient presents with galactorrhea and a negative urine pregnancy test. MRI reveals a large pituitary mass. If she declines surgical intervention, which of the following is the best pharmacological treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case is consistent with a prolactinoma, a benign pituitary adenoma that secretes prolactin, leading to galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances, and infertility in women.

  • The absence of pregnancy rules out physiological galactorrhea.
  • In patients unwilling to undergo surgery, dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine or Cabergoline) are the first-line drugs.
  • They lower prolactin secretion, shrink tumor size, and restore gonadal function.
  • Bromocriptine is the traditional choice, while Cabergoline is often preferred due to fewer side effects.

Prolactinoma Overview:

  • Nature: Benign pituitary adenoma producing prolactin.
  • Causes: Usually sporadic; sometimes linked with MEN 1 syndrome or RET mutations.
  • Classification:
    • Microadenoma: <1 cm, often limited to endocrine symptoms.
    • Macroadenoma: >1 cm, may cause mass effects like headaches or visual field defects (e.g., bitemporal hemianopia).
  • Clinical features:
    • Women: Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility.
    • Men: Erectile dysfunction, decreased libido.
    • Both sexes: Headache, diplopia, or visual loss in large tumors.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Raised serum prolactin.
    • MRI pituitary for localization and size.
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: Dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine, Cabergoline).
    • Surgery (transsphenoidal resection): For drug-resistant or intolerant cases.
    • Radiotherapy: Reserved for refractory tumors.

Explanation of other options:

Promethazine (Option B): Antihistamine used for allergies, nausea, and motion sickness; not effective in prolactinoma.

Octreotide (Option C): Somatostatin analog mainly used in acromegaly, variceal bleeding, and certain neuroendocrine tumors; not first-line in prolactinoma.

Clozapine (Option D): An atypical antipsychotic indicated for refractory schizophrenia; not used in endocrine tumors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bromocriptine (dopamine agonist) is the drug of choice for prolactinoma in patients declining surgery.
  • Cabergoline is an alternative with better tolerability.
  • Surgery and radiotherapy are reserved for refractory or complicated cases.

References:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1116493/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3487282/

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department after consuming ten paracetamol tablets. He now has oliguria, and his liver function tests are abnormal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation with a history of paracetamol overdose, oliguria, and deranged liver function strongly suggests paracetamol-induced hepatotoxicity. The specific antidote in this situation is N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) Toxicity:

  • Most common cause of acute liver failure worldwide.
  • Toxic dose: Ingesting ≥25 g may be fatal.
  • Clinical features: Oliguria, elevated liver enzymes, signs of hepatic injury.

Mechanism of Toxicity:

  • Normally, paracetamol is metabolized in the liver.
  • A fraction is converted via CYP2E1 into a toxic metabolite, NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine).
  • In overdose, glutathione stores become depleted, leading to accumulation of NAPQI, which causes hepatocellular necrosis.

Management:

  • Antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC).
    • Mechanism: Restores glutathione reserves, thereby detoxifying NAPQI.
    • Timing: Most effective when administered within 8 hours of overdose; benefit persists up to 36 hours.
  • Severe cases: Liver transplantation may be required if fulminant hepatic failure develops despite NAC therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Dopamine (Option B): Used in cardiogenic or septic shock; has no role in paracetamol toxicity.

Ursodeoxycholic acid (Option C): Utilized in cholestatic liver diseases such as primary biliary cholangitis, not in drug-induced hepatic injury.

Furosemide (Option D): A loop diuretic for fluid overload; does not treat paracetamol-induced hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaways:

  • N-acetylcysteine is the drug of choice in paracetamol overdose.
  • Works best within 8 hours but still beneficial later.
  • In refractory cases, liver transplantation is the definitive treatment.

References: https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.107.728840

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with migratory arthritis, and clinical examination detected a pansystolic murmur. Echocardiography indicated mitral regurgitation. A biopsy sample was taken, and the accompanying histopathology image is shown. What lesion is most likely demonstrated on the slide?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion most likely depicted in the histopathological slide is Aschoff bodies.

  • Aschoff bodies are the classic histological marker of rheumatic fever.
  • The combination of migratory arthritis, a pansystolic murmur, mitral regurgitation, and typical granulomatous lesions in this patient indicates rheumatic heart disease secondary to rheumatic fever.


Explanations of other options:

Epithelioid granuloma (Option B): Epithelioid granulomas are a hallmark of tuberculosis and other granulomatous conditions such as sarcoidosis, but they are not usually present in rheumatic fever.

Granulomatous vasculitis (Option C): Granulomatous vasculitis is characterised by inflammation of blood vessels with granuloma formation in their walls, commonly occurring in conditions such as Wegener's granulomatosis or Takayasu arteritis, but not in rheumatic fever.

Granuloma inguinale (Option D): Granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, produces ulcerative genital lesions but is not associated with heart murmurs, mitral regurgitation, or migratory arthritis.

questions.text: A girl with short stature, webbed neck, broad chest, ankle swelling, prominent calf muscles, and an increased carrying angle most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described features are typical of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder resulting from complete or partial loss of one X chromosome (45 XO), leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

The following illustration depicts features of Turner syndrome.



Down syndrome (Option B): Down syndrome is caused by Trisomy 21 and is characterised by intellectual disability, epicanthal folds, a flat facial appearance, and congenital heart abnormalities, but it lacks the distinct skeletal and physical traits observed in Turner syndrome.

Patau syndrome (Option C): Patau syndrome, caused by trisomy 13, presents with features such as microphthalmia, microcephaly, rocker-bottom feet, polycystic kidney disease, and congenital heart defects, which do not match the clinical findings described in the case.

Edward syndrome (Option D): Edward syndrome, resulting from an additional copy of chromosome 18 (Trisomy 18), is marked by profound developmental delay, clenched hands, rocker-bottom feet, and cardiac abnormalities, which are distinct from the manifestations of Turner syndrome.


References: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/congenital-cytogenetic-abnormalities

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass, as shown in the image below. What will be done next for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A tender pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular origin, most often an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm.
  • Ultrasound Doppler is the most appropriate next step as it is non-invasive, readily available, and provides real-time information on blood flow.
  • It confirms whether the swelling is vascular and distinguishes between a true aneurysm and a pseudoaneurysm.
  • It also helps determine size, morphology, and the need for further advanced imaging such as CT angiography.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Needle aspiration (Option B): Aspiration is suited for fluid-filled collections like abscesses. Attempting it in a pulsatile swelling risks catastrophic hemorrhage if the mass is vascular.

CT angiogram with percutaneous management (Option C): This is a definitive imaging and treatment modality, but it is not the first step. Ultrasound Doppler must be performed first to establish the diagnosis before moving to CT.

Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days (Option D): Antibiotics are appropriate for cellulitis or abscesses, not for a vascular swelling like an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm.

Key Takeaway:

A tender pulsatile swelling should first be assessed with Ultrasound Doppler to confirm vascular involvement and to differentiate a true aneurysm from a pseudoaneurysm before any invasive procedure is planned.

questions.text: A patient on diuretic therapy presents with generalized weakness. ECG demonstrates flattened T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of flattened T waves and prominent U waves on ECG in a patient taking diuretics is characteristic of hypokalemia. This condition occurs when serum potassium levels drop below 3.5 mEq/L.

  • Clinical Features:
    • Muscle weakness, cramps, fatigue, or paralysis
    • Constipation/ileus due to smooth muscle dysfunction
    • Severe cases: cardiac arrhythmias
  • Common Causes:
    • Diuretic use (loop & thiazide diuretics): Increased renal potassium excretion
    • Metabolic alkalosis: Potassium shift into cells due to elevated extracellular pH
    • Excess β-adrenergic activity: Potassium shift into cells (e.g., asthma treatment with β-agonists)
    • GI losses: Vomiting or diarrhea → potassium depletion
    • Other: Insulin therapy, magnesium deficiency, hyperaldosteronism
  • ECG Findings:
    • Flattened T waves
    • Prominent U waves
    • ST segment depression
    • Prolonged QT interval
    • Severe depletion may cause ventricular tachyarrhythmias or fibrillation

  • Management:
    • Oral potassium chloride in mild cases
    • Intravenous potassium in severe or symptomatic hypokalemia (given cautiously to avoid rebound hyperkalemia)
    • Always correct underlying cause

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypocalcemia (Option A): Causes tetany, paresthesias, and muscle cramps. ECG shows prolonged QT interval without U waves.

Hypomagnesemia (Option B): Presents with weakness and arrhythmias; ECG shows torsades de pointes.

Hyperkalemia (Option C): Causes muscle weakness/paralysis. ECG shows tall peaked T waves, short QT interval, and wide QRS complex.


Key Takeaways:

  • Hypokalemia is the hallmark electrolyte abnormality producing U waves on ECG.
  • Diuretics are a leading cause.
  • Prompt recognition and potassium replacement prevent life-threatening arrhythmias.

questions.text: A child presents with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and knee joint pain due to arthritis. Urinalysis reveals hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint involvement, hematuria, and proteinuria in this child is most indicative of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP).



Explanation of other options:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A): ITP presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and usually shows non-blanching purpura, without associated arthritis, abdominal pain, or kidney involvement.

Dengue (Option B): Dengue typically manifests with high fever, rash, intense headache, and pain behind the eyes. Although petechiae may appear, purpura and kidney involvement are not common features.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Option C): Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, is an ANCA-associated vasculitis characterised by asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous inflammation. Unlike HSP, it typically does not present with palpable purpura or kidney involvement.

questions.text: A patient's Pap smear showed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear margins, and a low maturation index affecting the full thickness of the epithelium without invading the basement membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Pap smear findings of hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear margins, and a low maturation index affecting the full thickness of the epithelium without invading the basement membrane are typical of dysplasia, a precancerous lesion.

  • Dysplasia represents atypical cellular growth and differentiation, typically limited to the epithelial layer without breaching the basement membrane.
  • In the early phase, it is reversible, but if it progresses to involve the full epithelial thickness, it may become irreversible.

Explanations of other options:

Carcinoma (Option B): Carcinoma refers to invasive cancer in which abnormal cells cross the basement membrane and extend beyond the epithelial layer. Since the description specifies an intact basement membrane, carcinoma can be excluded.

Metaplasia (Option C): Metaplasia is the process where one cell type is replaced by another, usually as an adaptive response to injury, chronic irritation, or repair. This does not account for the nuclear abnormalities, such as hyperchromasia and irregular borders, described in the Pap smear.

Hyperplasia (Option D): Hyperplasia refers to a rise in the number of cells within a tissue, usually triggered by a stimulus. It generally lacks nuclear abnormalities such as hyperchromasia and irregular borders, which are more suggestive of dysplasia.

questions.text: A female presents with a unilateral headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. Which of the following is the drug of choice for acute treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triad of unilateral headache, nausea, and sensory hypersensitivity (photophobia/phonophobia) is classic for an acute migraine attack.
  • Sumatriptan, a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist, is the drug of choice for acute migraine management.
  • Mechanism of action: Causes cranial vasoconstriction and inhibits trigeminovascular nociceptive pathways, rapidly relieving migraine symptoms.

Acute management of migraine:

  • First-line: NSAIDs, Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan).
  • Other options: Gepants (rimegepant), Ditans (lasmiditan).
  • Supportive therapy: Antiemetics (e.g., domperidone, metoclopramide) for associated nausea.

Prophylaxis for recurrent migraine attacks:

  • Flunarizine (Option A): Calcium channel blocker.
  • Propranolol (Option C): Non-selective β-blocker.
  • Topiramate (Option D): Anticonvulsant with preventive benefit.
  • Other options: Amitriptyline (TCA).

Explanation of other options:

Flunarizine (Option A): Used for prophylaxis, not acute attacks.

Propranolol (Option C): Effective in prevention, but not for acute relief.

Topiramate (Option D): Preventive therapy, not used during acute episodes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sumatriptan is the gold standard for acute migraine therapy.
  • Preventive therapy is reserved for frequent or severe migraine attacks.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anaemia and hemoglobin in the urine. Tests show elevated bilirubin and lactate dehydrogenase. The provided peripheral smear image is shown. Which of the following conditions is linked to this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Considering the anaemia, associated findings, and the peripheral smear revealing fragmented RBCs (schistocytes), the most probable diagnosis is microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia, which may occur in conditions such as hemolytic uremic syndrome or with mechanical heart valves.

  • Mechanical heart valves can cause intravascular hemolysis due to the turbulence of blood flow around the valve, leading to red blood cell fragmentation, hemoglobinuria, increased bilirubin, and elevated LDH.
  • The schistocytes are marked in the following image.

Explanation of other options:

Splenomegaly (Option A): Splenomegaly is often linked to chronic hemolytic anemias, but in this scenario, the presence of hemoglobinuria, raised bilirubin, and elevated LDH is more indicative of mechanical hemolysis, which usually does not lead to spleen enlargement.

Increased HbA2 (Option C): A rise in HbA2 is characteristic of beta-thalassemia, a hereditary defect in haemoglobin synthesis caused by reduced beta-globin chain production, resulting in a relative increase in HbA2. However, beta-thalassemia does not produce hemoglobinuria or the acute hemolysis features seen in this case.

Goitre (Option D): Goitre is an enlargement of the thyroid gland, usually linked to thyroid disease. In this patient, the symptoms and test findings suggest a hematological issue, namely hemolysis, which is unrelated to thyroid conditions such as goitre.

Reference:

https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/780702-overview?form=fpf

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal

questions.text: Why do cancer cells make use of Warburg metabolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neoplastic cells utilise Warburg metabolism because it forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication.

  • The Warburg effect is a hallmark of cancer cell metabolism, where tumor cells, despite having adequate oxygen, display increased glucose uptake and preferentially convert it to lactate through glycolysis (Option A ruled out).
  • This metabolic reprogramming does not enhance ATP generation but supplies essential intermediates that support rapid proliferation (Option C ruled out).
  • Otto Warburg received the Nobel Prize in 1931 for this discovery.
  • This principle underlies positron emission tomography (PET), where patients are given 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), a glucose analogue that accumulates in tumor cells due to their high glucose demand, allowing detection by PET imaging.

Explanations of other options:

It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal (Option D): Although Warburg metabolism may contribute to cell survival and resistance against stress, its main role is not to block apoptosis or ensure immortality. Rather, it supports the heightened metabolic needs of fast-growing cancer cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic alcoholic presents with oral ulcers and a burning sensation. A picture of the oral cavity is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leukoplakia is the most common precancerous lesion of the oral cavity.
  • It presents as white plaques or patches on the mucosal surfaces that cannot be scraped off.
  • Strongly associated with smoking, alcohol, chronic irritation, and sometimes nutritional deficiencies.
  • The patient here has a history of chronic alcoholism, oral ulcers, and burning sensation, all fitting with the presentation of leukoplakia.

Leukoplakia details:

  • Definition: White patch on the oral mucosa not attributable to other causes like candidiasis or lichen planus.
  • Common causes: Tobacco chewing, smoking, alcohol abuse, chronic trauma from dentures or cheek biting.
  • Common sites: Buccal mucosa, floor of mouth, tongue, oral commissures, lip mucosa.
  • Types:
    • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignant risk.
    • Nodular: White plaques on red base, higher risk.
    • Erosive/Erythroleukoplakia: Highest malignant transformation risk.
  • Malignant potential: 1-17.5% (average ~5%); higher with dysplasia and in high-risk sites.
  • Management: Remove risk factors, biopsy suspicious lesions, excision/laser therapy for dysplastic or persistent lesions.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Erythroplakia (Option B): A fiery red velvety patch of the mucosa that carries a higher risk of malignant transformation than leukoplakia, but it does not typically present with white patches as in this patient.

Submucosal fibrosis (Option C): A progressive condition due to areca nut chewing leading to fibrosis of the submucosa, trismus, and reduced mouth opening, not typically presenting as white plaques with burning sensation.

Malakoplakia (Option D): A rare granulomatous disease often seen in the urinary tract, caused by chronic infection and immunodeficiency, and not associated with oral mucosal white patches or leukoplakia-like lesions.

Key Takeaway: Leukoplakia is a white precancerous lesion of the oral cavity commonly linked to smoking and alcohol, with a risk of malignant transformation. Careful evaluation and biopsy of suspicious areas are essential.

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with ageing
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with ageing
Decreased telomere length is associated with ageing
Increased telomere length is associated with ageing

questions.text: Select the accurate statement related to the telomerase theory of aging:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct statement related to the telomerase theory of ageing is "decreased telomere length is associated with ageing".

  • The telomerase theory of aging proposes that telomere length serves as a marker of biological aging, as telomeres progressively shorten with each cell division, eventually causing cellular senescence and contributing to aging and age-related diseases (Option D is ruled out).
  • Telomerase, sometimes called the "immortality enzyme," is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase that extends chromosome ends by adding DNA sequences, thereby delaying telomere shortening during replication.
  • In most somatic cells, telomerase activity declines with age, leading to gradual telomere erosion.
  • Once telomeres reach a critically short length, they lose their protective function, resulting in genomic instability and ultimately triggering cell senescence or cell death.

Explanation of other options:

Telomere stability is associated with ageing (Option A): Telomere stability means preserving telomere length, the protective ends of chromosomes. However, with aging, telomeres progressively shorten instead of staying stable, making telomere shortening a major contributor to cellular aging.

Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with ageing (Option B): Abnormal activation of telomerase is mainly linked to cancer, allowing cells to bypass normal aging and keep dividing. In contrast, during aging, telomerase activity usually decreases rather than rises.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with abdominal dragging pain and is found to have massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear reveals leukocytosis with elevated myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils. Which chromosomal translocation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abdominal dragging pain, massive splenomegaly, and peripheral smear findings point to Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), which is characterised by the Philadelphia chromosome caused by the t(9;22) translocation.

Explanation of options:

t(8;21) (Option B): The t(8;21) translocation produces the RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion gene, a genetic abnormality frequently associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

t(15;17) (Option C): The t(15;17) chromosomal translocation gives rise to the PML-RARA fusion gene, a defining feature of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

t(8;14) (Option D): The t(8;14) translocation affects the MYC gene and is a hallmark feature of Burkitt lymphoma.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6415732/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3100545/

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with his medications presents with sudden-onset severe breathlessness. Chest X-ray findings are consistent with pulmonary edema. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation indicates acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (ACPE), a medical emergency often precipitated by severe hypertension, myocardial infarction, or medication non-compliance.

  • Intravenous nitroglycerin is the drug of choice as it provides rapid relief by reducing preload and afterload via venodilation, thereby decreasing pulmonary venous pressure.

Clinical Features of ACPE:

  • Symptoms: Sudden dyspnea, pink frothy sputum, cyanosis, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
  • Signs: Tachypnea, rales and rhonchi on auscultation, raised jugular venous pressure, gallop rhythm.
  • Chest X-ray findings: Interstitial edema, alveolar edema in "butterfly pattern," cardiomegaly.

Management of Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:

  • IV Nitroglycerin: First-line agent; start sublingual, escalate to IV if required. Rapid symptom relief without hypotension.
  • Oxygen therapy: Maintain SpO2 >92%; non-invasive ventilation (NIPPV) or intubation if severe.
  • Diuretics (e.g., furosemide): Used after stabilization to remove excess fluid.
  • Morphine: Reduces anxiety and provides venodilation; use cautiously due to risk of respiratory depression.
  • Positioning: Upright posture with legs dependent reduces venous return.

Explanation of other options:

Intravenous salbutamol (Option A): Salbutamol is a β2-agonist used in asthma and hyperkalemia, not in pulmonary edema.

Nebulization with salbutamol (Option C): Similar to Option A; appropriate in obstructive airway disease, not ACPE.

Oxygen and antibiotics (Option D): Oxygen is beneficial, but antibiotics are unnecessary unless infection (e.g., pneumonia) coexists.

Key Takeaways:

  • Intravenous nitroglycerin is the first-line drug in ACPE.
  • Oxygen and diuretics are supportive measures after stabilization.
  • Antibiotics are not part of routine management unless secondary infection is present.

References:

https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/full/10.1161/JAHA.119.013441

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31587602/

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A, but they are not a feature of MEN 2B.

  • MEN 2B (also referred to as MEN 3) is an uncommon inherited disorder resulting from gain-of-function mutations in the RET proto-oncogene on chromosome 10q11.2.

Key Features of MEN 2B:

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): Most common; aggressive, often presenting at a young age.
  • Pheochromocytoma: Usually bilateral, presenting with palpitations, headache, and sweating.
  • Mucosal Neuromas (Option C ruled out): Seen as thickened lips, tongue, and eyelid nodules.
  • Marfanoid Habitus (Option D ruled out): Tall stature, long limbs, arachnodactyly, hypermobile joints.
  • Megacolon (Option A ruled out): Due to autonomic ganglion dysfunction of the intestine.
  • Additional findings: Thickened corneal nerve fibers, delayed puberty.

questions.text: A patient had a cystoscopy that revealed several yellowish-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The provided histopathology image is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone on cystoscopy, along with histology showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, is indicative of malakoplakia.

  • Malakoplakia is an uncommon inflammatory disorder that frequently occurs in immunocompromised individuals, such as patients on long-term immunosuppressive therapy after organ transplantation.

Explanation of other options:

Interstitial cystitis (Option A): Interstitial cystitis is a long-term disorder marked by bladder pain, urgency, and frequent urination, usually lacking distinct histological markers such as Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. On cystoscopy, it typically presents with Hunner’s ulcers or reduced bladder capacity, rather than yellow-white plaques.

Polypoid cystitis (Option C): Polypoid cystitis is a non-cancerous inflammatory condition characterized by the formation of inflammatory polyps, but it lacks Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

Acute cystitis (Option D): Acute cystitis, a frequent urinary tract infection, typically presents with urgency, frequency, and painful urination but does not produce yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564348/

https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/bladdermalakoplakia.html

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image corresponds to a Stage 4 pressure sore, the most advanced type of ulcer.
  • Stage 4 ulcers show extensive tissue damage extending through the skin into deeper structures such as muscle, tendon, and bone.
  • They are associated with a high risk of infection, osteomyelitis, and sepsis if not managed promptly.

Pressure Sore Stages

  • Stage I (Option A ruled out): Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. No break in the epidermis.
  • Stage II (Option B ruled out): Partial-thickness skin loss involving epidermis and dermis. Presents as a shallow open ulcer or blister.
  • Stage III (Option C ruled out): Full-thickness skin loss with damage to subcutaneous tissue but not extending through underlying fascia.
  • Stage IV: Full-thickness skin loss with exposure of bone, muscle, tendon, or joint. Often accompanied by undermining and tunneling.

Key Takeaway:

Stage 4 pressure ulcers are the most severe form, with deep tissue involvement and high risk of complications, requiring aggressive wound care, debridement, and often surgical intervention.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of gum bleeding and fever lasting 2 months. On examination, he was pale, though systemic findings were normal. Lab tests showed hemoglobin at 3 g/dl, total leukocyte count of 1500/μL, and platelet count of 15,000/μL. The peripheral smear revealed macrocytes with a reticulocyte count of 0.5%. Bone marrow analysis demonstrated fatty replacement with absent megakaryocytes and no immature cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of gum bleeding, fever, pallor, profound anemia, low white cell and platelet counts, along with peripheral smear findings and bone marrow biopsy showing fatty replacement, is highly indicative of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia (AAA).

  • Aplastic Anemia is characterised by bone marrow failure, where the bone marrow does not produce enough blood cells, leading to pancytopenia.
  • In severe cases, the bone marrow may become hypocellular, making it difficult to aspirate sufficient material, leading to a dry tap.
  • The absence of immature cells and the presence of fatty streaks in the bone marrow suggests bone marrow failure, typical of aplastic anemia, where normal hematopoiesis is replaced by fat.

Explanation of other options:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B): Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an uncommon condition in which red blood cells are destroyed early by complement activation. It presents with hemolytic anaemia and hemoglobinuria, with peripheral smears typically showing signs of hemolysis, which are absent in this case.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (Option C): Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) comprises a group of conditions marked by defective blood formation and abnormal cells in the bone marrow. Although it can present with pancytopenia, the marrow usually displays dysplastic changes with abnormal cell morphology, which are not observed in this case.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, is not typically linked to profound pancytopenia, fatty marrow replacement, or loss of megakaryocytes. When TB affects the bone marrow, it more often shows features such as granuloma formation.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8432379/

questions.text: A retro-positive patient has been started on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following is the best parameter to monitor treatment efficacy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Viral load (HIV RNA levels) is the most reliable marker for assessing the efficacy of HAART.
  • It reflects the degree of viral replication and treatment response.
  • A significant drop (≥10-fold) is expected within 1-2 months of therapy, with the target being <50 copies/mL within 6 months of treatment initiation.

Explanation of other options:

CD4+ T cell count (Option A): Indicates immune reconstitution and helps stage disease but is less sensitive for early response compared to viral load.

p24 antigen (Option C): A structural core protein used in early diagnosis before antibody formation; not used for treatment monitoring.

Viral serotype (Option D): Identifies viral subtype (commonly HIV-1) but has no role in monitoring therapeutic efficacy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Viral load monitoring is the gold standard for assessing HAART response.
  • CD4+ count is useful for staging and prognosis but not the primary efficacy marker.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4872286/

questions.text: Identify the fluid shown below on the basis of composition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The composition provided exactly matches Ringer's lactate (Hartmann's solution), a balanced crystalloid used widely in surgery, trauma, and fluid resuscitation.
  • Composition:
    • Sodium: 131 mmol/L
    • Chloride: 111 mmol/L
    • Potassium: 5 mmol/L
    • Calcium: 2 mmol/L
    • Lactate: 29 mmol/L (converted to bicarbonate in the liver, acting as a buffer)
    • Osmolarity: 279 mmol/L (close to plasma osmolarity)
  • Uses:
    • Maintenance fluid during surgery
    • Resuscitation in hypovolemia and burns
    • Corrects acidosis (lactate → bicarbonate)
  • Advantage: Unlike normal saline, it does not cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Haemaccel (Option A): A colloid plasma expander containing degraded gelatin, sodium chloride, potassium chloride, and calcium chloride. It restores blood volume but does not have the same electrolyte profile as Ringer's lactate.

Isolyte (Option C): An isotonic solution with sodium, potassium, magnesium, chloride, acetate, phosphate, and sometimes dextrose. Its composition differs from Ringer's lactate and is mainly used for hydration and electrolyte balance.

Isolyte M (Option D): Contains sodium, potassium, chloride, acetate, and dextrose, with a different composition, and is used in pediatric maintenance therapy. It does not match the given electrolyte distribution.

Key Takeaway:

Ringer's lactate is a balanced crystalloid solution containing sodium, potassium, calcium, chloride, and lactate, making it the fluid described here. It is preferred in surgical and resuscitation settings due to its buffering capacity and similarity to plasma composition.

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, joint pains, oral ulcers, and fatigue for six months, now associated with hematuria. Urine analysis reveals red blood cell casts and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of systemic features of SLE (fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue) along with renal involvement (RBC casts, proteinuria, hematuria) strongly indicates lupus nephritis, a renal manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus caused by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

Lupus Nephritis:

  • Pathophysiology: Immune complex-mediated glomerular injury involving anti-dsDNA antibodies.
  • Clinical features:
    • Proteinuria (may reach nephrotic levels)
    • Hematuria with RBC casts
    • Systemic SLE manifestations: fever, arthralgia, oral/nasal ulcers, photosensitivity, fatigue
    • Risk of progression to hypertension and ESRD if untreated
  • Diagnosis:
    • Urinalysis: proteinuria, hematuria, RBC casts
    • Serology: ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm positivity
    • Renal biopsy: classification into six histological classes (I-VI)
  • Management:
    • Corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil
    • Hydroxychloroquine (for systemic SLE; safe in pregnancy)

Explanation of other options:

Acute interstitial nephritis (Option A): Typically drug-induced (e.g., NSAIDs, antibiotics) or due to infections. Presents with fever, rash, eosinophilia, and urine showing WBC casts-not RBC casts.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option B): Seen in children post-streptococcal infection; presents with hematuria, edema, and hypertension, but lacks systemic lupus features such as ulcers or arthritis.

IgA nephropathy (Option D): Often presents with recurrent hematuria following an upper respiratory infection; shows mesangial IgA deposits on biopsy but does not include systemic SLE manifestations.

Key Takeaways:

  • RBC casts + systemic SLE features = lupus nephritis.
  • Always confirm with serology and renal biopsy for classification and prognosis.
  • Requires immunosuppressive therapy to prevent progression to renal failure.
